text: After the death of Saul, David returned from the slaughter of the Amalekites and stayed in Ziklag two days.

translation_challanges.note: See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. The author is using it to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method here that is natural in your language for introducing a new development.

The author is using **David** to represent him and his men. See the discussion of this usage in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that David and his men returned]

Here the name of a person, **Amalek**, represents his descendants. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Amalekites]
See the discussion of the term “strike” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [from slaughtering the Amalekites]

The author is expressing this in the way his culture reckoned time. He does not mean that David and his men arrived in Ziklag and stayed there for two subsequent days before something further happened. He is reckoning the day of their arrival as the first of these **two days**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that day and the next one]

text: On the third day a man with torn clothes and dust on his head arrived from Saul’s camp. When he came to David, he fell to the ground to pay him homage.

translation_challanges.note: In this case, the author is using this phrase to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method here that is natural in your language for introducing a new development.

In this culture, the current day was considered the first day, the next day was considered the second day, and the day after that was considered **the third day**. So this phrase is referring to the day after the day after David returned to Ziklag. Express this in terms that your language and culture would naturally use. Alternate translation: [on the next day]
See the discussion of the expression “behold” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel to decide how to represent it in your translation here and throughout the book.

If your language does not use a passive form such as **were torn**, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. You could also identify this man as the one responsible for the **dirt** being on his **head**. Alternate translation: [and he had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head]

This was a symbolic action that showed the man was in mourning. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he had torn his clothes and put dirt on his head to show that he was grieving]

Be sure it is clear in your translation that this man did not fall down accidentally. He knelt down in front of David as a gesture to honor him. He then **prostrated himself** or stretched out flat on the ground to show David great honor. Alternate translation: [and he knelt on the ground in front of David, stretching himself out flat, to honor him greatly]

text: “Where have you come from?” David asked. “I have escaped from the Israelite camp,” he replied.

translation_challanges.note: David is using a common expression of his culture. The expression combines a question and an anticipated answer: “**Where** are you coming **from**?” “I am coming from **this** place.” It may be more natural in your language to translate this without reflecting the anticipated answer. Alternate translation: [Where are you coming from?]

text: “What was the outcome?” David asked. “Please tell me.” “The troops fled from the battle,” he replied. “Many of them fell and died. And Saul and his son Jonathan are also dead.”

translation_challanges.note: It may be more natural in your language to have a direct quotation here. Alternate translation: [And he said, “The people fled from the battle, and also many from the people fell and died, and even Saul and Jonathan his son died.”]

By **the people**, the young man means the Israelite army. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the army … from the army]

The verbs **fallen** and **died** together also express a single idea. The verb **fallen** tells in what way these soldiers had **died**. Specifically, this was by being mortally wounded in battle, which caused them to fall to the ground. Alternate translation: [had died of their wounds] or [had died in battle]

text: Then David asked the young man who had brought him the report, “How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?”
“I happened to be on Mount Gilboa,” he replied, “and there was Saul, leaning on his spear, with the chariots and the cavalry closing in on him.

translation_challanges.note: Since the author has already identified this **young man** in the previous verse, it might seem that identifying him again here in the same way would be extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could leave it out. Alternate translation: [And the young man said]

The young man is repeating forms of the same verb in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I just happened to be]

text: When he turned around and saw me, he called out to me, and I answered, ‘Here I am!’

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and I asked what I could do for him]

The young man says he responded to Saul with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Yes, sir?]

text: ‘Who are you?’ he asked. So I told him, ‘I am an Amalekite.’

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And he asked me who I was, and I told him that I was an Amalekite]

text: Then he begged me, ‘Stand over me and kill me, for agony has seized me, but my life still lingers.’

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And he asked me please to stand over him and kill him, for agony had seized him, for his life was still whole in him]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since my life is still whole in me, agony has seized me, so please stand over me and kill me]

The young man claims that Saul spoke of **agony** as if it were a living thing that could have **seized** him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. This could mean: (1) that Saul is in such pain from his wounds that he is no longer capable of fighting. The **agony** would be restraining him in that sense, as if it had **seized** him and was holding him immobile. Alternate translation: [I am in too much pain to defend myself]; (2) that Saul has an overwhelming sense of pain. Alternate translation: [I am in very great agony]

This could mean: (1) that Saul is using a common expression of his culture to mean that he wants this young man to use violence against him. In this context, the expression **stand over me** may be equivalent to the expression “rise up against” in [22:49](../22/49.md). Alternate translation: [attack me and kill me]; (2) that Saul actually wants the young man to **stand over** him and use all of his weight to push a sword or spear into him and kill him. Alternate translation: [stab me with all your weight and kill me]

By **my life {is} still whole in me**, Saul means that he is badly wounded, but not mortally wounded. He will not die imminently from the wounds he currently has. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [I am badly wounded, but not wounded mortally]

text: So I stood over him and killed him, because I knew that after he had fallen he could not survive. And I took the crown that was on his head and the band that was on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [So because I knew that he would not live after his having fallen, I stood over him and killed him]

The young man is using a common expression of his culture, **I stood over him**, to mean that he attacked Saul. See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [So I attacked him and killed him] or [So I stabbed him with all my weight and killed him]

The young man does not mean that Saul had actually **fallen** to the ground. He says in [1:6](../01/06.md) that Saul was standing up, leaning on his spear. The young man is speaking of Saul being badly defeated by the Philistines as if Saul had fallen from a height. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the Philistines would surely kill him now that they had defeated his entire army]

A **crown** is a decorative headpiece that shows that a person is a king. In this context, the term describes a narrow band of gold encircling Saul’s helmet, not a large, ornamental headpiece with jewels. The **band on his arm** was probably a decorative item worn on the arm to show that the person was a king. If your readers would not be familiar with what these items are, in your translation you could use the name of similar things that your readers would recognize, or you could use a general expression. Alternate translation: [the royal headpiece that was on his head and the royal armband that was on his arm]

Even though the young man is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my master** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [to you, my master]

text: Then David took hold of his own clothes and tore them, and all the men who were with him did the same.

translation_challanges.note: This was a symbolic action that showed David was feeling shock and grief. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [And David seized his clothes and tore them to show that he was shocked and grieving]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and all the men who were with him also seized their clothes and tore them]

text: They mourned and wept and fasted until evening for Saul and his son Jonathan, and for the people of the LORD and the house of Israel, because they had fallen by the sword.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And because Saul and Jonathan his son and the people of Yahweh had fallen by the sword, they mourned and wept and fasted until the evening for them and for the house of Israel]
By **the people of Yahweh**, the author means the Israelite army. See how you translated the term “people” in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the army of Yahweh] or [the Israelite army]

Here, **house** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of Israel** figuratively means all the people descended from the man named Israel (who was also known as Jacob). If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the nation of Israel]

The author is using the term **fallen** by association to mean that they had died, since soldiers fall down when they die. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [they had died]

The author is using the term **sword** by association to mean battle, since swords were used in battle. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in battle]

text: And David inquired of the young man who had brought him the report, “Where are you from?” “I am the son of a foreigner,” he answered. “I am an Amalekite.”

translation_challanges.note: David is using a common expression of his culture. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:3](../01/03.md). Alternate translation: [Where are you from]

The man is using this expression to introduce his father as a participant in his story. Your language may have its own way of introducing participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a certain foreigner]

text: So David asked him, “Why were you not afraid to lift your hand to destroy the LORD’s anointed?”

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should have feared to stretch out your hand to destroy the anointed of Yahweh!]

David is using a common expression of his culture, **stretch out your hand**, to mean attacking or violently harming someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to use violence to destroy]

David is using the adjective **anointed** as a noun to mean a particular of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase, here and in [verse 16](../01/16.md). Alternate translation: [the anointed one of Yahweh] or [the one whom Yahweh anointed]

text: Then David summoned one of the young men and said, “Go, execute him!” So the young man struck him down, and he died.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the term “striking” in [1:1](../01/01.md) in light of the discussion in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [attack … And he attacked him]

The phrase **and he said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this phrase explicitly.

text: For David had said to the Amalekite, “Your blood be on your own head because your own mouth has testified against you, saying, ‘I killed the LORD’s anointed.’”

translation_challanges.note: This could mean: (1) that David is speaking to the Amalekite even though he cannot hear him (since he is already dead) in order to show in a strong way how he feels about his claim that he killed Saul. He would actually be speaking to the people who can hear him, the men around him. If this would not be clear to your readers, you could translate David’s words as if he were speaking directly to those who can hear him. Alternate translation: [And David said, “His blood is on his own head, for his mouth answered against him, saying, ‘I myself killed the anointed of Yahweh]; (2) that the young man had not died yet and David was speaking to him directly. (The author’s statement in the previous verse, “and he died,” would be a description of what ultimately happened.) Alternate translation: [And David said to him as he was dying, “Your blood {is} on your head, for your mouth answered against you, saying, ‘I myself killed the anointed of Yahweh]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since your mouth answered against you, saying, ‘I myself killed the anointed of Yahweh,’ your blood is on your head]

David is using the term **blood** by association to mean “death,” since the young man he summoned shed the Amalekite’s blood when he killed him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Your death is on your head]

When David says **on your head**, he is using a common expression that means that someone is morally and legally responsible for something. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You are responsible for your own death]

David is speaking of the young man’s **mouth** as if it were a living thing that could testify against him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you testified against yourself]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that you yourself killed the anointed of Yahweh]

The term **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly, here and throughout your translation.

text: Then David took up this lament for Saul and his son Jonathan,

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Then David made this lamentation]

text: and he ordered that the sons of Judah be taught the Song of the Bow. It is written in the Book of Jashar:

translation_challanges.note: See the discussion of the phrase **sons of** in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the people of Judah]
**The Bow** is the name of a song. In your translation, use the appropriate conventions of your language to indicate this.

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [one can read the words to this song in the Book of Jashar]

This is the title of a book. In your translation, use the appropriate conventions of your language to indicate this. You can spell the word **Jashar** the way it sounds in your language, or you could use a word or phrase from your language that expresses the meaning of this name. Alternate translation: [the Book of the Upright]

text: “Your glory, O Israel, lies slain on your heights. How the mighty have fallen!

translation_challanges.note: David is speaking to the nation of Israel as if it were a person who could hear him. He is doing this to show in a strong way how he feels about the deaths of Saul and Jonathan. He is actually speaking to the people who can hear him, the people of Judah who will eventually learn this song. If this would not be clear to your readers, you could translate David’s words as if he were speaking directly to those who could hear him. Alternate translation: [The splendor of Israel {is} slain on its high places]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **splendor**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [The men who made Israel splendid lie slain]

David is speaking about **Israel** in the third person even though he is addressing that nation directly. If you retain the direct address in your translation, you could translate this in the second person if that would be helpful in your language. Alternate translation: [Your splendor, O Israel]

The word **your** here is singular because David is addressing the nation of Israel as if it were a single person. So use the singular form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

David is using the term **fallen** by association to mean “died,” since these soldiers fell down when they died. See how you translated this word in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [How the mighty have died]

David is using the adjective **mighty** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [How these mighty warriors have died]

David is using a phrase that expresses a strong feeling, great sorrow that the mighty warriors have died. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this feeling. If not, you could indicate specifically what David was feeling. Alternate translation: [I am so sad that these mighty warriors have died]

text: Tell it not in Gath; proclaim it not in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, and the daughters of the uncircumcised exult.

translation_challanges.note: David is not using the pronoun **they** to refer to specific people. Use a comparable expression that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [May no one declare it in Gath, may no one proclaim it in the streets of Ashkelon] or [May it not be declared in Gath, may it not be proclaimed in the streets of Ashkelon]

Following the customary practice of Hebrew poetry, David is using two phrases together that mean basically the same thing. See the discussion of this practice in the Introduction to this chapter to help you decide how you will represent such pairs of phrases in your translation.
Here the term **daughters** has the same kind of meaning as the term **sons** in [1:18](../01/18.md). See how you decided to translate that term there. Alternate translation: [the women of Philistia]

David is using the adjective **uncircumcised** as a noun to mean people who have not been circumcised. Israelites used this as a term of derision to describe the Philistines as people did not worship Yahweh and did no obey his laws, such as the one requiring the circumcision of men. Your language may have a comparable term of derision that you can use in your translation. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated this term in [1 Samuel 14:6](../../1sa/14/06.md). Alternate translation: [the women among those heathen]

text: O mountains of Gilboa, may you have no dew or rain, no fields yielding offerings of grain. For there the shield of the mighty was defiled, the shield of Saul, no longer anointed with oil.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since the shield of the mighty was loathed there, the shield of Saul, not anointed with oil, may dew and rain not be upon you, nor fields of offerings, mountains in Gilboa]

David is speaking to the mountains of Gilboa as if they could hear him. He is doing this to show in a strong way how he feels about the deaths of Saul and Jonathan on those mountains. He is actually speaking to the people who can hear him, the people of Judah who will eventually learn this song. If this would not be clear to your readers, you could translate his words as if he were speaking directly to people who could hear him. Alternate translation: [May there be no dew or rain, nor fields of offerings, upon the mountains in Gilboa]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and may fields of offerings not be upon you]

David is using this possessive form to mean fields that produce only enough crops for people to use as offerings. Offerings were typically only a small percentage of an overall crop. So David is wishing for so little rain and dew that the fields will not produce even a fraction of their usual amount. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [nor fields producing even enough crops for small offerings]
See the Introduction to this chapter for a discussion of how this may have represented a symbolic action and for a suggestion of how you might translate it.

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [people treated the shield of the mighty disrespectfully]

David is using the adjective **mighty** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [a mighty warrior]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [no one anoints the shield of Saul with oil anymore]

text: From the blood of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan did not retreat, and the sword of Saul did not return empty.

translation_challanges.note: David is speaking of **the bow of Jonathan** as if it had been a person who could have been sent to fulfill a task but who might have decided to **turn itself back** and not complete it. David is speaking similarly of **the sword of Saul** as if it had been a person who could have been sent to get something but who might have returned with **empty** hands, that is, without it. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When Jonathan shot arrows at enemy soldiers, the arrows pierced them so that they bled and died. When Saul stabbed enemy soldiers, his sword cut them so deeply that their fat came out and they died]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. He is using a common image of his culture, but in an abbreviated form. The image appears in its full form in [Deuteronomy 32:42](../../deu/32/42.md), “I will make my arrows drunk with blood, and my sword will devour flesh.” You can supply the omitted words from the cultural context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [From drinking the blood of the slain, from devouring the fat of the mighty]

David is speaking as if the bow and sword were living things that could drink blood and consume fat. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [From slaying soldiers by piercing them so that they bled, from stabbing the mighty so deeply that their fat came out]

David is using the adjectives **slain** and **mighty** as nouns to mean certain kinds of people. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases. Alternate translation: [slain soldiers … mighty warriors]

David is using the term **bow** by association to mean the arrows that Jonathan shot from his bow. You may choose to use the arrows to represent this image in your translation. Alternate translation: [the arrows of Jonathan did not turn themselves back]

text: Saul and Jonathan, beloved and delightful in life, were not divided in death. They were swifter than eagles; they were stronger than lions.

translation_challanges.note: If your language would not use the passive forms **were being loved** and **were not separated**, you could express these ideas in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [While Saul and Jonathan were alive, people loved them and delighted in them, and when they died, they were together]

David is making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [They were swift like eagles; they were mighty like lions]

text: O daughters of Israel, weep for Saul, who clothed you in scarlet and luxury, who decked your garments with ornaments of gold.

translation_challanges.note: David is speaking to the women of Israel as if they could hear him. He is doing this to show in a strong way how he feels about Saul’s death. He is actually speaking to the people who can hear him, the people of Judah who will eventually learn this song. If this would not be clear to your readers, you could translate this as if he were speaking directly to those who could hear him. Alternate translation: [The daughters of Israel should weep for Saul, the one having clothed them in scarlet with delights, the one having put an ornament of gold on their clothing]
See how you translated this expression in [1:20](../01/20.md). Alternate translation: [Women of Israel]

Saul had not directly **clothed** the Israelite women in scarlet, and he had not directly **put** gold ornaments on their clothing. David is illustrating the prosperity that Saul brought to Israel by ensuring its security and by plundering its enemies. The UST models one way to express this meaning.

David is using the term **scarlet** by association to mean clothing that was scarlet in color. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in scarlet-colored clothing]

This expression conveys a single idea by using two phrases connected with **with**. The phrase **in delights** tells in what way Saul clothed the women **in scarlet**. Specifically, the clothing brought delight to the ones who wore it. Alternate translation: [delightfully in scarlet]

The term **scarlet** refers to a bright red color. In this culture, people had to use an expensive dye to make clothes this color. So having scarlet clothing represented prosperity and status. If your readers would not be familiar with what scarlet is, in your translation you could use a general expression. Alternate translation: [in expensive clothing]

text: How the mighty have fallen in the thick of battle! Jonathan lies slain on your heights.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated this expression in [1:19](../01/19.md). Alternate translation: [I am so sad that these mighty warriors have died]

As in [1:19](../01/19.md), the word **your** refers to the nation of Israel as if it were a single person. See how you translated this expression there. Alternate translation: [on one of the high places of Israel]

text: I grieve for you, Jonathan, my brother. You were delightful to me; your love to me was extraordinary, surpassing the love of women.

translation_challanges.note: David is speaking as if he were in a **narrow** (tightly confined) space in which he did not have much freedom of movement. In such a situation, a person would feel distress, and that feeling is what David is expressing through this image. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I am very distressed about you]

David is speaking as if Jonathan were his actual brother, even though he was not. David is using this expression to emphasize that Jonathan was as dear to him as a brother would have been. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [my dear friend Jonathan]
David is saying that his bond of friendship with Jonathan meant more to him than any romantic relationship with a woman. See the discussion of this statement in the Introduction to this chapter.

text: How the mighty have fallen, and the weapons of war have perished!”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated this expression in [1:19](../01/19.md). Alternate translation: [I am so sad that these mighty warriors have died]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and how the weapons of war have perished]

David is using these **weapons** by association to mean Saul and Jonathan who used them so skillfully, as he describes in [1:22](../01/22.md). If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and how these men who used weapons of war so skillfully have perished]

David is using a phrase that expresses a strong feeling, great sorrow that Saul and Jonathan, who used weapons skillfully, have died. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this feeling. If not, you could indicate specifically what David was feeling. Alternate translation: [yes, I am so sad that these men who used weapons of war so skillfully have perished]

text: Some time later, David inquired of the LORD, “Should I go up to one of the towns of Judah?” “Go up,” the LORD answered. Then David asked, “Where should I go?” “To Hebron,” replied the LORD.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using this expression to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method here that is natural in your language for introducing a new event.

See the discussion in the Introduction to 2 Samuel of how Hebrew speakers and writers marked descriptions of travel for change in elevation. David says **go up** because he is in Ziklag, near the seacoast, so he would be going up in elevation if he went to a city in the territory of Judah, which was hilly. Alternate translation: [Shall I go]
See the discussion in the Introduction to 2 Samuel of how the ULT represents the Hebrew verb form for instruction or obligation. Alternate translation: [Should I go]

Yahweh is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Go to Hebron]

text: So David went there with his two wives, Ahinoam of Jezreel and Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel.

translation_challanges.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and the two of his wives also went up there]
Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship, since Nabal was now dead and Abigail was no longer his legal **wife**. Alternate translation: [the widow of Nabal]

text: David also took the men who were with him, each with his household, and they settled in the towns near Hebron.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **house** by association to mean the people who lived in the same house with a man. He means the people in that man’s household. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [each man with his family]

The author is using the plural form **cities** in a context where the singular term “city” would suffice, since Hebron was a single city. This suggests that he is using the plural form to refer to Hebron and its surrounding villages. Your language may use plural forms in the same way. If not, you could express the meaning in another way. Alternate translation: [in and around the city of Hebron]

text: Then the men of Judah came to Hebron, and there they anointed David king over the house of Judah. And they told David, “It was the men of Jabesh-gilead who buried Saul.”

translation_challanges.note: Here, **house** represents all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of Judah** figuratively means all the people descended from Judah, one of the sons of Jacob or Israel. Alternate translation: [the people of the tribe of Judah]
The author is not using the pronoun **they** to refer to specific people. Use a comparable expression that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And David was told]

text: So David sent messengers to the men of Jabesh-gilead to tell them, “The LORD bless you, because you showed this kindness to Saul your lord when you buried him.

translation_challanges.note: Here the masculine term **men** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [the people of Jabesh Gilead]

The author is using the term **he said** by association to mean that David said this through the messengers he sent. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and they said to them on his behalf]
If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [May Yahweh bless you]

The words **you** and **your** are plural here because David is addressing all the people of Jabesh Gilead. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction, here and through [verse 7](../02/07.md).

This expression conveys a single idea by using two phrases connected with **and**. The phrase **have buried him** tells in what way the people **have done this kindness** with Saul. Alternate translation: [you have done this kindness with your master, with Saul, by burying him]

text: Now may the LORD show you loving devotion and faithfulness, and I will also show you the same favor because you have done this.

translation_challanges.note: **And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. The UST models one way to do that.

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **kindness** and **faithfulness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [may Yahweh treat you kindly and be faithful to you]

David is using the adjective **good** as a noun to mean a certain kind of action. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [And I myself will also do good things for you]

text: Now then, be strong and courageous, for though Saul your lord is dead, the house of Judah has anointed me as their king.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since your master Saul has died, and also the house of Judah has anointed me as king over them, may your hands be strong, and be sons of valor]

David is using one part of the people of Jabesh Gilead, their **hands**, to mean all of them in the act of being courageous. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [be courageous]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **sons of** to describe people who have a certain quality. In this case, **sons of valor** describes warriors who have the quality of valor, which is courage in dangerous situations. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated this expression in [1 Samuel 18:17](../../1sa/18/17.md). Alternate translation: [valiant warriors]
See how you translated this expression in [2:4](../02/04.md). Alternate translation: [the people of the tribe of Judah]

text: Meanwhile, Abner son of Ner, the commander of Saul’s army, took Saul’s son Ish-bosheth, moved him to Mahanaim,

translation_challanges.note: The author is reintroducing Abner as a participant in the story. He was first introduced in [1 Samuel 14:50](../../1sa/14/50.md) Your language may have its own way of reintroducing participants that you can use in your translation.

text: and made him king over Gilead, Asher, Jezreel, Ephraim, and Benjamin—over all Israel.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Abner, while the pronoun **him** refers to Ishbosheth. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Abner made Ishbosheth rule]

The author is not referring to a specific Ashurite. He means the Ashurites in general. It may be more natural in your language to express this meaning by using a plural form. Alternate translation: [and over the Ashurites]

The author is making a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [all of it except the tribe of Judah]

text: Saul’s son Ish-bosheth was forty years old when he began to reign over Israel, and he reigned for two years. The house of Judah, however, followed David.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using this statement formally to introduce Ishbosheth as a participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing participants that you can use in your translation. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter about the form of this statement, which marks the reigns of kings throughout the books of 1 and 2 Samuel and 1 and 2 Kings.

In this culture, to say how old a man was, speakers would say that he was **a son of** a certain number of **years**. In your translation, express this in the way your language and culture say how old someone is. Alternate translation: [was 40 years of age]
See how you translated this expression in [2:4](../02/04.md). Alternate translation: [the people of the tribe of Judah]

The author is speaking as if the people of Judah had positioned themselves physically **behind** David. He means that they were loyal to him as their king. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [were loyal to David as their king]

text: And the length of time that David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **the number of the days** by association to mean the length of time, since time is made up of days. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the length of time]

text: One day Abner son of Ner and the servants of Ish-bosheth son of Saul marched out from Mahanaim to Gibeon.

translation_challanges.note: The author is introducing a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method here that is natural in your language for introducing a new event.

text: So Joab son of Zeruiah and the servants of David marched out and met them by the pool of Gibeon. And the two groups took up positions on opposite sides of the pool.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing Joab as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation.
The word **Zeruiah** is the name of a woman, David’s older sister.

The author is using a common expression of his culture to mean that the two groups were on opposite sides of the pool from each other. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [on opposite sides of the pool]

text: Then Abner said to Joab, “Let us have the young men get up and compete before us.” “Let them get up,” Joab replied.

translation_challanges.note: While these young men would have to **arise** from their seated position, Abner could be using the term here to suggest that they take action. That is one frequent meaning of the term. Alternate translation: [May the young men now take action]
See the discussion of the possible meanings here of the term **play** in the Introduction to this chapter. Alternate translation: [and engage in single combat] or [and start the fighting]
See the discussion of the term **face** in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [in front of us]

text: So they got up and were counted off—twelve for Benjamin and Ish-bosheth son of Saul, and twelve for David.

translation_challanges.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and they fought against 12 from the servants of David]

text: Then each man grabbed his opponent by the head and thrust his sword into his opponent’s side, and they all fell together. So this place, which is in Gibeon, is called Helkath-hazzurim.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **head** by association to mean the hair on the head. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [by the hair]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and thrust his sword in the side of his fellow]

The author is using the term **fell** by association to mean that they died, since they fell down when they died. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and they died]
The author is not using the pronoun **one** to refer to a specific person. Use a comparable expression that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [So that place was called]

As the author indicates, **Helkath Hazzurim** is the name of a place. In your translation, you could spell it the way it sounds in your language. Alternatively, you could use a word or phrase from your language that expresses the meaning of this name. However, the exact meaning is uncertain. One possible meaning is “The Field of the Sides,” which would be an allusion to the way each soldier stabbed his opponent in the side. Another possible meaning is “The Field of the Swords” or “The Field of the Daggers,” which would be an allusion to the weapons that the soldiers used. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region and it suggests one of these meanings, you may wish to suggest the same meaning in your translation.

text: The battle that day was intense, and Abner and the men of Israel were defeated by the servants of David.

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the servants of David struck Abner and the men of Israel to their faces]

The author is using the term **face** by association to mean that Abner and the men of Israel were in front of the servants of David. The expression indicates agency. It means that David’s soldiers struck Abner and his soldiers as they engaged them in battle. See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [were struck by the servants of David] or [were struck as they opposed the servants of David]

By **were struck**, the author means that Abner and the men of Israel “were defeated” in battle. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [were defeated to the face of the servants of David] or [were defeated by the servants of David]

text: The three sons of Zeruiah were there: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Now Asahel was fleet of foot like a wild gazelle,

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing Asahel as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation.

The author is using a common expression of his culture, **light on his feet**, to mean that Asahel was very fast when he ran. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language, as the UST does. Alternate translation: [And Asahel was swift of foot]

The word **gazelles** describes small, fast-running, deer-like animals. If your readers would not be familiar with what a gazelle is, in your translation you could use the name of a similar animal that your readers would recognize, or you could use a general expression. Alternate translation: [the fast deer] or [the swift-running wild animals]

text: and he chased Abner, not turning to the right or to the left in his pursuit.

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking of two extremes, right and left, in order to mean them and everything in between. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in any direction except after Abner]

text: And Abner glanced back and said, “Is that you, Asahel?” “It is,” Asahel replied.
So Abner told him, “Turn to your right or to your left, seize one of the young men, and take his equipment for yourself.” But Asahel would not stop chasing him.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:19](../02/19.md). Alternate translation: [in some other direction] or [in pursuit of someone else]

text: Once again, Abner warned Asahel, “Stop chasing me. Why should I strike you to the ground? How could I show my face to your brother Joab?”

translation_challanges.note: Abner is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Do not make me strike you to the ground! Then I would not be able to lift my face to Joab, your brother.]

By **strike you to the ground**, Abner means kill Asahel, causing him to fall to the ground dead. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Why should I kill you, so that you fall to the ground dead]

Abner failing to **lift** his **face** to look at Joab directly would be a symbolic action that would express shame for killing Asahel, a younger, less experienced warrior. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [Then I would be too ashamed to look your brother Joab in the face]

text: But Asahel refused to turn away. So Abner thrust the butt of his spear into his stomach, and it came out his back, and he fell dead on the spot. And every man paused when he came to the place where Asahel had fallen and died.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Asahel died right in the place where Abner killed him, that is, on the ground that was **under him** at that time. The author is not saying that Abner stood over Asahel as he was dying. Be sure that this is clear for your readers. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [on the spot]

The author is making a generalization for emphasis, since the next verse shows that **every** did not include Joab and Abishai. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [whenever soldiers came]
It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [where Asahel fell]
See the discussion in the Introduction to the chapter of why the soldiers who came to this place may have **stood** still there.

text: But Joab and Abishai pursued Abner. By sunset, they had gone as far as the hill of Ammah opposite Giah on the way to the wilderness of Gibeon.

translation_challanges.note: The words that the ULT translates as **and … and** indicate that Joab and Abishai **came to the hill of Ammah** at the same time as when **the sun was coming in**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe the time relationship more explicitly. Alternate translation: [while the sun was going down, they came to the hill of Ammah]

The author is using a common expression of his culture to mean that the sun was setting. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the sun was setting]

The author is using the term **face** by association to mean that the hill of Ammah was opposite or facing the place called Giah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [which is opposite Giah]

The author is using this possessive form to mean the road that lead to the wilderness of Gibeon. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [on the road that leads to the wilderness of Gibeon]

text: The Benjamites rallied to Abner, formed a single unit, and took their stand atop a hill.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:18](../01/18.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers from the tribe of Benjamin]

The author is speaking as if these soldiers had positioned themselves physically **behind** Abner. He means that they were following Abner as their leader. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with Abner leading them] or [under the command of Abner]

The author is speaking of this **hill** as if it were a living thing that could have had a **head**. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language, as the UST does. Alternate translation: [on the crown of a hill]

text: Then Abner called out to Joab: “Must the sword devour forever? Do you not realize that this will only end in bitterness? How long before you tell the troops to stop pursuing their brothers?”

translation_challanges.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly.

Abner is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [The sword should not devour forever! You must know that it will be bitter at the last! You should say to the people right away to turn from after their brothers!]

Abner is speaking of a **sword** as if it were a living thing that could **devour** something. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Are we going to keep killing each other?] or [We should not keep killing each other!]

Abner is using the adjective **last** as a noun to mean a certain time. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [in the end]
See how you translated the term **people** in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [to your soldiers]

Abner is speaking as if his soldiers were the actual **brothers** of Joab’s soldiers. He means they were fellow Israelites. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [their fellow Israelites]

text: “As surely as God lives,” Joab replied, “if you had not spoken up, the troops would have continued pursuing their brothers until morning.”

translation_challanges.note: Following the custom of his culture, Joab is swearing an oath by guaranteeing it by something he holds sacred, **The life of God**. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath.

Joab is not actually saying that a second event is not going to take place because a first event has not taken place. He does not mean, “If you had not spoken, the people would have taken itself up, but since you have spoken, they are not going to do that.” Instead, he means that this second event would have taken place whether or not the first event had taken place. He is assuring Abner that he too recognizes how destructive war is, and so he would have called off the attack very soon. Be sure that this is clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [even if you had not spoken, by morning the people would still have taken itself up]

Joab is using a common expression of his culture to mean that his soldiers would have stopped pursuing Abner’s men. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [would have given up its pursuit]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:26](../02/26.md). Alternate translation: [his fellow Israelite]

text: So Joab blew the ram’s horn, and all the troops stopped; they no longer pursued Israel or continued to fight.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the name of a nation by association to represent its army. See the discussion of this in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [the Israelite soldiers]

text: And all that night Abner and his men marched through the Arabah. They crossed the Jordan, marched all morning, and arrived at Mahanaim.
When Joab returned from pursuing Abner, he gathered all the troops. In addition to Asahel, nineteen of David’s servants were missing,
but they had struck down 360 Benjamites who were with Abner.

translation_challanges.note: The author seems to add they had died in order to clarify that here the term struck means “killed.” If this seems like extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [had killed 360 men from Benjamin and among the men of Abner]

The author is using the name of a person by association to represent his descendants, the tribe of Benjamin. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [among the Benjaminites]

text: And they took Asahel and buried him in his father’s tomb in Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men marched all night and reached Hebron at daybreak.

translation_challanges.note: The author is not using the pronoun **they** to refer to specific people. Use a comparable expression that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And Asahel was carried off the battlefield and buried in the tomb of his father]

Ordinarily, soldiers were buried on the battlefield where they had died, so carrying Asahel’s body more than fifteen kilometers (more than ten miles) to his family tomb in Bethlehem was a symbolic action that showed special honor to him as a great warrior and as the brother of the commanding general, Joab. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [And they respectfully took up Asahel, and they buried him with great honor in the tomb of his father]

The author is using the term **it became light** by association to mean that the sky had begun to become light when they reached Hebron. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and they reached Hebron in the early morning]

text: Now the war between the house of Saul and the house of David was protracted. And David grew stronger and stronger, while the house of Saul grew weaker and weaker.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using this clause to describe something that was ongoing. This provides the background for other events he will describe that began to happen during this time. Connect this clause to the story in a way that makes it clear in your language that this clause is describing something that was ongoing in the background. Alternate translation: [For a long time after that there was war between the house of Saul and between the house of David.]

In this context, the term **house** refers to the family line of a king, which might include several descendants who were his successors as king. Your language may use this term in the same way, or it may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language, as the UST does. Alternate translation: [the royal house of Saul … the royal house of David] or [the dynasty of Saul … the dynasty of David]

The phrases **going and strong** and **going and weak** express single ideas. The word **going** indicates that the strength and weakness grew greater over time. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express these meanings in a different way. Alternate translation: [And David kept getting stronger, but the house of Saul kept getting weaker]

The author is using **David** to represent David and all those who supported him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David and his supporters kept getting stronger]

text: And sons were born to David in Hebron: His firstborn was Amnon, by Ahinoam of Jezreel;

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens later in the story. Three of these sons, **Amnon**, Absalom, and Adonijah, will figure prominently in the narrative. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Now David’s wives bore him sons]
Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Alternate translation: [And his eldest]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [who was born to Ahinoam the Jezreelitess] or [whose mother was Ahinoam the Jezreelitess]

text: his second was Chileab, by Abigail the widow of Nabal of Carmel; his third was Absalom, the son of Maacah daughter of King Talmai of Geshur;

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the adjectives **second** and **third** as nouns to mean certain people. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases, here and in [verses 4](../03/04.md) and [5](../03/05.md). Alternate translation: [And his second son … And his third son]

Your language may have its own way of showing that someone or something is first, second, third, or fourth in a series. If so, you can use it here and in [verses 4](../03/04.md) and [5](../03/05.md). Alternate translation: [And son number two … And son number three] or [And his next son … And his next son]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:2](../02/02.md). Alternate translation: [the widow of]

text: his fourth was Adonijah, the son of Haggith; his fifth was Shephatiah, the son of Abital;
and his sixth was Ithream, by David’s wife Eglah. These sons were born to David in Hebron.

translation_challanges.note: The author expects his readers to understand that this phrase applies to all of the women he lists here, not just to **Eglah**. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. (The author explains in [5:13](../05/13.md) that David had concubines in addition to wives. These sons of his wives had rights of inheritance, and so they competed to succeed David as king, as much of the later story relates.) Alternate translation: [All of these women were David’s wives]

The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [David’s wives bore them to him] or [They bore them to him]

Since this statement duplicates information that is already in [verse 2](../03/02.md), it might seem like extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you might leave it out. However, see the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how this statement provides a summary conclusion to the list and of how you might present the whole list in a way that is natural in your language and culture.

text: During the war between the house of Saul and the house of David, Abner had continued to strengthen his position in the house of Saul.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event. Alternate translation: [During this time] or [Meanwhile]
See how you translated these expressions in [3:1](../03/01.md).

text: Now Saul had a concubine named Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah. So Ish-bosheth questioned Abner, “Why did you sleep with my father’s concubine?”

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing Rizpah as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Saul had a concubine named Rizpah who was the daughter of Aiah]
The pronoun **he** refers to Ishbosheth. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Then Ishbosheth said to Abner]

Ishbosheth is using the question form to rebuke Abner. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not have gone in to the concubine of my father!]

Ishbosheth is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **gone in to**. Depending on what is appropriate in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [slept with]

text: Abner was furious over Ish-bosheth’s accusation. “Am I the head of a dog that belongs to Judah?” he asked. “All this time I have been loyal to the house of your father Saul, to his brothers, and to his friends. I have not delivered you into the hand of David, but now you accuse me of wrongdoing with this woman!

translation_challanges.note: The author is describing Abner becoming extremely angry by association with the way a person’s skin may become hot when he is angry. Your culture may also associate anger with heat, and if so, you could use its characteristic expression in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [And Abner became steaming mad] or [And Abner became extremely angry]

The author is using the term **words** to represent what Ishbosheth said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what Ishbosheth had said to him]

Abner is using one part of a dog, his **head**, to mean an entire dog. He may be doing this to make his statement more elaborate and emphatic. Your language may have its own way of doing this. Alternate translation: [Am I some kind of dog that is to Judah]

Abner is using the question form to express anger and deny that he is worthless. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for those purposes, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I am not the head of a dog that is to Judah!] or [I am not some kind of dog that is to Judah!]

In this culture, people considered wild dogs dirty and regarded them with contempt. Abner is suggesting that the Judeans are contemptible for not supporting Saul’s son as their next king. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [I am not some contemptible Judean!]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **kindness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [I am treating your father Saul’s descendants, brothers, and friends kindly] or [I am remaining loyal to the house of Saul your father, to his brothers, and to his friends]

Here, **hand** represents the capability of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I have not delivered you into David’s power] or [and I have not allowed David to overpower you]

Abner is using this possessive form to mean iniquity committed against a woman. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [you charge me with committing iniquity against a woman]
See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how, if Abner had actually had sexual relations with Rizpah, that would have been a symbolic action asserting a claim to be the king.

text: May God punish Abner, and ever so severely, if I do not do for David what the LORD has sworn to him:

translation_challanges.note: Abner swears in this verse that he is going to do something, but he does not describe until the next verse what he is going to do. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could create a verse bridge for [verses 9–10](../03/09.md) and have Abner first describe what he is going to do and then swear that he will do it. (That would not change the meaning, only the order of the information.) The UST models one way to do that.

Following the custom of his culture, Abner is using a conditional statement to swear an oath. What he states as a condition (“if”) is what he is swearing to do. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could put the condition before the consequence. Alternate translation: [I swear that I will do for David according to what Yahweh has sworn to him, and if I do not, then may God do thus to Abner, and thus may he add to him]

Because he is swearing an oath, Abner is speaking about himself solemnly in the third person. If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to me, Abner, and thus may he add to me]

When Abner says **thus may he add**, he is using a common expression of his culture. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to Abner, and may he do even worse]

The word **Thus**: (1) could refer to what Abner describes in the next verse. Abner could be saying that if he does not take away the privileged position of Saul’s family, then he wants God to take away his privileged position as a powerful leader. The UST models one way to express that meaning. (2) could be a general expression introducing the entire statement as a reference to severe punishment. Alternate translation: [May God punish me, Abner, very severely]

text: to transfer the kingdom from the house of Saul and to establish the throne of David over Israel and Judah, from Dan to Beersheba.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [to cause the kingdom to pass over from the descendants of Saul]

Abner is using the term **kingdom** to mean a king’s rule over the Israelites, not the Israelites themselves over whom he would rule. Alternate translation: [to cause the kingship to pass over from the descendants of Saul]

Here, Abner is speaking as if the **kingdom** might physically **pass over** from one location to another. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to cause the descendants of Saul no longer to rule as kings]

Abner is speaking as if he would physically **raise up** the **throne** of David to a high position above Israel and Judah. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express his meaning using an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and to establish the rule of David]

Abner is referring to all of the Israelite territory by naming two extremes, **Dan** (a city in the far north) and **Beersheba** (a city in the far south). If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [over the entire territory of Israel and Judah]

text: And for fear of Abner, Ish-bosheth did not dare to say another word to him.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Ishbosheth. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Ishbosheth was not able]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Ishbosheth might have said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to say anything further]

text: Then Abner sent messengers on his behalf to say to David, “To whom does the land belong? Make your covenant with me, and surely my hand will be with you to bring all Israel over to you.”

translation_challanges.note: The term **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly. Alternate translation: [saying, “To whom {is} the land? Cut your covenant with me]

Abner is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Abner could mean: (1) that he, not Ishbosheth, actually controls the **land**, so if David makes a covenant **with** him, he can deliver **all of Israel** to David. Alternate translation: [The land is under my control!]; (2) that since Yahweh promised David the kingship, Abner will help him become the king of all of Israel on that basis. Alternate translation: [You are the rightful king of the land!]

Abner is using **Cut your covenant** as a common expression of his culture to mean “make your covenant.” If this phrase would not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Make a covenant with me]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md).

Abner is using his **hand** to represent himself in the act of accompanying and assisting David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will be with you]

In telling David he will be **with** him, Abner is using a common expression of his culture to mean that he will help him. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will support you]

Here, Abner is speaking as if he would physically make the Israelites **turn** in a different direction. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to make all the Israelites accept you as their king]

text: “Good,” replied David, “I will make a covenant with you. But there is one thing I require of you: Do not appear before me unless you bring Saul’s daughter Michal when you come to see me.”

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Then David said]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will cut** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that he is making a commitment to Abner. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [I agree to cut a covenant with you]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Only one thing I am asking from you. You will not see my face unless you bring Michal, the daughter of Saul, to my face when you come to see my face.]

If it would appear in your language that David was making a statement and then contradicting it, you could reword this as a positive statement. Alternate translation: [You will only see my face if you bring Michal]

Here, **face** represents personal presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [You will not come into my presence … when you come into my presence]

David is using **face** to represent his whole person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [back to me]

text: Then David sent messengers to say to Ish-bosheth son of Saul, “Give me back my wife, Michal, whom I betrothed to myself for a hundred Philistine foreskins.”
So Ish-bosheth sent and took Michal from her husband Paltiel son of Laish.

translation_challanges.note: Since David refers to Michal as “my wife” in the previous verse, it may not be appropriate in your language and culture to describe Paltiel as **{her} husband** here. If that is the case, you can use a different expression. Alternate translation: [the man to whom her father Saul had given her]

Here the author is introducing Paltiel as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a man named Paltiel who was the son of Laish]
