See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of why this man is called **Paltiel** here but Palti when he first appears in the story in [1 Samuel 25:44](../../1sa/25/44.md). We recommend that you use these two different versions of his name in these places in your translation.

text: Her husband followed her, weeping all the way to Bahurim. Then Abner said to him, “Go back.” So he returned home.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:15](../03/15.md).

The phrase **going and weeping** expresses a single idea. The word **weeping** tells in what way Paltiel was **going**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [going tearfully]

Abner could be using the term **Go** to tell Paltiel: (1) that he must now **return**. **Bahurim** was near the border of Judah, and Abner did not want Paltiel to enter the territory that David was ruling. Alternate translation: [It is time for you to return]; (2) that Paltiel must leave that place, where Michal was, and return to his home without her. Alternate translation: [Leave here and return home]

text: Now Abner conferred with the elders of Israel and said, “In the past you sought David as your king.

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. Alternate translation: [Meanwhile, Abner had been speaking with the elders of Israel]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Abner said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Now Abner had sent a message to the elders of Israel]

Abner is using **Both yesterday and the third day** as a common expression of his culture to mean the way things had been previously. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [In the past]

text: Now take action, because the LORD has said to David, ‘Through My servant David I will save My people Israel from the hands of the Philistines and of all their enemies.’”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since Yahweh spoke about David, saying, ‘By the hand of David my servant, I will save my people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all of their enemies,’ do it]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that by the hand of David his servant he would save his people Israel from the hand of the Philistines and from the hand of all of their enemies]

Here, **hand** represents the actions of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Through the actions of David my servant]

Here, **hand** represents the power or control of a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the power of the Philistines and from the power of all of their enemies] or [from the control of the Philistines and from the control of all of their enemies]

text: Abner also spoke to the Benjamites. Then he went to Hebron to tell David all that seemed good to Israel and to the whole house of Benjamin.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **ears** to mean hearing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in the hearing of Benjamin … in the hearing of David] or [to Benjamin in person … to David in person]

See the discussion of the phrase **good in the eyes of** in the Introduction to this chapter. Alternate translation: [everything that Israel and the house of Benjamin had decided was the right thing to do]
Here, **Israel** represents the people of Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelites]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [the whole tribe of Benjamin]

text: When Abner and twenty of his men came to David at Hebron, David held a feast for them.

translation_challanges.note: Bringing a round and significant number of men with him was a symbolic action by which Abner showed respect for David. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he brought 20 men with him to show respect for David]

text: Then Abner said to David, “Let me go at once, and I will gather all Israel to my lord the king, that they may make a covenant with you, and that you may rule over all that your heart desires.” So David dismissed Abner, and he went in peace.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [Let me take action]

Even though Abner is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [to you, my lord the king]

Abner says **all of Israel** as an generalization for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [leaders from throughout Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [so they may make a covenant with you]

Abner is using David’s **soul** to represent all of him as a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you desire]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [peacefully]

text: Just then David’s soldiers and Joab returned from a raid, bringing with them a great plunder. But Abner was not with David in Hebron, because David had sent him on his way in peace.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using this possessive form to mean not people who served both David and Joab but people who served David, including Joab. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Joab and other servants of David]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since David had sent Abner away and he had gone in peace, he was not with David in Hebron]

text: When Joab and all his troops arrived, he was informed, “Abner son of Ner came to see the king, who sent him on his way in peace.”

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and Joab was told]

text: So Joab went to the king and said, “What have you done? Look, Abner came to you. Why did you dismiss him? Now he is getting away!

translation_challanges.note: Joab is using the question form to challenge David for letting Abner go. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You have done something that you should not have done!]

Joab is using the question form to express his strong disapproval of David letting Abner go. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [There was no good reason to send him away, so that going, he has gone!]

Joab is repeating forms of the verb “go” in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [and he has completely gone]

text: Surely you realize that Abner son of Ner came to deceive you and to track your movements and all that you are doing.”

translation_challanges.note: Joab is speaking of the first and last actions of a military campaign, **going out** and **coming in**, in order to mean military activities as a whole. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the same expression in [1 Samuel 29:6](../../1sa/29/06.md). Alternate translation: [and to find out about how you conduct your military campaigns]

Joab speaks in the present tense to David of things **you are doing** in order to describe actions that David has not yet done but that Joab believes he is planning to do. Use the verb form in your language that is natural for referring to planned future actions. Alternate translation: [and to find out everything that you are planning to do]

text: As soon as Joab had left David, he sent messengers after Abner, who brought him back from the well of Sirah. But David was unaware of it.

When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab pulled him aside into the gateway, as if to speak to him privately, and there Joab stabbed him in the stomach. So Abner died on account of the blood of Joab’s brother Asahel.

translation_challanges.note: The author assumes that his readers will know that by **the middle of the gate**, he is referring to an area within the city wall between the openings that led out of the city and into the city. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. The UST models one way to do that.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **quiet**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [quietly]

If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about why Joab killed Abner before the information about how he did it. Alternate translation: [And for the blood of Asahel his brother, he struck him there in the stomach, and he died]

The pronoun **he** refers to Joab, while the pronoun **him** refers to Abner. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And for the blood of Asahel his brother, Joab struck Abner there in the stomach, and Abner died]

Here, **blood** represents the killing of Asahel for which Joab wanted to take revenge. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to avenge the death of Asahel his brother]

text: Afterward, David heard about this and said, “I and my kingdom are forever guiltless before the LORD concerning the blood of Abner son of Ner.

translation_challanges.note: The implication is that David is referring not just to his current reign but to the continuing rule of his descendants. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and my royal dynasty]

Here, **blood** represents the killing of Abner. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [regarding the death of Abner]

The word **blood** is plural here because it refers to blood shed by violence. Your language may use the plural form of its word for blood to mean the same thing. If not, you could express the meaning in another way. Alternate translation: [of the bloodshed against Abner]

text: May it whirl over the head of Joab and over the entire house of his father, and may the house of Joab never be without one having a discharge or skin disease, or one who leans on a staff or falls by the sword or lacks food.”

translation_challanges.note: The word **it** refers back to “the blood of Abner” in the previous verse. If you translated “blood” with a plural form there, it may be natural for you to use a plural pronoun here. You could also state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [May Abner’s blood writhe on the head of Joab and to all of the house of his father]

David is using the same common expression here that he used in [1:16](../01/16.md), about blood being on someone’s **head**, to mean that a person was morally and legally responsible for something and would be punished for it. Here he uses a more vivid form of the expression and wishes that the blood of Abner would **writhe** on Joab’s head. This represents the sufferings of Joab and his extended family that David describes in the rest of the verse. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [May Joab and all of the house of his father painfully bear the responsibility for it]

The expression **the house of his father** refers to Joab’s extended family and descendants. Your language may have its own term or expression for such a group of related people. Alternate translation: [his extended family]

The expression **be cut off** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and may not be missing from the house of Joab] or [may there always be in the house of Joab]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [among the descendants of Joab]

The expression **stricken with leprosy** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [or a leper]

This expression could describe: (1) a person who, because of injury or illness, needs to use a staff to support himself when standing or walking. Alternate translation: [or a lame person]; (2) a man who, because of injury or weakness, cannot do strenuous work or fight in battles and so must do domestic work such as using a distaff (spindle) to wind wool into thread. Alternate translation: [or a weak man]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [or one dying in battle]

David is using the adjective **destitute** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [or someone who lacks bread]

David is using **bread** to represent all food or basic necessities. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [or someone who lacks food] or [someone who is desperately poor]

text: (Joab and his brother Abishai murdered Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.)

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand why David so greatly disapproved of what Joab had done. The author is contrasting the way Abner **killed** Asahel in battle (as he described in [2:23](../02/23.md)) with the way Joab and Abishai **murdered** Abner treacherously under peaceful conditions. If your language has different words for killing and murdering, it would be appropriate to use them here in your translation to show this contrast.

text: Then David ordered Joab and all the people with him, “Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn before Abner.” And King David himself walked behind the funeral bier.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers]

Tearing one’s **clothes** and wearing **sackcloth** were symbolic actions that showed intense grief and mourning in ancient Israelite culture. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [show your grief by tearing your clothes and wearing rough cloth]

Here David speaks of **Abner** to mean Abner’s body. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and walk in procession as mourners ahead of Abner’s body]

Here, **walking behind the bier** was a symbolic action by which David showed public respect for Abner and demonstrated that he had not been responsible for Abner’s death. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [King David himself followed the funeral procession to show his respect]

A **bier** is a kind of platform or frame used to carry a dead body to burial. If your readers would not be familiar with what a bier is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [the stretcher carrying Abner’s body]

text: When they buried Abner in Hebron, the king wept aloud at Abner’s tomb, and all the people wept.

translation_challanges.note: Here, the author is speaking as if **voice** were an object that could be lifted up. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And the king raised the volume of his voice and wept]

The phrase **lifted up his voice and wept** expresses a single idea. The words **lifted up his voice** describe in what way David **wept**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And the king wept loudly]

text: And the king sang this lament for Abner: “Should Abner die the death of a fool?

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form to emphasize how wrong it was for Abner to have died the way he did. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Abner should not have died like the death of a fool!]

The implication is that Abner died in an unjust and dishonorable way, as if he were a criminal deserving death, when in fact he was not. You could indicate this if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Abner should not have been executed as if he had been a wicked person!]

text: Your hands were not bound, your feet were not fettered. As a man falls before the wicked, so also you fell.” And all the people wept over him even more.

translation_challanges.note: David is speaking to Abner, who is dead and cannot hear him. He is doing this to communicate to the people listening to him that he feels very strongly about how Abner was treacherously murdered. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate these words as if he were speaking directly to the people about Abner. Alternate translation: [His hands were not bound, and his feet were not put in shackles. He died like someone murdered by wicked men]

Here, bound **hands** and shackled **feet** represent being held as a prisoner. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [You were not being held as a prisoner because you had been convicted of a crime]
See how you translated the expression similar to **falling** and **fallen** in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [As dying to the face of sons of wickedness, you have died]

See how you translated the expression similar to **to the face of** in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [As dying at the hands of sons of wickedness, you have died] or [You died because sons of wickedness killed you]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [wicked men]
This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: [wept for him even more]; (2) Alternate translation: [wept for him again]

text: Then all the people came and urged David to eat something while it was still day, but David took an oath, saying, “May God punish me, and ever so severely, if I taste bread or anything else before the sun sets!”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about when this happened before the information about the people coming to David. Alternate translation: [Then, while it was still day, all of the people came to make David eat bread]

The author says **all of the people** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [Then the others in attendance came with concern]

The author is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food] or [a meal]

See how you translated the similar expression in [3:9](../03/09.md). Alternate translation: [If I taste bread or any of a thing to the face of the coming in of the sun, then may God do thus to me, and thus may he add]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:9](../03/09.md). Alternate translation: [Thus may God do to me, and may he do even worse]

The word **Thus**: (1) could refer to the way Abner died a violent death. Alternate translation: [May God make me suffer a violent death, as Abner did, and even worse]; (2) could be a general expression introducing the entire statement as a reference to severe punishment. Alternate translation: [May God punish me very severely]

David not eating bread or anything else until sunset, not even a small taste, was a symbolic action that showed deep mourning and grief in ancient Israelite culture. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [if I fail to show proper morning by even tasting any food before sunset]
Here, **face** represents “before.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [before the coming in of the sun]

David is using **the coming in of the sun** as a common expression of his culture to mean “sunset.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [before the sun goes down] or [before sunset]

text: All the people took note and were pleased. In fact, everything the king did pleased them.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:35](../03/35.md). Alternate translation: [And the others in attendance noticed]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [and they felt that he had done the right thing]

The author says **everything that the king did was good in the eyes of all of the people** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [just as the people of Judah generally felt that David, their king, was doing the right things]

text: So on that day all the troops and all Israel were convinced that the king had no part in the murder of Abner son of Ner.
Then the king said to his servants, “Do you not realize that a great prince has fallen today in Israel?

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form for emphasis when he makes a strong statement that his people should recognize Abner’s importance. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You must appreciate that a commander and great has fallen this day in Israel!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [a great commander]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [has died]
David is using the term **this day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [at this time]

text: And I am weak this day, though anointed as king, and these men, the sons of Zeruiah, are too fierce for me. May the LORD repay the evildoer according to his evil!”

translation_challanges.note: The expression **anointed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [even though Yahweh has anointed me to be the king]

text: Now when Ish-bosheth son of Saul heard that Abner had died in Hebron, he lost courage, and all Israel was dismayed.

translation_challanges.note: The author is reporting that Ishbosheth’s **hands dropped** in order to indicate that he lost his strength and courage. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he became weak with fear]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:28](../02/28.md). Alternate translation: [and all the people of Israel]

The expression **was terrified** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [became very afraid]

text: Saul’s son had two men who were leaders of raiding parties. One was named Baanah and the other Rechab; they were sons of Rimmon the Beerothite of the tribe of Benjamin—Beeroth is considered part of Benjamin,

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing **Baanah and Rechab** as new participants in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Among Ishbosheth’s officers were two men named Baanah and Rechab. They were sons of Rimmon from the town of Beeroth in the territory of Benjamin]

See the discussion of this statement in the Introduction to this chapter. Alternate translation: [While they were the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, since the city of Beeroth is within the territory of the tribe of Benjamin, they were considered to be members of the tribe of Benjamin]

The expression **is reckoned** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [for people also reckon Beeroth to Benjamin]

text: because the Beerothites fled to Gittaim and have lived there as foreigners to this day.

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of why the author may provide this information.

See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. The author is using this phrase to refer to the time when he was writing. In your translation, make clear that the phrase refers to a time that is already past. Avoid giving the impression the phrase means “to the present day.” Alternate translation: [right up to the time of this writing]

text: And Jonathan son of Saul had a son who was lame in his feet. He was five years old when the report about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled, but as she was hurrying to escape, he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:10](../02/10.md). Alternate translation: [He was five years of age]

The author is speaking of **the report** as if it were a living thing that could have come from a place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when people came from Jezreel and reported about Saul and Jonathan]

text: Now Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, set out and arrived at the house of Ish-bosheth in the heat of the day, while the king was taking his midday nap.

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **bed of noon** describes a special bed or couch on which someone would rest or sleep during the midday rest period that was common in this region where the middle of the day would be very hot. If your readers would not be familiar with this custom, you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [was resting during the heat of midday] or [was taking his midday nap]

text: They entered the interior of the house as if to get some wheat, and they stabbed him in the stomach. Then Rechab and his brother Baanah slipped away.

translation_challanges.note: Following the conventions of Hebrew storytelling, the author gives a general summary of these events in this verse and then describes them in more specific detail in the next verse. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could create a verse bridge for [verses 6–7](../04/06.md) and relate these events only once. The UST models one way to do that.
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [Then suddenly]

text: They had entered the house while Ish-bosheth was lying on his bed, and having stabbed and killed him, they beheaded him, took his head, and traveled all night by way of the Arabah.

They brought the head of Ish-bosheth to David at Hebron and said to the king, “Here is the head of Ish-bosheth son of Saul, your enemy who sought your life. Today the LORD has granted vengeance to my lord the king against Saul and his offspring.”

translation_challanges.note: Rechab and Baanah are using this phrase to describe Saul, not Ishbosheth. You may be able to use punctuation or some other convention of your language to make this clear.

By saying that Saul sought David’s **life**, Rechab and Baanah mean that Saul sought to take his life, that is, to kill him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to murder you]

One of the sons of Rimmon is addressing David, so he calls him **my** lord, but since he is speaking on behalf of both of them, it may be more natural in your language to use a plural pronoun. Alternate translation: [to our lord the king]

Even though the sons of Rimmon are addressing David directly, one of them is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [to you, my lord the king] or [to you, our lord the king]

The speaker is speaking here of descendants as if they were **seed**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and against his descendants]

text: But David answered Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, “As surely as the LORD lives, who has redeemed my life from all distress,

translation_challanges.note: The expression **and he said to them** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [But David responded to Rechab and Baanah his brother, the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite]

Following the custom of his culture, David is swearing an oath by guaranteeing it by something he holds sacred. David is using this oath to swear that what he says in the next verse is true. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath.

text: when someone told me, ‘Look, Saul is dead,’ and thought he was a bearer of good news, I seized him and put him to death at Ziklag. That was his reward for his news!

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [the one who declared to me that Saul was dead]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [and he thought that he was bringing good news]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:15](../01/15.md). Alternate translation: [that I had one of my soldiers seize him and kill him]

In this figure of speech, David actually means to communicate the opposite of the literal meaning of his words. (By saying that he gave him **a reward for good news**, he means that he killed the messenger for bringing what the messenger wrongly thought was good news.) If a speaker of your language would not say the opposite of what he meant, you could translate the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [which was how I punished him for telling me that he had killed Saul as if that had been good news]

text: How much more, when wicked men kill a righteous man in his own house and on his own bed, shall I not now require his blood from your hands and remove you from the earth!”

translation_challanges.note: David is using this expression to convey a strong feeling, his conviction that the crime of Rechab and Baanah is much greater than the crime of the person who told him that Saul was dead. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this feeling.

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [How much more would I punish rather than reward]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **wickedness** and **righteousness**, you could express the same ideas in other ways. Alternate translation: [wicked men … a righteous man]

**And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

David is using the question form to emphasize that he will certainly punish Rechab and Baanah for killing Ishbosheth. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I should certainly seek his blood from your hand and consume you from the earth!]

David is using **seek his blood from your hand** as a common expression of his culture to mean “punish you for killing him.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [should I not punish you for killing him]

Here, David is speaking as if he would **consume** the murderers as fire consumes something completely. This image emphasizes total destruction. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and completely destroy you]

text: So David commanded his young men, and they killed Rechab and Baanah. They cut off their hands and feet and hung their bodies by the pool in Hebron, but they took the head of Ish-bosheth and buried it in Abner’s tomb in Hebron.

translation_challanges.note: This could mean: (1) that David’s soldiers hung up the **hands** and **feet** of Rechab and Baanah beside the pool. This would have been a symbolic action, exposing to disgrace in a public location the hands that these men had used to murder Ishbosheth and the feet that they had used to flee with his head. By this action, David would have been repudiating their deed and warning others against doing anything similar. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and they hung their murderous hands and fugitive feet in disgrace beside the pool in Hebron]; (2) that David’s soldiers hung the bodies of Rechab and Baanah beside the pool. This too would have disgraced them as murderers, repudiated their deed, and warned others. However, it would have been a violation of [Deuteronomy 21:23](../../deu/21/23.md), which required the Israelites to bury the body of an executed person on the same day on which he was executed. So this is less likely. Alternate translation: [and they hung their bodies in disgrace beside the pool in Hebron]

text: Then all the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron and said, “Here we are, your own flesh and blood.

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking of a whole, **all of the tribes of Israel**, to mean a part of that whole, representatives of the tribes who came to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [representatives of all of the tribes of Israel]

The tribal representatives are using the courteous expression that people in this culture would use to tell a superior that they were ready and willing to obey his orders. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:7](../01/07.md).

Here, **we are your bone and your flesh** was a common expression that the tribal representatives were using to affirm to David that they were related by descent from a common ancestor. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [we are your blood relatives]

text: Even in times past, while Saul was king over us, you were the one who led Israel out and brought them back. And to you the LORD said, ‘You will shepherd My people Israel, and you will be ruler over them.’”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:7](../03/07.md). Alternate translation: [In the past]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:25](../03/25.md). Alternate translation: [the one leading Israel on military campaigns]

Here the term **Israel** represents the Israelite soldiers whom David commanded. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite soldiers]

The Israelite leaders are stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **you were** already includes this meaning. They are doing that to emphasize David’s personal role in leading the Israelite army. When Yahweh spoke to David as they describe, he was stating the pronoun **you** separately in both of these instances, even though the verbs translated as **you will shepherd** and **you will become** already included this meaning, to emphasize that he was making promises to David. If speakers of your language would use explicit pronouns for these same purposes, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meanings here.  Alternate translation: [you personally were … I promise that you will shepherd … and I promise that you will become]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And they reminded David that Yahweh had told him that he would shepherd the people of Israel and become their ruler]

These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [You yourself will shepherd my people Israel, indeed, you yourself will become the ruler over Israel]

Yahweh is speaking here as if David would actually **shepherd** the people of Israel as though they were sheep. This image compares the way a shepherd cares for and guides his sheep to the way a king should care for and lead his people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You yourself will care for and guide my people Israel]

text: So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron, where King David made with them a covenant before the LORD. And they anointed him king over Israel.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [and King David made a covenant with them]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:13](../03/13.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

text: David was thirty years old when he became king, and he reigned forty years.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is reintroducing **David** as a participant in the story in his new role as king over all Israel. Your language may have its own way of reintroducing participants in new roles that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Now David was 30 years old when he began to reign as king, and he ruled for 40 years]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:10](../02/10.md). Alternate translation: [David was 30 years old]

text: In Hebron he reigned over Judah seven years and six months, and in Jerusalem he reigned thirty-three years over all Israel and Judah.

Now the king and his men marched to Jerusalem against the Jebusites who inhabited the land. The Jebusites said to David: “You will never get in here. Even the blind and lame can repel you.” For they thought, “David cannot get in here.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is not referring to a specific **Jebusites**. He means the Jebusites who lived in this fortified area in Jerusalem. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use expressions that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [to the Jebusites, the inhabitants of that area. And they spoke to David]

The Jebusites say **the blind and the lame will turn you away** as an extreme statement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [our least capable soldiers will be able to keep you from capturing our city]

The Jebusites are using the adjectives **blind** and **lame** as nouns to mean people who cannot see and people who cannot walk well. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases. Alternate translation: [people who are blind and people who cannot walk well]

In this instance, the author is using the term **saying** to introduce what the Jebusites were thinking or saying to themselves. They did not say this out loud to David. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing what people said to themselves or thought. Alternate translation: [thinking to themselves]

text: Nevertheless, David captured the fortress of Zion (that is, the City of David).

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to explain to readers that the fortified area that he calls **Zion** is the same area that they know as **the City of David**. In your translation, present this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

text: On that day he said, “Whoever attacks the Jebusites must use the water shaft to reach the lame and blind who are despised by David.” That is why it is said, “The blind and the lame will never enter the palace.”

translation_challanges.note: David is not referring to a specific **Jebusite**. He means all of the Jebusites who are living in this fortified area of Jerusalem and fighting to keep him out of it. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [these Jebusites]

David is using the adjectives **lame** and **blind** as nouns to mean people who cannot walk well and people who cannot see. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate these adjectives with equivalent phrases. Alternate translation: [people who cannot walk well and people who cannot see]

The expression **hated by the soul of David** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [whom David’s soul hates]

David is using **the soul of David** to represent David himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [whom David hates]

In giving an official command to his soldiers, David is speaking about himself formally in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [whom I hate]

The author is providing the background information that David’s statement that he hated the lame and the blind was the origin of the popular saying that he quotes. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

The people using this popular saying are not referring to a specific **blind** or **lame** person. They mean blind and lame people in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [A blind person or a lame person]

Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [it came to be said] or [it became a saying]
In this saying, **the house** means the palace where the king lived. You could clarify this if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the palace]

text: So David took up residence in the fortress and called it the City of David. He built it up all the way around, from the supporting terraces inward.

translation_challanges.note: The word **Millo** is the name of a place. (It was likely a raised platform or landfill that formed part of Jerusalem’s fortifications.)

text: And David became greater and greater, for the LORD God of Hosts was with him.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And since Yahweh, the God of Armies, was with him, David went, going and becoming great]

The author is using **went, going and becoming great** as a common expression of his culture to mean “kept becoming greater and greater.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David kept becoming greater and greater]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [was helping him]

text: Now Hiram king of Tyre sent envoys to David, along with cedar logs, carpenters, and stonemasons, and they built a palace for David.

translation_challanges.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and he also sent trees of cedar]
The pronoun **they** refers to the woodworkers and stonemasons whom Hiram sent. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Hiram’s craftsmen built]

text: And David realized that the LORD had established him as king over Israel and had exalted his kingdom for the sake of His people Israel.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is speaking of David’s **kingdom** as if it had been an object that could have been lifted up physically. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he had made his kingdom prosperous and strong]

text: After he had arrived from Hebron, David took more concubines and wives from Jerusalem, and more sons and daughters were born to him.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And they bore more sons and daughters to David]

text: These are the names of the children born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,

translation_challanges.note: The expression **born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the sons he had]

text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over Israel, they all went in search of him; but David learned of this and went down to the stronghold.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [David had been anointed] or [the leaders of the Israelites had anointed David]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [and all of the Philistines went … and he went]

text: Now the Philistines had come and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.
So David inquired of the LORD, “Should I go up against the Philistines? Will You deliver them into my hand?” “Go up,” replied the LORD, “for I will surely deliver the Philistines into your hand.”

translation_challanges.note: In keeping with what is usual in this language and culture, David and Yahweh are marking travel for change in elevation. If these expressions contain extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten them. Alternate translation: [Shall I attack the Philistines … Attack them]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [into my power … into your power]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since giving, I will give the Philistines into your hand, go up]

Yahweh is repeating forms of the verb **give** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly give]

text: So David went to Baal-perazim, where he defeated the Philistines and said, “Like a bursting flood, the LORD has burst out against my enemies before me.” So he called that place Baal-perazim.

translation_challanges.note: See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. The meaning of that term here and in [verses 24](../05/24.md) and [25](../05/25.md) is “defeated.” Alternate translation: [and David defeated them]

Here, **face** represents opposing or being in front. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [who were in front of me] or [who were opposing me]

The point of this comparison is that just as a ** breach of waters** is powerful and overwhelming, so was Yahweh’s defeat of David’s enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [as powerfully as a rushing flood]

It might seem that the expression **called the name of** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [he called that place]
The name **Baal Perazim** means “the Lord of Breakthroughs.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in the text of your translation or in a footnote.

text: There the Philistines abandoned their idols, and David and his men carried them away.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **they** refers to the Philistines who were fleeing from David’s army. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines abandoned]

Taking away the Philistines’ idols was a symbolic action that illustrated the character of David’s victory over the Philistines and their gods. The Philistines had brought these idols into battle with them in the hopes that the gods they represented would help them defeat David and the Israelites. Instead, the gods themselves were shown to be helpless. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and David and his men carried off their idols to show how weak and helpless the Philistine gods were compared to Yahweh]

text: Once again the Philistines came up and spread out in the Valley of Rephaim.

translation_challanges.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation. He is also saying **resumed again**. If these expressions contain extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten them. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines invaded again]

text: So David inquired of the LORD, who answered, “Do not march straight up, but circle around behind them and attack them in front of the balsam trees.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Yahweh. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and Yahweh said]

While David would have had to move to a higher elevation in order to engage the Philistines, in this context, by telling him not to **go up**, Yahweh means that he should not make a direct, frontal attack. If this phrase would not have that meaning in your language in this context, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not make a frontal attack]

text: As soon as you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, move quickly, because this will mean that the LORD has gone out before you to strike the camp of the Philistines.”

translation_challanges.note: Here, **face** represents what is ahead of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in advance of you]

Here, **camp** represents the army that has camped in a place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the army of the Philistines]

text: So David did as the LORD had commanded him, and he struck down the Philistines all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.

translation_challanges.note: The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 14:16](../../1ch/14/16.md) read “Gibeon” instead of **Geba**. That may have been the original reading, particularly since the location of Gibeon suits the account of this battle better than the location of Geba. At one point in the process of transmission, scribes may have left out the additional letters that would have spelled “Gibeon” rather than “Geba,” either accidentally or as a way of abbreviating. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

text: David again assembled the chosen men of Israel, thirty thousand in all.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the adjective **chosen** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the select warriors] or [the elite troops]

text: And he and all his troops set out for Baale of Judah to bring up from there the ark of God, which is called by the Name—the name of the LORD of Hosts, who is enthroned between the cherubim that are on it.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [And David took action]

The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 13:6](../../1ch/13/06.md) explains that **Baalah** was another name for Kiriath Jearim. That was where the Box had remained since the Philistines returned it after capturing it, according to [1 Samuel 7:2](../../1sa/07/02.md). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in the text of your translation or in a footnote.

In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [to bring]

The expression **whose name is called** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [which people call]

text: They set the ark of God on a new cart and brought it from the house of Abinadab, which was on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were guiding the new cart,

translation_challanges.note: The author assumes that his readers will know that by **on the hill**, he means a certain hill within the city of Baalah, that is, Kiriath Jearim. Since modern readers would not recognize the identity of this hill, it may be more natural to speak of it in general terms. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 7:1](../../1sa/07/01.md). Alternate translation: [which was on a hill]

The author is speaking of the **new cart** to mean the oxen that were pulling the cart. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the oxen that were pulling the new cart]

text: bringing with it the ark of God. And Ahio was walking in front of the ark.

translation_challanges.note: The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in 1 Chronicles do not have this sentence, which seems to have been repeated accidentally from the previous verse. Without it, the text of [verses 3–4](../06/03.md) would sensibly read, “And Uzzah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, were leading the new cart with the Box of God” (that is, the new cart that had the Box of God on it). Many versions of the Bible do not include this sentence. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to omit the sentence if it does.

The author assumes that his readers will know that Ahio and Uzzah were following the custom of this culture for steadying a load on a cart that animals were pulling. One person would walk ahead of the cart, leading and guiding the animals, while another person would walk next to the cart to make sure that the load did not fall off. By saying that **Ahio was walking to the face of the Box**, he also means that Uzzah was walking alongside the cart that was carrying it, as the story itself indicates in [6:6](../06/06.md). You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. The UST models one way to do that.
Here, **to the face of** represents “in front of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of]

Here, **the Box** represents the oxen that were pulling the cart that was carrying the Box. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the oxen that were pulling the cart that was carrying the Box]

text: David and all the house of Israel were celebrating before the LORD with all kinds of wood instruments, harps, stringed instruments, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [and all of the people of Israel]

The author says **and all of the house of Israel** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [and people from throughout Israel]

Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:13](../03/13.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

The expression **all woods of cypress** means various musical instruments made from cypress wood.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with various musical instruments made from cypress wood]

A **tambourine** is a kind of hand-held drum with metal discs around its frame that jingle when people shake or strike the drum. If your readers would not be familiar with what a tambourine is, you could use the name of a similar instrument that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and with hand drums] or [and with jingling drums]

A **sistrum** is a kind of musical instrument consisting of a handle and a U-shaped metal frame with loose metal crossbars that jingle when people shake the frame. If your readers would not be familiar with what a sistrum is, you could use the name of a similar instrument that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and with rattles] or [and with shaking instruments]

A **cymbal** is a kind of musical instrument made of two metal discs that people strike together to make a loud, ringing sound. If your readers would not be familiar with what a cymbal is, you could use the name of a similar instrument that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and with clashing metal discs] or [and with metal percussion instruments]

text: When they came to the threshing floor of Nacon, Uzzah reached out and took hold of the ark of God, because the oxen had stumbled.

translation_challanges.note: The word **Nacon** is the name of the place where this threshing floor was located.

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [and because the oxen stumbled, Uzzah reached out to the Box of God and held it]

text: And the anger of the LORD burned against Uzzah, and God struck him down on the spot for his irreverence, and he died there beside the ark of God.

translation_challanges.note: The author is describing Yahweh becoming extremely angry by alluding to the way a person’s **nose** may become hot and red when he is angry. Your culture may also associate anger with heat or with a particular part of the body, and if so, you could use its characteristic expression in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [And Yahweh blazed with fury] or [And Yahweh became extremely angry]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Alternate translation: [and God killed him]

text: Then David became angry because the LORD had burst forth against Uzzah. So he named that place Perez-uzzah, as it is called to this day.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And because Yahweh had broken out an outbreak against Uzzah, it burned to David]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [And David became angry]

It might seem that the expression **Yahweh had broken out an outbreak** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Yahweh had broken out]
The name **Perez Uzzah** means “Outbreak against Uzzah.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in the text of your translation or in a footnote.

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and that is still its name to this day]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [as of the time of this writing]

text: That day David feared the LORD and asked, “How can the ark of the LORD ever come to me?”

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form to express his concern about trying bring the Box of Yahweh to where he lives. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I should not dare to try to bring the Box of Yahweh to me!]

text: So he was unwilling to move the ark of the LORD to the City of David; instead, he took it aside to the house of Obed-edom the Gittite.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing **Obed Edom** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a certain man named Obed Edom who came from Gath]

text: Thus the ark of the LORD remained in the house of Obed-edom the Gittite for three months, and the LORD blessed him and all his household.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **house** by association to mean the people who lived in the same house with a man. He means the people in that man’s household. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [and his entire household]

text: Now it was reported to King David, “The LORD has blessed the house of Obed-edom and all that belongs to him, because of the ark of God.” So David went and had the ark of God brought up from the house of Obed-edom into the City of David with rejoicing.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **it was declared** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone declared]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [and he brought]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **joy**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [joyfully]

text: When those carrying the ark of the LORD had advanced six paces, he sacrificed an ox and a fattened calf.

translation_challanges.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how having the **lifters of the Box** pause after taking **six steps** could have been a symbolic action.

It might seem that the expression **stepped six steps** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [had taken six steps]

text: And David, wearing a linen ephod, danced with all his might before the LORD,

translation_challanges.note: Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

The expression **was girded** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And David was wearing an ephod of linen]

Wearing **an ephod of linen** was a symbolic action by which David showed he was humbling himself before Yahweh. He was dressing like an ordinary worshiper rather than wearing his royal robes. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And David had humbly dressed himself in a simple linen garment]

text: while he and all the house of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouting and the sounding of the ram’s horn.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [and all of the people of Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [6:5](../06/05.md). Alternate translation: [and people from throughout Israel]

When the author says **bringing up**, the implication is that David and the Israelites were bringing the Box of Yahweh up the mountain into Jerusalem. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [were bringing the Box of Yahweh up the mountain into Jerusalem]

The author is not referring to a specific **shofar**. He means shofars in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [shofars]

text: As the ark of the LORD was entering the City of David, Saul’s daughter Michal looked down from a window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the LORD, and she despised him in her heart.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is reintroducing Michal into the story as **the daughter of Saul** to remind readers of who she was and to hint at why she might disapprove of David’s actions. If your language has its own way of reintroducing participants with characterizing information, you could use it here in your translation. Alternate translation: [But David’s wife Michal, who was Saul’s daughter]
Here the **heart** represents the feelings. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and she felt great disdain toward him]

text: So they brought the ark of the LORD and set it in its place inside the tent that David had pitched for it. Then David offered burnt offerings and peace offerings before the LORD.
When David had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and peace offerings, he blessed the people in the name of the LORD of Hosts.

translation_challanges.note: The author is not referring to a specific **burnt offering**. He means burnt offerings in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the burnt offerings]

To bless people **in the name of Yahweh** was to name Yahweh as the one whom one hoped and believed would bless those people. (The poetic parallel in [Psalm 129:8](../../psa/129/008.md) indicates this. It says, “May the blessing of Yahweh be on you; we bless you in the name of Yahweh.”) Alternate translation: [and he called upon Yahweh of Armies to bless the people]

text: Then he distributed to every man and woman among the multitude of Israel a loaf of bread, a date cake, and a raisin cake. And all the people departed, each to his own home.

translation_challanges.note: The expressions **all of the people** and **all of the multitude of Israel** mean similar things. The author is using the two expressions together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [to all of the Israelites who had gathered there]

In these cases, the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [to each one … each one back to his or her home]

text: When David returned home to bless his own household, Saul’s daughter Michal came out to meet him. “How the king of Israel has distinguished himself today!” she said. “He has uncovered himself today in the sight of the maidservants of his subjects, like a vulgar person would do.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **house** to mean the people who lived in the same house with a man. He means the people in that man’s household. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [his household]

Even though Michal is addressing David directly, she is speaking of him in the third person mockingly as **the king of Israel**, as if she were showing respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person, even though that would still represent mockery on the part of Michal. Alternate translation: [How you, the king of Israel, honored yourself today by uncovering yourself today to the eyes of the female servants of your servants]

In this figure of speech, Michal actually means to communicate the opposite of the literal meaning of her words. If a speaker of your language would not do that, you could translate the meaning plainly Alternate translation: [How the king of Israel disgraced himself today]
Here, **eyes** represent seeing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the sight of]

Michal is repeating forms of the verb “uncover” in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. Alternate translation: [as one of the worthless shamelessly uncovers himself]

Michal is using the adjective **worthless** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [a worthless person]

text: But David said to Michal, “I was dancing before the LORD, who chose me over your father and all his house when He appointed me ruler over the LORD’s people Israel. I will celebrate before the LORD,

translation_challanges.note: Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [In the presence of Yahweh … in the presence of Yahweh]

The author is using the term **house** to mean all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. Alternate translation: [his descendants]

The terms **over the people of Yahweh** and **over Israel** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [over his people Israel]

text: and I will humiliate and humble myself even more than this. Yet I will be honored by the maidservants of whom you have spoken.”

translation_challanges.note: David is using the expression **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in my own regard]

The expression **I will be honored** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But the female servants about whom you spoke will honor me]

text: And Michal the daughter of Saul had no children to the day of her death.
After the king had settled into his palace and the LORD had given him rest from all his enemies around him,

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the words **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

The author is using a common expression of his culture when he says that Yahweh **gave rest** to David. He means that Yahweh made it so none of the enemy nations around him were at war with him. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and Yahweh had made it so that he was not at war with any of the enemy nations around him]

text: he said to Nathan the prophet, “Here I am, living in a house of cedar, while the ark of God remains in a tent.”

translation_challanges.note: David is using the term **See** to focus Nathan’s attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Listen]
Here, **cedars** represent cedar wood. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in a house built of cedar wood]

Israelites characteristically referred to the individual pieces of cloth that they sewed together to make tents as “curtains,” and they referred to an entire tent made from such pieces as a **curtain**. It may be more natural in your language to use a plural form here. Alternate translation: [in the midst of tent-curtains] or [in a tent]
