The implication is that David wanted to build a splendid temple for Yahweh and put the Box in it. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but the Box of God is dwelling in the midst of a curtain. I want to build a splendid temple for Yahweh and put the Box in it]

text: And Nathan replied to the king, “Go and do all that is in your heart, for the LORD is with you.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since Yahweh is with you, go, do all that is in your heart]
Here, the **heart** represents a person’s desires. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [All that you desire to do]

Nathan is not telling David to **go** somewhere. He is saying **go** to mean that David should take action. (The meaning is similar to that of the term “arise” in [3:21](../03/21.md).) Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [go ahead and do] or [take action and do]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [Yahweh will help you]

text: But that night the word of the LORD came to Nathan, saying,

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the words **But it happened** to introduce a new development in this episode. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

When the author says that **the word of Yahweh was to Nathan**, he is using a common expression to mean that Yahweh spoke a message to Nathan. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that Yahweh spoke a message to Nathan]

text: “Go and tell My servant David that this is what the LORD says: Are you the one to build for Me a house to dwell in?

translation_challanges.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how you might use punctuation or some other convention of your language to indicate the second-level, third-level, and fourth-level quotations in Yahweh’s message to Nathan in [verses 5–16](../07/05.md). That discussion also suggests that, alternatively, you could translate these verses in such a way that there are not quotations within quotations. The UST models one way to do that.

Yahweh is using the question form for emphasis, to tell David that he will not build a house for him to dwell in. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You shall not build for me a house for my dwelling.]

Yahweh is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **will you build** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that David is wanting to do something that he has never asked the Israelites to do for him. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [No, you shall not build a house for my dwelling]

Yahweh is speaking here as if David wants to build him a physical **house** as his **dwelling**. He is actually speaking of a temple where he would be present with his people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a temple where I will be present]

text: For I have not dwelt in a house from the day I brought the Israelites up out of Egypt until this day, but I have moved about with a tent as My dwelling.

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]

Here, Yahweh is speaking as if a temple were actually a physical **house** in which he might live. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a temple]
Yahweh is using the term **day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [since the time when I brought up]

In keeping with what is usual for this language and culture, Yahweh is marking travel for change in elevation. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [my bringing]

Here, **sons** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the sons of Israel** figuratively means all the people descended from the patriarch Jacob, who was also known as Israel. Alternate translation: [the people of Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [up to this time]

The phrase **in a tent and in a dwelling** expresses a single idea. The word **dwelling** describes the purpose of the **tent**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [in a tent for my dwelling]

text: In all My journeys with all the Israelites, have I ever asked any of the leaders I appointed to shepherd My people Israel, ‘Why haven’t you built Me a house of cedar?’

translation_challanges.note: Yahweh is using the question form to emphasize that he never asked any of Israel’s leaders to build him a house. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I did not speak a word with one of the scepters of Israel whom I commanded to shepherd my people Israel, saying, ‘Why have you not built for me a house of cedars’!]

Yahweh is using the term **word** to represent what he might have said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [did I give a command to]

Here, **scepters** represents “leaders,” since leaders held scepters as an emblem of their office. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [any of the leaders of Israel]

Here, Yahweh is speaking as if each of these leaders was a **shepherd** and as if his **people Israel** were sheep. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to guide]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [a temple built from cedar wood]

text: Now then, you are to tell My servant David that this is what the LORD of Hosts says: I took you from the pasture, from following the flock, to be the ruler over My people Israel.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [I personally took you]

Yahweh is referring to the way a shepherd works in a **pasture** and walks behind a **flock** to represent the work of a shepherd generally. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from being a shepherd]

The terms **over my people** and **over Israel** mean similar things. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [over my people Israel]

text: I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have cut off all your enemies from before you. Now I will make for you a name like that of the greatest in the land.

translation_challanges.note: Yahweh is using **I have been with you** as a common expression of this culture to mean “I have helped you.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I have helped you]

Yahweh is speaking as if he had physically **cut off** David’s enemies, as if they had been a branch he wanted to remove from a tree. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I have destroyed]

Here, **from your face** means “in front of you,” with the implication that these enemies were confronting David and opposing him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [before you] or [who opposed you]

Here, a person’s **name** represents his reputation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [a great reputation, like the reputation of]

Yahweh is using the adjective **great** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the great leaders]

text: And I will provide a place for My people Israel and will plant them so that they may dwell in a place of their own and be disturbed no more. No longer will the sons of wickedness oppress them as they did at the beginning

translation_challanges.note: In this verse, the words **him** and **he** are singular in form, but they refer to all the Israelites as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural forms of these words. Alternate translation: [and I will plant them that they may dwell in their place, and they will not tremble … to afflict them]

Yahweh is speaking here as if he would physically **plant** the Israelites, as if they were a tree or some other plant. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I will make them secure]

Yahweh is using a common expression of this culture that means “that the Israelites may live on the ground that is under them.” Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 14:9](../../1sa/14/09.md). Alternate translation: [that the Israelites may live in that place]

Here, **tremble** represents being afraid. It refers to trembling with fear. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and he will not be afraid]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:34](../03/34.md). Alternate translation: [wicked people]

The phrase **at first** refers to an earlier time. If your language would not represent a number in a form such as **first**, you could represent this number in a form that your language would use or in some other way that would be clear in your language. Alternate translation: [as formerly]

The expression **at first** refers to the time when Israel was oppressed in Egypt. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [as at the time when you were slaves in Egypt]

text: and have done since the day I appointed judges over My people Israel. I will give you rest from all your enemies. The LORD declares to you that He Himself will establish a house for you.

translation_challanges.note: Yahweh is using the term **day** to refer to a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and during the time when]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:1](../07/01.md). Alternate translation: [And I will make it so that you are not at war with any of your enemies]

In making an official declaration, Yahweh is speaking about himself formally in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [And I, Yahweh, declare to you that I will make]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [a royal dynasty]

text: And when your days are fulfilled and you rest with your fathers, I will raise up your descendant after you, who will come from your own body, and I will establish his kingdom.

translation_challanges.note: **When your days are full** is a common expression of his culture to mean “when you have lived out your life.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When you have lived out your life]

Yahweh is referring to death in a polite way by using the phrase **lie down**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and you pass away as your fathers have] or [and you join your fathers in death]
Yahweh is using the term **fathers** to mean “ancestors.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [your ancestors]

Yahweh is speaking as if he will physically **raise up** one of David’s descendants to a high location. He means that he will make him become the next king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then I will make reign as king after you]

Yahweh is speaking of David’s descendant as if he were a **seed** and as if David were a plant that had produced it. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [one of your offspring]

The implication is that David will be the actual father of this son (that is, he will not be an adopted or foster son), and that this will happen in the future. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [whom you will father in the future]

text: He will build a house for My Name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression “you, you will shepherd” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [I promise that he will build]

Yahweh is speaking as if this descendant of David would build him a physical **house**. He means that he will build him a temple, a special building for worshiping him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a temple]

Here, **throne** represents the authority to rule as king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [his reign as king]

text: I will be his Father, and he will be My son. When he does wrong, I will discipline him with the rod of men and with the blows of the sons of men.

translation_challanges.note: Yahweh is speaking here as if he and David’s descendant would actually be **father** and **son**. He means that he will treat David’s descendant the way a father treats a son. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will treat him the way a father treats his son]

The terms **rod of men** and **blows of the sons of man** mean similar things. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [with human punishments]

Here, **rod** and **blows** represent punishment or discipline. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with human discipline]

This could mean: (1) that Yahweh will discipline David’s son with measures of the same type and purpose that humans use to correct their children, not with divine judgments that would destroy him and his descendants. Alternate translation: [with measures such as humans use to correct their children]; (2) that Yahweh will use human beings as his agents to punish David’s son. Alternate translation: [I will use people to punish him]

Here the masculine term **sons of man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [human beings]

text: But My loving devotion will never be removed from him as I removed it from Saul, whom I removed from before you.

translation_challanges.note: Yahweh is speaking of **covenant faithfulness** as if it were a living thing that could **turn away** from someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But I will not stop treating you with covenant faithfulness]

The word **you** is plural here because Yahweh is using it to mean both David and his descendants. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Other languages may have other ways of making the meaning clear. Alternate translation: [from you and your descendants]

Here, Yahweh is speaking as if he had physically **turned it away** his covenant faithfulness away from Saul. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as I stopped treating Saul with it]

Here, **face** represents the area in front of someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [I turned away from in front of you]

Yahweh is speaking as if Saul had been in front of David, that is, in his way, as David moved toward becoming king. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I removed so that you could be king]

text: Your house and kingdom will endure forever before Me, and your throne will be established forever.”

translation_challanges.note: The two phrases **your house and your kingdom will be confirmed to forever to your face** and **your throne will be established to forever** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [And your house and your kingdom will be confirmed to forever to your face, yes, your throne will be established to forever]

The expression **will be confirmed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [And I will confirm your house and your kingdom]

The terms **house** and **kingdom** mean similar things. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [your royal dynasty]

Here, **face** represents what is in front of someone, but in time rather than in space. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [beyond you into the future]

The expression **will be established** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [I will establish your throne]

Here, **throne** represents royal authority or rule. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [The reign of your descendants]

This is the end of Yahweh’s message to Nathan. Review your translation of [verses 5–16](../07/05.md) to ensure that you have consistently used punctuation or some other convention of your language to indicate the second-level, third-level, and fourth-level quotations in this message. Alternatively, you may have decided to translate the entire message in such a way that there are not quotations within quotations. If so, ensure that you have done that consistently.

text: So Nathan relayed to David all the words of this entire revelation.

translation_challanges.note: Together, the terms **words** and **vision** express a single idea. The term **vision** tells how Yahweh conveyed these **words** to David. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [According to all of these words that Yahweh had spoken to him in a vision]

Here, **words** represents what Yahweh said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [According to all of these things that Yahweh had said to him in a vision]

text: Then King David went in, sat before the LORD, and said, “Who am I, O Lord GOD, and what is my house, that You have brought me this far?

translation_challanges.note: Here, **face** represents “presence.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the presence of Yahweh]

David is using the question form to express his humility and amazement at what God has done for him. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [I am not so significant, my Lord Yahweh, and neither is my house, that you should have brought me to here!]
By **my house**, David probably means his “father’s house,” that is, the extended family from which he comes. Alternate translation: [my family]

The implication is that **here** means being the king of Israel. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [that you have made me the king of Israel]

text: And as if this was a small thing in Your eyes, O Lord GOD, You have also spoken about the future of the house of Your servant. Is this Your custom with man, O Lord GOD?

translation_challanges.note: David is using **this was small in your eyes** as a common expression of his culture to mean “you considered this to be insignificant.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you considered even this a small thing]

David is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person, here and in the rest of this chapter. Alternate translation: [my house]

Here, **house** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of your servant** figuratively means all the people who would descend from David. Alternate translation: [my descendants]

This could mean: (1) that David is marveling that Yahweh has established the perpetual reign of his descendants as a **law** that people must obey. Alternate translation: [And you, my Lord Yahweh, have made the perpetual reign of my descendants a law that people must obey!]; (2) that David is marveling that Yahweh has said that if his descendants do wrong, he will correct them with human-style discipline, not destroy them with divine judgments ([verse 14](../07/14.md)). Alternate translation: [And you, my Lord Yahweh, have said that you will not destroy my descendants if they do wrong but correct them as humans discipline their children!]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [human beings]

text: What more can David say to You? For You know Your servant, O Lord GOD.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form to express that he is too overwhelmed to say anything more. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I find that I am now at a loss for words!]

David is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **you know** already includes this meaning. He is doing that in order to contrast Yahweh’s knowledge of what he is thinking and feeling with his own inability to say anything further. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [But for your part, you know your servant]

Here, **your servant** represents what David wants to say. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [But you certainly know what I, your servant, want to say]

text: For the sake of Your word and according to Your own heart, You have accomplished this great thing and revealed it to Your servant.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the term **word** to represent what Yahweh said on some previous occasion by using words. In context, he seems to be referring to how Yahweh instructed Samuel in [1 Samuel 16:12](../../1sa/16/12.md) to anoint him as king. This constituted a commitment on Yahweh’s part to make David the king. The idea here seems to be that in order to keep this promise in the fullest sense, Yahweh is going to make David the head of a royal dynasty. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [In order to keep your promise in the fullest sense]

Here, the **heart** represents a person’s desires. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [according to your desire] or [because you wanted to]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **greatness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [all these great things]

In this context, the verb form **to make … know** does not describe the purpose of the preceding action **you have done all this greatness**. Instead, it describes an accompanying action. Use an appropriate verbal form in your language to convey this meaning. Alternate translation: [and you have made me, your servant, know this]

text: How great You are, O Lord GOD! For there is none like You, and there is no God but You, according to everything we have heard with our own ears.

translation_challanges.note: David is not saying that the reason why Yahweh is **great** is that he has done the great things for him that he describes in the previous verse. David means that he is able to declare confidently to Yahweh **you are great** because he has personally experienced his greatness and goodness in these ways. If this would not be clear, you may want to use a different connecting word or phrase to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. It may be possible to make the relationship clear without using any connecting word or phrase. The UST models one way to do that. Alternate translation: [As a result, I can confidently declare]
Here the word **for** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [and after all]

These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [no god is like you, indeed, you are the only God]

It might seem that in this context, the expression **with our ears** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could leave it out. Alternate translation: [in all that we have heard]

text: And who is like Your people Israel—the one nation on earth whom God went out to redeem as a people for Himself and to make a name for Himself? You performed great and awesome wonders by driving out nations and their gods from before Your people, whom You redeemed for Yourself from Egypt.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [And there is no other nation like your people … and its gods!]

The terms **like your people** and **like Israel** mean similar things. David is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [is like your people Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:3](../07/03.md). Alternate translation: [took action]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:9](../07/09.md). Alternate translation: [a reputation]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **greatness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [great things]

The word **you** is plural here because it refers to the Israelites, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [for you, O Israel] or [for them]

David has been addressing Yahweh in his prayer, but now he briefly addresses the nation of Israel (as **you**), even though he knows that the people of this nation cannot hear him. (David has gone to the sacred tent to speak with Yahweh alone, as [verse 18](../07/18.md) indicates.) He does this in order to express more powerfully his feelings about the **greatness** (great things) that Yahweh has done for Israel. You may be able to use punctuation or some other convention of your language to show that the addressee changes briefly here. You might also use a first-person plural pronoun to show that by **you** (plural), David is referring to the people group to which he belongs, not to Yahweh, to whom the singular forms of “you” refer in the rest of the verse. Alternate translation: [for us]

The expression **being feared** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and fearsome things]
The word **your** is singular here because it refers to Yahweh. So use the singular form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [for your land, O Yahweh]

Here, **from the face of** means “in front of,” with the implication that Yahweh did these fearsome things to defeat the enemies who were confronting the Israelites and opposing them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of] or [against the nations that opposed]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and from other enemy nations and the gods of each one]

text: For You have established Your people Israel as Your very own forever, and You, O LORD, have become their God.
And now, O LORD God, confirm forever the word You have spoken concerning Your servant and his house. Do as You have promised,

translation_challanges.note: **And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

David is using the term **word** to represent what God said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the things that you have said]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [my royal dynasty]

The phrases **raise up to forever** and **do just as you have spoken** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [raise up to forever, indeed, fulfill what you have promised]

David is speaking as if Yahweh’s **word** were an object that Yahweh could physically **raise up** or lift into a high position. He means that he wants Yahweh to fulfill the promise that he has made. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expressions in [1 Samuel 1:23](../../1sa/01/23.md), [1 Samuel 3:12](../../1sa/03/12.md), and [1 Samuel 15:11](../../1sa/15/11.md). Alternate translation: [perform] or [fulfill]

text: so that Your name will be magnified forever when it is said, ‘The LORD of Hosts is God over Israel.’ And the house of Your servant David will be established before You.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **name** represents “reputation.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [your reputation]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [as people say that you, Yahweh of Armies, are God over Israel]

The term **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. (In some languages, it may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly.) Alternate translation: [so that people will say]

The expression **will be established** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you will establish the house of your servant David]
See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [and the dynasty of]

This could mean: (1) that David is using one part of Yahweh, his **face**, to mean all of him in the act of maintaining the rule of David and his descendants. The idea is that Yahweh would be watching them and protecting them. Alternate translation: [as you maintain it]; (2) that David is using Yahweh’s **face** to represent his presence. Alternate translation: [in your presence]

text: For You, O LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel, have revealed this to Your servant when You said, ‘I will build a house for you.’ Therefore Your servant has found the courage to offer this prayer to You.

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]

David is using a common expression, **You have uncovered the ear**, that described one person telling something to another person. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You have told this to your servant] or [You have told this to me]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that you will build a house for me]

David is using **found his heart** as a common expression of his culture to mean “found courage” or “became brave enough.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [your servant has found the courage] or [I have found the courage]

text: And now, O Lord GOD, You are God! Your words are true, and You have promised this goodness to Your servant.

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that the expression **you {are} he, the God** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [you are God]
The implication is that Yahweh is the only true God. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [you are the only true God]

David is using the term **words** to represent what Yahweh says by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and what you say is true]

David is using the adjective **good** as a noun to mean a certain kind of thing. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [this good thing]

text: Now therefore, may it please You to bless the house of Your servant, that it may continue forever before You. For You, O Lord GOD, have spoken, and with Your blessing the house of Your servant will be blessed forever.”

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **take pleasure and bless** expresses a single idea. The word **take pleasure** tells with what attitude David hopes Yahweh will **bless** him and his descendants. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [gladly bless] or [may it please you to bless]

David is speaking here as if the dynasty Yahweh has promised him would actually be a **house**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the dynasty of your servant] or [my dynasty]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:26](../07/26.md). Alternate translation: [maintained by you] or [in your presence]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation: [For you, my Lord Yahweh, have told me this personally]

The expression **will be blessed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you will bless the house of your servant forever with your blessing]

text: Some time later, David defeated the Philistines, subdued them, and took Metheg-ammah from the hand of the Philistines.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [that David defeated the Philistines]

Here and frequently in this chapter, the author uses **David**, one person who was involved in these actions, to represent everyone who was involved. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md), where “David” means “David and his supporters.” Alternate translation: [David and his army]

The expression **Metheg Ammah** seems to be a description rather than the name of a place. No place is known by that name. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:1](../../1ch/18/01.md) says that David captured the city of Gath and its surrounding towns. **Metheg Ammah** means “the bridle of the mother city.” Gath was the capital city of the Philistine confederation, and the author may speak of it here as a “bridle” to mean that conquering it gave David the means to control the entire Philistine confederation. (The word “bridle” could also indicate that previously the Philistines had exercised control over the Israelites from their capital city of Gath.) In your translation, you may wish to represent the expression “Metheg Ammah” and spell it the way it sounds in your language. Alternatively, you could express the probable meaning and translate the expression as a reference to Gath. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to take the approach that it takes. Alternate translation: [Gath, their capital city]

Here, **hand** represents possession or control. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the possession of the Philistines]

text: David also defeated the Moabites, made them lie down on the ground, and measured them off with a cord. He measured off with two lengths those to be put to death, and with one length those to be spared. So the Moabites became subject to David and brought him tribute.

translation_challanges.note: The author is describing one event, David measuring these enemy soldiers **with a rope**, before describing another event that preceded it, David **making them lie on the ground**. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [and he made them lie on the ground and measured them with a rope]
The pronoun **them** refers to the Moabite soldiers. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the Moabite soldiers]

The implication is that David used a rope divided into three equal parts to measure groups of Moabite soldiers. He killed those who were lying under the first two parts but let those under the third part live. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [He used a rope divided into three equal parts. He stretched it out and killed the soldiers lying under the first two parts, but he let the soldiers lying under the rest of the rope live]

In this verse, the word **Moab** is singular in form, but it refers to all the Moabite people as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could refer to these people by using a plural form. Alternate translation: [the Moabites]

The author is using the first thing that subject peoples would do to deliver tribute, lift it onto the backs of animals that would transport it, to represent the entire action of paying tribute. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [bringers of tribute] or [vassals]

text: David also defeated Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah, who had marched out to restore his dominion along the Euphrates River.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Hadadezer. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [when Hadadezer went]
See the Introduction to this chapter for a discussion of this phrase and for suggestions of how you might represent it in your translation.

The author is referring to the Euphrates River, which was the most important river in this region and so was sometimes simply called **the River**. You could use your language’s name for this river if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [at the Euphrates River]

text: David captured from him a thousand chariots, seven thousand charioteers, and twenty thousand foot soldiers, and he hamstrung all the horses except a hundred he kept for the chariots.

translation_challanges.note: The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:4](../../1ch/18/04.md) read “1,000 chariots and 7,000 horsemen.” That may have been the original reading. At one point in the process of transmission, scribes may have accidentally left out the word “chariots,” and the letters or points that indicated numbers may also have been unintentionally altered. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

Here the term **chariots** represents the horses that pulled these chariots. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And David hamstrung all of the chariot horses, but he left from them 100 horses]

If, in your language, it would appear that the author was making a statement here and then contradicting it, you could reverse the order of the clauses so that the exception is stated first and then the larger group is named second. Alternate translation: [And after choosing 100 horses from the chariots, David had his soldiers hamstring the rest]

When the author says that David **hamstrung** these horses, he meant that he had his soldiers use a method of disabling them by cutting tendons in their legs. This would be done carefully so that horses would still be able to walk and carry loads, but they would no longer be able to run. As a result, they could no longer be used in warfare. If your readers would not be familiar with what hamstringing is, you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [And David had his soldiers disable all of the chariot horses by cutting their leg tendons]

text: When the Arameans of Damascus came to help King Hadadezer of Zobah, David struck down twenty-two thousand of their men.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **Aram of Damascus** represents the army of the Aramean kingdom whose capital was Damascus. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the army of the Aramean kingdom whose capital was Damascus]

text: Then he placed garrisons in Aram of Damascus, and the Arameans became subject to David and brought him tribute. So the LORD made David victorious wherever he went.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [8:2](../08/02.md). Alternate translation: [and the Arameans became servants to David and brought him tribute]

The author is making a summary comment about everything he has described since introducing a new event in [8:1](../08/01.md). This signals the end of his account of these wars that David fought. Use the natural form in your language for indicating the conclusion of a story.

text: And David took the gold shields that belonged to the officers of Hadadezer and brought them to Jerusalem.

translation_challanges.note: The meaning of the word translated as **shields** is uncertain. It could be a general term for military equipment whose meaning must be understood from the context. In some contexts, such as [Jeremiah 51:11](../../jer/51/11.md), it seems to mean “quivers” or arrow-cases, and some versions also translate it that way here. However, the context seems to support the meaning of **shields**. Some ancient rulers had their bodyguard carry shields that were plated with precious metals, and Hadadezer may have done that. Alternate translation: [the gold-plated shields that Hadadezer’s bodyguard had carried]

text: And from Betah and Berothai, cities of Hadadezer, King David took a large amount of bronze.

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **took bronze, making very much** expresses a single idea. The expression **making very much** tells in what way David **took bronze**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [greatly took bronze] or [took very much bronze]

text: When King Toi of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of Hadadezer,
he sent his son Joram to greet King David and bless him for fighting and defeating Hadadezer, who had been at war with Toi. Joram brought with him articles of silver and gold and bronze,

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Here the word **peace** indicates the idea of “welfare.” Alternate translation: [to ask about his welfare] or [to say that he hoped he was doing well]

The author is using **a man of war** as a common expression of his culture to mean “someone who fought wars against.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For Hadadezer had been fighting wars against Toi]

Here the author is providing background information to help readers understand what is happening in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. Alternate translation: [Hadadezer had been fighting wars against him]

The author does not mean that Joram somehow held all of these **vessels** in his **hand**. He is using the term **hand** to indicate that Joram was the agent who conveyed the vessels to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And he brought]
The pronoun **his** refers to Joram. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And in Joram’s hand were] or [And Joram brought]

text: and King David dedicated these to the LORD, along with the silver and gold he had dedicated from all the nations he had subdued—
from Edom and Moab, from the Ammonites and Philistines and Amalekites, and from the spoil of Hadadezer son of Rehob, king of Zobah.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: [and from the Ammonites]

text: And David made a name for himself when he returned from striking down eighteen thousand Edomites in the Valley of Salt.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:9](../07/09.md). Alternate translation: [a reputation]

The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation of the Hebrew Bible) and the parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:12](../../1ch/18/12.md) read “Edom.” That may have been the original reading, particularly since the **the Valley of Salt** (the Arabah south of the Dead Sea) was close to Edom, not to Aram. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [killing 18,000 Edomites]

text: He placed garrisons throughout Edom, and all the Edomites were subject to David. So the LORD made David victorious wherever he went.

translation_challanges.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [And he stationed military garrisons throughout all of Edom]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [there were garrisons throughout all of Edom] or [he placed garrisons throughout all of Edom]

After providing some further details about the plunder David captured, the gifts he received, and how he defeated Edom, the author is once again making a summary comment about everything he has described since introducing a new event in [8:1](../08/01.md). See how you translated the similar expression in [8:6](../08/06.md).

text: Thus David reigned over all Israel and administered justice and righteousness for all his people:

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **justice and righteousness** expresses a single idea. The word **righteousness** describes what kind of **justice** David carried out. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [David did righteous judgment]

text: Joab son of Zeruiah was over the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the recorder;

translation_challanges.note: A **recorder** was a kind of royal official who kept records of important events and handled official documents. If your readers would not be familiar with what a recorder is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [was the royal secretary] or [was in charge of the official records]

text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelech son of Abiathar were priests; Seraiah was the scribe;
Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and Pelethites; and David’s sons were priestly leaders.

translation_challanges.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [was over both the Cherethites and the Pelethites] or [commanded both the Cherethites and the Pelethites]

The **Cherethites and the Pelethites** were special groups of soldiers who served as David’s personal bodyguards and elite fighting force. If your readers would not be familiar with what these groups were, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [the royal guard and special soldiers] or [the elite bodyguards and special military units]

David’s sons were from the tribe of Judah, not Levi, and so they could not serve as priests who offered sacrifices on the altar at the sacred tent. In this context, the author is probably using the term **priests** to mean high-ranking royal officials. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 18:17](../../1ch/18/17.md) says that they were “chief officials,” suggesting that that is the meaning here. Alternate translation: [and the sons of David were chief officials]

text: Then David asked, “Is there anyone left from the house of Saul to whom I can show kindness for the sake of Jonathan?”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **house** by association to mean all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. So **the house of Saul** figuratively means all the people descended from King Saul. (This is slightly different from the uses of this phrase in [chapter 3](../03/01.md) to mean “the supporters of Saul” or “the successors of Saul.”) Alternate translation: [among the descendants of Saul]

text: And there was a servant of the house of Saul named Ziba. They summoned him to David, and the king inquired, “Are you Ziba?” “I am your servant,” he replied.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing **Ziba** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Now there was a certain servant named Ziba in Saul’s household]

Ziba is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Yes, your servant is Ziba]

Ziba is speaking of himself in the third person as **Your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [Yes, I am Ziba]

Ziba is responding to David with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Yes, I am Ziba, and I am ready to obey you]

text: So the king asked, “Is there anyone left of the house of Saul to whom I can show the kindness of God?” Ziba answered, “There is still Jonathan’s son, who is lame in both feet.”

translation_challanges.note: Here the masculine term **a man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [a person] or [anyone]

David is using the possessive form **the covenant faithfulness of God** to mean the covenant faithfulness that he will show to such a person because of the oath he swore to God. He does not mean God’s own covenant faithfulness. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the covenant faithfulness that I swore to God I would do]

text: “Where is he?” replied the king. And Ziba said, “Indeed, he is in Lo-debar at the house of Machir son of Ammiel.”

translation_challanges.note: Ziba is using the term **behold** to focus his listeners’ attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [I will tell you]

text: So King David had him brought from the house of Machir son of Ammiel in Lo-debar.
And when Mephibosheth son of Jonathan, the son of Saul, came to David, he fell facedown in reverence. Then David said, “Mephibosheth!” “I am your servant,” he replied.

translation_challanges.note: Be sure that it is clear in your translation that Mephibosheth did not fall down accidentally. He knelt down in front of David, pressing his face to the ground and stretching himself out completely, as a gesture to honor David. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he knelt down and pressed his face to the ground in front of David, stretching himself out completely, to show David great honor]

Mephibosheth is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [Behold me]

Mephibosheth is responding to David with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. The meaning here is the same as for the expression “Behold me” in [1:7](../01/07.md). See how you translated that expression there.

text: “Do not be afraid,” said David, “for surely I will show you kindness for the sake of your father Jonathan. I will restore to you all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Doing, I will do covenant faithfulness with you for the sake of Jonathan your father, so do not fear]

David is repeating forms of the verb **do** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly do]

In this verse, the word **field** is singular in form, but it refers to all of Saul’s agricultural lands. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “field.” Alternate translation: [the fields of] or [the lands of]
Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Saul was actually the father of the father of Mephibosheth. Alternate translation: [Saul your grandfather]

David is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food] or [meals]

David is using the term **table** to represent eating meals as part of his household. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with the rest of my household]

text: Mephibosheth bowed down and said, “What is your servant, that you should show regard for a dead dog like me?”

translation_challanges.note: Mephibosheth is using the question form to express humility and to emphasize that he does not deserve such kindness. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Your servant is not anyone important, that you should turn to a dead dog that is like me!]

Mephibosheth is speaking as if David would physically **turn** toward him. In this context, **turn to** represents “show regard for” or “show kindness to.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that you should show any regard for]

Mephibosheth is speaking as if he were actually a **dead dog**. In this culture, dogs were wild, and they were considered dirty and regarded with contempt. Moreover, a **dead dog** would be powerless. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 24:14](../../1sa/24/14.md). Alternate translation: [someone like me who is powerless and whom people regard with contempt]

text: Then the king summoned Saul’s servant Ziba and said to him, “I have given to your master’s grandson all that belonged to Saul and to all his house.

translation_challanges.note: While the author refers to Ziba as a **young man** who belonged to Saul, in this context he is using that term to mean “servant,” which is what he calls Ziba in the rest of this chapter. Since Ziba had many grown sons, he was not physically a “young man.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use the term “servant” here. Alternate translation: [the servant of Saul]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:1](../09/01.md). Alternate translation: [his family]

Mephibosheth was actually the son of the son of Ziba’s master. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship that would be appropriate to use here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [to the grandson of]

text: You and your sons and servants are to work the ground for him and bring in the harvest, so that your master’s grandson may have food to eat. But Mephibosheth, your master’s grandson, is always to eat at my table.” Now Ziba had fifteen sons and twenty servants.

translation_challanges.note: The word **you** is singular here because David is addressing Ziba directly. However, the context makes clear that David is commanding Ziba’s sons and servants to be involved in these actions as well. It may be more appropriate to use a plural form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction.
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md). Alternate translation: [food … meals]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md).

Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand something that happens later in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

text: And Ziba said to the king, “Your servant will do all that my lord the king has commanded.” So Mephibosheth ate at David’s table like one of the king’s own sons.

translation_challanges.note: Ziba is speaking about David respectfully and about himself humbly in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate his reference to David in the second person and his reference to himself in the first person. Alternate translation: [you, my lord the king, command me, your servant, thus shall I do]

Ziba is using a verb form that describes action in the present. The implication is that he will do not just what David has commanded him on this occasion but also anything further that David might command him in the future regarding Mephibosheth. Use an appropriate verb form in your language to convey this sense.

The author is quoting David’s words directly, perhaps to show that his command was carried out. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [at his table]

text: And Mephibosheth had a young son named Mica, and all who dwelt in the house of Ziba were servants of Mephibosheth.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **the dwelling of the house** means the people who lived in Ziba’s house, that is, the members of his household. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the members of the household of]

text: So Mephibosheth lived in Jerusalem, because he always ate at the king’s table, and he was lame in both feet.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since Mephibosheth was continually eating at the table of the king, he dwelled in Jerusalem]

Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand something that happens later in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

text: Some time later, the king of the Ammonites died and was succeeded by his son Hanun.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.
See how you translated the similar expression in [8:12](../08/12.md). Alternate translation: [the Ammonites]

text: And David said, “I will show kindness to Hanun son of Nahash, just as his father showed kindness to me.” So David sent some of his servants to console Hanun concerning his father. But when they arrived in the land of the Ammonites,

translation_challanges.note: In this instance, the author is using the term **said** to introduce what David was thinking or saying to himself. David did not necessarily say this out loud to anyone. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing what people say to themselves or think. Alternate translation: [And David thought]

The author presents David’s thoughts as a direct quotation. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [And David decided that he should do kindness with Hanun the son of Nahash, just as his father had done kindness with him]

Here, the **hand** of David’s servants represents their agency in acting with David’s authority as his representatives. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David sent some of his servants as his representatives]

text: the princes of the Ammonites said to Hanun their lord, “Just because David has sent you comforters, do you really believe he is showing respect for your father? Has not David instead sent his servants to explore the city, spy it out, and overthrow it?”

translation_challanges.note: The advisors are using the question form to deny emphatically that David was honoring Hanun’s father. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not believe that David is honoring your father by sending consolers to you!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [In your opinion]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since David has sent consolers to you, is he honoring your father]

The advisors are using the question form to strongly assert that David sent his servants for a different reason, to explore, spy on, and overthrow the city. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [No, David has sent his servants to you in order to explore the city and to spy on it and to overthrow it!]

The terms **explore the city** and **spy on it** mean similar things. The commanders are using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [to investigate the city thoroughly]

The advisors are using one group of people who would be involved in the **overthrow** of their city, the messengers whom they believe to be spies, to represent everyone who would be involved. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [so that he can lead the Israelite army to overthrow it]

text: So Hanun took David’s servants, shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their garments at the hips, and sent them away.

translation_challanges.note: Shaving half of the beards of these men and cutting their garments in the middle was a symbolic action by which the Ammonite king sought to humiliate David’s messengers. (See the further discussion in the Introduction to this chapter.) If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he humiliated them by shaving half of their beard and cutting their garments in the middle, to their buttocks]

In this verse, the word **beard** is singular in form, but it refers to all of the beards of David’s servants. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “beard.” Alternate translation: [their beards]

text: When this was reported to David, he sent messengers to meet the men, since they had been thoroughly humiliated. The king told them, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return.”

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Someone declared to David] or [David was told]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [and since the men were greatly humiliated, he sent to meet them]

The expression **were greatly humiliated** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [this had greatly humiliated the men]

The author is saying **the king** to mean his messengers, who were speaking on his behalf. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the king’s messengers told them]

text: When the Ammonites realized that they had become a stench to David, they hired twenty thousand Aramean foot soldiers from Beth-rehob and Zoba, as well as a thousand men from the king of Maacah and twelve thousand men from Tob.

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking as if the Ammonites had made themselves smell so bad that they were offensive to David. He is using this image to mean that the Ammonites had provoked David. Your language may have a comparable image that you could use in your translation. You could also use plain language. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 13:4](../../1sa/13/04.md). Alternate translation: [they had incensed David] or [they had provoked David]

The author is using the names of each of these kingdoms to represent soldiers from those kingdoms. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [20,000 footsoldiers from Aram of Beth-Rehob and Aram of Zoba, 1,000 men of the king of Maacah, and 12,000 men of Tob]

The author is not referring to a specific **man of Tob**. He means men from Tob in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and men from Tob]

text: On hearing this, David sent Joab and the entire army of mighty men.

translation_challanges.note: The expressions **all of the army** and **the mighty** mean similar things. The author is using the two expressions together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [all of the valiant warriors]

The author is using the adjective **mighty** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. In context, he seems to mean regular army soldiers who were experienced in warfare, as opposed to other men capable of fighting who would be summoned when large armies were needed. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the elite soldiers]

text: The Ammonites marched out and arrayed themselves for battle at the entrance of the city gate, while the Arameans of Zobah and Rehob and the men of Tob and Maacah were by themselves in the open country.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using one central location in the city wall, **the entrance of the gate**, to represent the entire wall, which served as a defensive support for the Ammonite battle line. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of the city wall]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:6](../10/06.md). Alternate translation: [and the men from Tob]

text: When Joab saw the battle lines before him and behind him, he selected some of the best men of Israel and arrayed them against the Arameans.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **the faces of the battle** represents the battle lines that the enemy armies had drawn up in order to fight the Israelites. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [there were battle fronts ahead of him and behind him]

The author is using the adjective **chosen** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the chosen troops]

The expression **chosen** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the select troops] or [the elite troops]

text: And he placed the rest of the troops under the command of his brother Abishai, who arrayed them against the Ammonites.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the army]

Here, **hand** represents control. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [under the control of] or [under the command of]
The pronoun **he** refers to Abishai. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and Abishai arrayed {them}]

text: “If the Arameans are too strong for me,” said Joab, “then you will come to my rescue. And if the Ammonites are too strong for you, then I will come to your rescue.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Joab. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Joab said]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [then you shall come and save me]

text: Be strong and let us fight bravely for our people and for the cities of our God. May the LORD do what is good in His sight.”

translation_challanges.note: Here, **the cities of our God** represents the cities of Israel, where the true God was worshiped. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [our Israelite cities]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [as he sees fit] or [what he considers to be right]

text: So Joab and his troops advanced to fight the Arameans, who fled before him.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using one part of Joab, his **face**, to represent all of him in the act of leading an attack against the Arameans. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from him as he led the attack]

text: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, they too fled before Abishai, and they entered the city. So Joab returned from fighting against the Ammonites and came to Jerusalem.
