translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [from Abishai as he led the attack]

text: When the Arameans saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they regrouped.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the name of this people group, **Aram**, to represent the soldiers of its army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the Arameans saw that they had been struck]

Here, **struck** represents “defeated.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [it had been defeated] or [they had been defeated]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [as it opposed Israel] or [as they opposed Israel]

The expression **it had been struck** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the Israelites had defeated them in battle]

text: Hadadezer sent messengers to bring more Arameans from beyond the Euphrates, and they came to Helam with Shobach the commander of Hadadezer’s army leading them.

translation_challanges.note: The author is referring to the Euphrates River, which was the most important river in this region and so was sometimes simply called **the River**. You could use your language’s name for this river if that would be helpful to your readers. See how you translated the similar expression in [8:3](../08/03.md). Alternate translation: [the Euphrates River]

This expression depicts Shobach as being in front of this combined army, and the author is using that position to represent his leadership of the army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [was leading them] or [was commanding them]

text: When this was reported to David, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan, and went to Helam. Then the Arameans arrayed themselves against David and fought against him.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **it was declared to David** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Someone declared to David]

The author is using the name **Israel** to represent the soldiers of the Israelite army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the whole Israelite army]

text: But the Arameans fled before Israel, and David killed seven hundred charioteers and forty thousand foot soldiers. He also struck down Shobach the commander of their army, who died there.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [10:14](../10/14.md). Alternate translation: [from the Israelites as they attacked]

The author is using one person who was involved in this action of the Israelite army, **David**, to represent the entire army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and David’s army killed] or [and David’s forces defeated]

The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 19:18](../../1ch/19/18.md) reads “footsoldiers” instead of **horsemen**. So does the Septuagint, an ancient Greek translation. (It is possible that here in 2 Samuel and in that passage in 1 Chronicles the biblical author is mentioning one kind of soldier in order to mean soldiers in general. The UST models one way to express that meaning, which would be the same in both cases.) If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

The pronoun **he** refers to David and his soldiers in the first instance, and it refers to Shobach in the second instance. The pronoun **his** refers to Hadadezer. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And David and his soldiers struck Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, and Shobach died there]

text: When all the kings who were subject to Hadadezer saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they made peace with Israel and became subject to them. So the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites anymore.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [10:15](../10/15.md). Alternate translation: [the Israelites had defeated them in battle]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [and they asked to have peaceful relations with Israel]

text: In the spring, at the time when kings march out to war, David sent out Joab and his servants with the whole army of Israel. They destroyed the Ammonites and besieged Rabbah, but David remained in Jerusalem.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

Here, **at the return of the year** was a common expression that referred to the beginning of a new year. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [at the start of the next year]

The people in this culture considered that a new year began in the spring, when they could once again start the cycle of planting and harvesting crops. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [in the spring]

The author says **going out** as a common expression that meant “going to war.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:25](../03/25.md). Alternate translation: [in the season when kings go to war]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: [the Ammonites]

text: One evening David got up from his bed and strolled around on the roof of the palace. And from the roof he saw a woman bathing—a very beautiful woman.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new development in this episode. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

This culture considered the **evening** to begin once the day had become cooler. Some cultures would describe that time as “late afternoon” rather than evening. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe what the author means here. Alternate translation: [after the hottest part of the day]
Since David is the subject of this sentence, it may be more natural in your language to refer to his **house** or palace with a pronoun. Alternate translation: [his house] or [his palace]

text: So David sent and inquired about the woman, and he was told, “This is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam and the wife of Uriah the Hittite.”

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **sent and inquired** expresses a single idea. The word **inquired** tells for what purpose David **sent** someone. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And David sent to inquire]
Here the author is using **one** in a general sense, not to refer to a specific person. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And he was told]

The messenger is using the question form to give information to David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [The woman is Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite.]

text: Then David sent messengers to get her, and when she came to him, he slept with her. (Now she had just purified herself from her uncleanness.) Then she returned home.

translation_challanges.note: The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lay with her**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and he slept with her]

The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. He is explaining that Bathsheba had been washing herself in order to restore ceremonial cleanness at the end of the seven-day period of uncleanness that followed her monthly period. This meant that she was at the time in her monthly cycle when she could conceive a child when David had sexual relations with her. In your translation, introduce this background information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

text: And the woman conceived and sent word to David, saying, “I am pregnant.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using Bathsheba (referring to her with the pronoun **she**) to represent the person she **sent** to give this message to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and the person she sent said on her behalf]

text: At this, David sent orders to Joab: “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” So Joab sent him to David.

translation_challanges.note: It may be natural in your language to use a term such as “saying” to introduce the direct quotation that follows this phrase.

text: When Uriah came to him, David asked how Joab and the troops were doing and how the war was going.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the army]

The author is speaking of **the war** as if it were a living thing that could experience **welfare** or well-being. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and about whether the Israelites were winning the war]

text: Then he said to Uriah, “Go down to your house and wash your feet.” So Uriah left the palace, and a gift from the king followed him.

translation_challanges.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, David is marking travel for change in elevation. His palace was on the highest mountain in Jerusalem, so Uriah would have to go **down** from there to get to his **house**. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Go]

In this culture, people wore sandals or went barefoot, and so their feet became dirty during work and travel. They would wash their feet when they returned home for the day and intended to do no further work or traveling. When David tells Uriah **wash your feet**, the implication is that he should consider himself to be finished with his military mission of bringing news from the battlefield. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and consider yourself to be off duty]

The author is speaking of **a gift** as if it were a living thing that could have gone out from the palace on its own. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the king sent messengers with a gift]

The implication is that this **gift** was special food that David had told someone to prepare. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and a choice portion of food]

text: But Uriah slept at the door of the palace with all his master’s servants; he did not go down to his house.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information that Uriah did not go to his house as David told him to do before the new information about what he did instead. Alternate translation: [But Uriah did not go down to his house. Instead, lay down at the entrance of the house of the king with all of the servants of his master]

text: And David was told, “Uriah did not go home.” “Haven’t you just arrived from a journey?” David asked Uriah. “Why didn’t you go home?”

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And someone declared to David] or [And David was told]

David is using the question form for emphasis, to express his disapproval of Uriah not going to his house. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [You are coming from a journey! You should have gone down to your house!]

text: Uriah answered, “The ark and Israel and Judah are dwelling in tents, and my master Joab and his soldiers are camped in the open field. How can I go to my house to eat and drink and sleep with my wife? As surely as you live, and as your soul lives, I will not do such a thing!”

translation_challanges.note: Uriah is using **the face of the field** as a common expression of his culture to mean “the surface of the field.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [on the bare earth] or [on the surface of the ground]

Uriah is not referring to a specific **field**. He means open ground in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the ground]

Uriah is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **to lie with my wife**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and to sleep with my wife]

Uriah is using the question form for emphasis, to express his strong conviction that he should not go to his house. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [So I myself should not go to my house to eat and to drink and to lie with my wife!]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [And shall I, for my part, go]

Following the custom of his culture, Uriah is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. In your translation, express this in such a way that your readers will recognize it as an oath. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [I swear by your life, the life of your soul] or [As you live and breathe]

The terms **life** and **life of your soul** mean similar things. Uriah is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [I swear by your very life]

text: “Stay here one more day,” David said to Uriah, “and tomorrow I will send you back.” So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
Then David invited Uriah to eat and drink with him, and he got Uriah drunk. And in the evening Uriah went out to lie down on his cot with his master’s servants, but he did not go home.

translation_challanges.note: The pronouns **he** refer to Uriah in the first two instances and to David in the third instance. The pronoun **his** refers to David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and Uriah ate to David’s face, and Uriah drank, and David got him drunk]

The author is speaking of David’s **face** to represent his presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in his presence] or [as his guest]

text: The next morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new development in this episode. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

The author is using the term **hand** to indicate that Uriah was the agent who delivered the letter to Joab. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [8:10](../08/10.md). Alternate translation: [and he had Uriah deliver it]

text: In the letter he wrote: “Put Uriah at the front of the fiercest battle; then withdraw from him, so that he may be struck down and killed.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [10:9](../10/09.md). Alternate translation: [the deadliest battle front]
The pronoun **them** refers to the other soldiers who were fighting with Uriah. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [and turn the other soldiers back]

The expression **will be struck** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that the Ammonites will strike him and he will die]

text: So as Joab besieged the city, he assigned Uriah to a place where he knew the strongest enemy soldiers were.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [valiant warriors]

text: And when the men of the city came out and fought against Joab, some of David’s servants fell, and Uriah the Hittite also died.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using **Joab** to represent his entire army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [against Joab’s army]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [and some of the people from the servants of David died]

By **the people**, the author means the Israelite army. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers in David’s army]

text: Joab sent to David a full account of the battle

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking as if Joab himself **declared** this to David. The author means that Joab sent a messenger to speak to David on his behalf. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And Joab sent a messenger, and that messenger declared]

text: and instructed the messenger, “When you have finished giving the king a full account of the battle,

translation_challanges.note: Joab is saying **all of the things of the battle** as a generalization. Since Joab expects that the messenger will not initially tell David that Uriah has been killed, the word **all** might not be appropriate in your language. If it would be clearer in your language, you could indicate that **all** is a generalization. Alternate translation: [a general report about the battle]

text: if the king’s anger flares, he may ask you, ‘Why did you get so close to the city to fight? Did you not realize they would shoot from atop the wall?

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [6:7](../06/07.md). Alternate translation: [the king becomes angry]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [he may ask you why we drew near to the city to fight. He may say that we should have known that they would shoot from the wall.]

Joab anticipates that David may use the question form to rebuke the army for fighting so close to the city wall. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [You should not have drawn near to the city to fight! You should have known that they would shoot from the wall!]

The word **you** is plural here because David would be addressing all of the Israelite soldiers. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [did you soldiers draw near … Did you soldiers not know]

text: Who struck Abimelech son of Jerubbesheth? Was it not a woman who dropped an upper millstone on him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez? Why did you get so close to the wall?’ If he asks you this, then you are to say, ‘Your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.’”

translation_challanges.note: If, in the previous verse, you translated the first two questions that Joab suggests David might ask so that there was not a quotation within a quotation, you can continue doing that here. Alternate translation: [He may ask you who struck Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth. He may ask whether it was not a woman who threw a piece of a millstone onto him from the wall so that he died in Thebez. He may ask you why we drew near to the wall]

Joab continues to anticipate that David may use the question form to rebuke the army. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [Remember who struck Abimelech the son of Jerubbesheth! It was a woman who threw a piece of a millstone onto him from the wall, so that he died in Thebez! You should not have drawn near to the wall!]

**Jerubbesheth** is another name for the person who is called Jerubbaal in the book of Judges. (That was a second name that people gave to Gideon.) Here in this book, either the original author or later scribes did not want to reproduce the name “Baal,” since that was the name of a foreign god whom the Israelites detested. So the author or scribes replaced “baal” with “besheth,” a Hebrew word that means “shame.” We recommend that you use the name **Jerubbesheth** in your translation to reflect this. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain in a footnote that this is the same person known as Jerubbaal or Gideon in Judges.

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [then you shall tell him that his servant Uriah the Hittite is also dead]

text: So the messenger set out and reported to David all that Joab had sent him to say.
The messenger said to David, “The men overpowered us and came out against us in the field, but we drove them back to the entrance of the gate.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **that** to introduce a direct quotation from the messenger. This is a shorter version of the usual introductory phrase. More typically he would write, “And the messenger spoke to David, saying.” This shorter form suggests the haste with which the messenger gave this report, fearing that David would become angry. Your language may have a way of introducing quotations that would similarly suggest this. Some languages may not need to use any introductory term. Alternate translation: [And the messenger told David, “The men]

The messenger is using **the men became strong against us** as a common expression of his culture to mean that the Ammonites organized a force to attack the Israelites. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the men organized a force against us]

The messenger is using **we were against them** as a common expression of his culture to mean that the Israelite soldiers repulsed this attack. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but we drove them back]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:8](../10/08.md). Alternate translation: [to in front of the city wall]

text: Then the archers shot at your servants from the wall, and some of the king’s servants were killed. And your servant Uriah the Hittite is dead as well.”

translation_challanges.note: Even though the messenger is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [some of your servants]

text: Then David told the messenger, “Say this to Joab: ‘Do not let this matter upset you, for the sword devours one as well as another. Strengthen your attack against the city and demolish it.’ Encourage him with these words.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Tell Joab not to let this matter be bad in his eyes, for like this and like this the sword devours. Tell him to strengthen his battle against the city and destroy it]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since like this and like this the sword devours, may this matter not be bad in your eyes]

David is using **May this matter not be bad in your eyes** as a common expression of his culture to mean “Do not think that this matter is wrong” or “Do not be troubled about this matter.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not believe that you have done the wrong thing in this matter]

Here, **like this and like this** was a common expression that described things as uncertain and unpredictable. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the sword devours people here and there]

Here, David is speaking as if a **sword** were a living thing, such as a wild animal, that **devours** people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [soldiers die in battle here and there]

text: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband was dead, she mourned for him.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author describes Uriah as Bathsheba’s husband in two different ways. First he calls him her **man**, perhaps referring more to the personal relationship that they had. Then he calls him her **husband**, using a word that can also mean “lord,” perhaps referring more to their social status in the context of Bathsheba’s public mourning for him. If your language has different terms for this relationship with these shades of meaning, it would be appropriate to use them in your translation.

text: And when the time of mourning was over, David had her brought to his house, and she became his wife and bore him a son. But the thing that David had done was evil in the sight of the LORD.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the expression **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But the thing that David had done was bad in the judgment of Yahweh] or [But Yahweh considered that David had done an evil thing]

text: Then the LORD sent Nathan to David, and when he arrived, he said, “There were two men in a certain city, one rich and the other poor.

translation_challanges.note: To help David understand what Yahweh has sent him to say, Nathan tells David a story as if it were true. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could state that explicitly. Alternate translation: [and to help him understand what Yahweh had sent him to say, he told him a story as if it were true. He said to him]

Nathan is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [One man was rich, and the other one was poor]

text: The rich man had a great number of sheep and cattle,

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the adjective **rich** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. The ULT indicates this by adding the word **one**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [To the rich man]

text: but the poor man had nothing except one small ewe lamb that he had bought. He raised it, and it grew up with him and his children. It shared his food and drank from his cup; it slept in his arms and was like a daughter to him.

translation_challanges.note: A **ewe** is a female sheep. If your readers would not be familiar with what a ewe is, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [a young female sheep]

The author is not referring to a specific **morsel**. He means portions of food in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [scraps of food that he gave it]

text: Now a traveler came to the rich man, who refrained from taking one of his own sheep or cattle to prepare for the traveler who had come to him. Instead, he took the poor man’s lamb and prepared it for his guest.”

translation_challanges.note: Nathan uses two different terms to describe the rich man’s guest. The first term, **traveler**, simply refers to someone who is on a journey. The second term, **wayfarer**, refers in this context to a traveler whom someone has taken into his home as a guest. If your language has separate words or phrases that express these ideas, it would be appropriate to use them in your translation. Alternate translation: [a man who was on a journey … his guest]

text: David burned with anger against the man and said to Nathan: “As surely as the LORD lives, the man who did this deserves to die!

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [6:7](../06/07.md). Alternate translation: [And David became very angry with the man]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:27](../02/27.md). Alternate translation: [I swear by Yahweh]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **son of** to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, David is saying that the rich man has the characteristic of **death**, in the sense that David feels he deserves to die for what he did. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 26:16](../../1sa/26/16.md). Alternate translation: [deserves to die]

text: Because he has done this thing and has shown no pity, he must pay for the lamb four times over.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is describing one event, **he did this thing**, before describing another event that preceded it, **he did not spare**. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [because he did not spare but instead did this thing]

David is using the same term, **spare**, that Nathan used in his story. Nathan said that the rich man spared all of the animals in his flock and herd from being butchered, while David means that the rich man did not spare the poor man, that is, he had no pity on him but cruelly took his lamb and butchered it. Your language may have a term that you can use meaningfully in both places in your translation. If not, be sure that the meaning of **spare** in this verse is clear. Alternate translation: [he had no pity on the poor man]

text: Then Nathan said to David, “You are that man! This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘I anointed you king over Israel, and I delivered you from the hand of Saul.

translation_challanges.note: Nathan is speaking as if David actually were **the man** in his story. He means that David has done something just like what the man in the story did. text: I gave your master’s house to you and your master’s wives into your arms. I gave you the house of Israel and Judah, and if that was not enough, I would have given you even more.

translation_challanges.note: Nathan is continuing to speak a message from Yahweh to David. Alternate translation: [He says that he gave … and he gave … then he would have added]

The author is using the term **house** by association to mean all the people and property associated with a person. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the property and possessions of]

Yahweh is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and I gave the wives of your master into your lap]

Yahweh is referring to sexual intimacy in a polite way by using the phrase **into your lap**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and I made you the king of the people of Israel and Judah]

Here, **like them and like them** was a common expression that described unspecified things similar to ones just mentioned. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then I would have given to you even more of such things]

text: Why then have you despised the command of the LORD by doing evil in His sight? You put Uriah the Hittite to the sword and took his wife as your own. You have slain him with the sword of the Ammonites.

translation_challanges.note: Yahweh is using the question form to rebuke David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Yahweh is using **in my eyes** as a common expression of this culture to mean “in my judgment.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what I regard as evil]

If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about Uriah’s murder with the information about striking him with the sword, before the information about David taking his wife. Alternate translation: [You struck Uriah the Hittite with the sword, murdering him with the sword of the sons of Ammon, and then you took his wife for yourself as a wife]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Alternate translation: [you killed]

Here, **sword** represents warfare, since in this culture people used swords as a primary weapon of war. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [using warfare]

If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with the weapons of]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:6](../07/06.md). Alternate translation: [the Ammonites]

text: Now, therefore, the sword will never depart from your house, because you have despised Me and have taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your own.’

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Here, **house** means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. text: This is what the LORD says: ‘I will raise up adversity against you from your own house. Before your very eyes I will take your wives and give them to another, and he will lie with them in broad daylight.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **Behold me ** was a common expression that speakers used to mean that they were about to do something. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I am about to raise up]

Here, the **eyes** represent being aware or conscious of something happening. Yahweh does not necessarily mean that David will see this, but he will know about it. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [with your full awareness]

Yahweh is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lie with**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [And he will sleep with your wives]

God is speaking of the **sun** as if it were a living thing that had **eyes** and could see. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [out in the open]

text: You have acted in secret, but I will do this thing in broad daylight before all Israel.’”

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but further consideration. Alternate translation: [Indeed]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [For you, for your part, did this in secret, but I, for my part, will do]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **secret**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [secretly]
See how you translated the similar expression about the sun in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [out in the open where any Israelite can see it]

text: Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against the LORD.” “The LORD has taken away your sin,” Nathan replied. “You will not die.

translation_challanges.note: In this context, the word translated as **also** indicates a correspondence between what David has said, **I have sinned against Yahweh**, and what Yahweh has done, **taken away** his sin. Alternate translation: [you have utterly spurned]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter.
The word translated as **also** here has the same meaning as in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [consequently]

Nathan is repeating forms of the verb **die** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [will certainly die]

text: After Nathan had gone home, the LORD struck the child that Uriah’s wife had borne to David, and he became ill.

translation_challanges.note: Here, the author is speaking as Yahweh had physically **struck** a blow against this **child**. text: David pleaded with God for the boy. He fasted and went into his house and spent the night lying in sackcloth on the ground.

translation_challanges.note: Here, the author is speaking as if David had actually **sought** or looked for God somewhere. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And David entreated God]

Abstaining from food and lying on the ground were symbolic actions by which David expressed deep mourning and humility before God. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. text: The elders of his household stood beside him to help him up from the ground, but he was unwilling and would not eat anything with them.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [his household]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [took action regarding]

The author is using **bread** to represent food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [food]

text: On the seventh day the child died. But David’s servants were afraid to tell him that the child was dead, for they said, “Look, while the child was alive, we spoke to him, and he would not listen to us. So how can we tell him the child is dead? He may even harm himself.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using this phrase to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [So how can we tell him that the child has died?]

If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. text: When David saw that his servants were whispering to one another, he perceived that the child was dead. So he asked his servants, “Is the child dead?” “He is dead,” they replied.

translation_challanges.note: Getting up from the ground, washing, anointing himself, and changing his clothes were symbolic actions by which David showed that he was accepting God’s decision about his child. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [Then David showed that he accepted God’s will regarding the child by getting up from the ground, washing himself, putting olive oil on his hair and body, and changing into clean clothes]

See how you translated the similar expression in [10:2](../10/02.md). Alternate translation: [I thought]

If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe the time relationship more explicitly. Alternate translation: [At the same time, Joab was fighting]

text: Then Joab sent messengers to David to say, “I have fought against Rabbah and have captured the water supply of the city.

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking as if Joab himself **said** this to David. The author means that the messengers Joab sent said this to David on his behalf. Alternate translation: [And Joab sent messengers to David, and those messengers said on Joab’s behalf]
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:13](../12/13.md). Alternate translation: [Consequently]

text: Now, therefore, assemble the rest of the troops, lay siege to the city, and capture it. Otherwise I will capture the city, and it will be named after me.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:4](../01/04.md). Alternate translation: [the rest of the army]

Alternate translation: [otherwise, I myself will capture the city and my name will be called to it]

Alternate translation: [and it be named after me]

text: So David assembled all the troops and went to Rabbah; and he fought against it and captured it.

Then he took the crown from the head of their king. It weighed a talent of gold and was set with precious stones, and it was placed on David’s head. And David took a great amount of plunder from the city.

translation_challanges.note: A **talent** of gold weighed about 34 kilograms or 75 pounds. In your translation, you could use the ancient measurement and spell the word “talent” the way it sounds in your language. You could also use the metric measurement given in the UST or use the measurement that your language and culture customarily use. Alternatively, you could use the ancient measurement and put a modern measurement in parentheses in the text or in a footnote. The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [There was very much of it]

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new event in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. text: Then David sent word to Tamar at the palace: “Please go to the house of Amnon your brother and prepare a meal for him.”

text: So Tamar went to the house of her brother Amnon, who was lying down. She took some dough, kneaded it, made cakes in his sight, and baked them.

text: Then Amnon said to Tamar, “Bring the food into the bedroom, so that I may eat it from your hand.” Tamar took the cakes she had made and went to her brother Amnon’s bedroom.

translation_challanges.note: Amnon is not telling Tamar to **Come** somewhere. She is already in his room. He is saying **Come** to mean that he wants her to take action. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [Come on, lie with me]

Amnon is referring to having sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **lie with me**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [sleep with me]

In this context, Amnon may be using the word **sister** not to describe a kinship relationship but as a term of endearment, as in [Song of Songs 4:9](../../sng/04/09.md) and several other places in that book. Your language may have a comparable term that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [my darling]

text: “No, my brother!” she cried. “Do not violate me, for such a thing should never be done in Israel. Do not do this disgraceful thing!

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [it is not done thus in Israel, so do not humble me]

The expression **it is not done** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [people in Israel do not do thus]

Here the expression **humble me** has the sense of forcibly violating and raping a woman. You could translate the expression that way if that would be clearer for your readers. Alternate translation: [do not rape me]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **wickedness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [this wicked thing]

text: Where could I ever take my shame? And you would be like one of the fools in Israel! Please speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you.”

translation_challanges.note: Tamar is stating the pronouns **I** and **you** separately, even though the verbs translated as **would I bring** and **you would be** already include their meanings. She is doing that because she is comparing the situations that she and Amnon would each be in. If a speaker of your language would use explicit pronouns for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that Tamar is comparing these situations. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronouns explicitly. Alternate translation: [For my part … And for your part]

Tamar is using the question form to emphasize that she would be permanently disgraced if Amnon raped her. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I would not be able to bring my shame anywhere!]

Here, Tamar is speaking as if **shame** were actually something that could be carried to a different place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I could never get rid of my shame]

**And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since the king would not withhold me from you, please speak to him]

This is a double negative, consisting of the negative particle **not** and the negative word **withhold**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a positive expression to translate this. Alternate translation: [he would give me to you]

text: But Amnon refused to listen to her, and being stronger, he violated her and lay with her.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [12:18](../12/18.md). Alternate translation: [to do what she said]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:12](../13/12.md). Alternate translation: [and he raped her]

text: Then Amnon hated Tamar with such intensity that his hatred was greater than the love he previously had. “Get up!” he said to her. “Be gone!”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [13:1](../13/01.md). Alternate translation: [the sexual attraction that he had felt toward her]

While Tamar would have to **Arise** from the bed in order to **go**, Amnon seems to be saying **Arise** brusquely to tell Tamar to take action. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [Go on, get out of here]

text: “No,” she replied, “sending me away is worse than this great wrong you have already done to me!” But he refused to listen to her.

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **evil**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [this very evil action]

Tamar is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [is worse than the other]

Tamar is using the adjective **other** as a noun to mean a certain kind of action. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the other very evil action]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:14](../13/14.md). Alternate translation: [But he was not willing to do what she said]

text: Instead, he called to his attendant and said, “Throw this woman out and bolt the door behind her!”

translation_challanges.note: Amnon is using the adjective **this** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Amnon is being hostile and dismissive toward the woman he previously admired but whom he now detests because of his own guilt. Use an expression in your translation that reflects this. The UST models one way to do that.

text: So Amnon’s attendant threw her out and bolted the door behind her. Now Tamar was wearing a robe of many colors, because this is what the king’s virgin daughters wore.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about the servant forcing Tamar outside and locking the door first in the verse to connect it with Amnon’s instruction in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [So the one attending him brought her outside, and he locked the door behind her. Now a long robe was on her, for thus the virgin daughters of the king dressed in garments]

The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

It might seem that the expression **dressed in garments** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [dressed]
The pronoun **him** refers to Amnon. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the one attending Amnon]

text: And Tamar put ashes on her head and tore her robe. And putting her hand on her head, she went away crying aloud.

translation_challanges.note: Putting ashes on her head, tearing her robe, and putting her hand on her head were symbolic actions by which Tamar showed extreme grief and distress. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And Tamar showed her deep grief by putting ashes on her head, tearing her long robe, and putting her hand on her head]

The phrase **going and she cried out** expresses a single idea. The word **going** describes what she did as she **cried out**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [crying out as she went]

text: Her brother Absalom said to her, “Has your brother Amnon been with you? Be quiet for now, my sister. He is your brother. Do not take this thing to heart.” So Tamar lived as a desolate woman in the house of her brother Absalom.

translation_challanges.note: Absalom is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **been with you**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [Has Amnon your brother slept with you?]

Absalom is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Tamar should not continue to think about what happened and be upset about it. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not take this matter to heart] or [Do not dwell on this matter]

The meaning of the term **desolate** in this context is that Tamar remained unmarried because of her defilement. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and never married]

text: When King David heard all this, he was furious.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:8](../03/08.md). Alternate translation: [And he became very angry]

text: And Absalom never said a word to Amnon, either good or bad, because he hated Amnon for violating his sister Tamar.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since Absalom hated Amnon for the reason that he had humiliated Tamar his sister, Absalom did not speak with Amnon to evil or to good]

The author is referring to all of Absalom’s speech by naming two extremes, **evil** and **good**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [But Absalom did not say anything at all to Amnon about this]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:12](../13/12.md). Alternate translation: [he had raped]

text: Two years later, when Absalom’s sheepshearers were at Baal-hazor near Ephraim, he invited all the sons of the king.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the words translated **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.
Here, **days** represents “time.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [after two years’ time]

text: And he went to the king and said, “Your servant has just hired shearers. Will the king and his servants please come with me?”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

Absalom is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [I have hired shearers … with me]
In a context such as this, your language might say “come” instead of **go**, here and in the next verse Alternate translation: [May the king and his servants please come]

Even though Absalom is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, O king, and your servants]

text: “No, my son,” the king replied, “we should not all go, or we would be a burden to you.” Although Absalom urged him, he was not willing to go, but gave him his blessing.

translation_challanges.note: The king is using the word translated as **and** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives Absalom an instruction to follow so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the instruction. Alternate translation: [otherwise, we would be heavy to you]

Here, the king is speaking as if he and his sons were **heavy** objects that would weigh Absalom down. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language, as the UST does. Alternate translation: [so that we will not be a burden to you]

The pronoun **he** refers to Absalom in the first instance and to David in the next two instances. The pronoun **him** refers to David in the first instance and to Absalom in the second instance. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Then Absalom urged David, but David was not willing to go, but David blessed Absalom]

text: “If not,” said Absalom, “please let my brother Amnon go with us.” “Why should he go with you?” the king asked.

translation_challanges.note: The king is using the question form to emphasize that Amnon does not need to go with Absalom. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [There is no need for him to go with you.]

text: But Absalom urged him, so the king sent Amnon and the rest of his sons.

Now Absalom had ordered his young men, “Watch Amnon until his heart is merry with wine, and when I order you to strike Amnon down, you are to kill him. Do not be afraid. Have I not commanded you? Be courageous and valiant!”

translation_challanges.note: Here, Absalom is speaking as if to pay attention meant to **See**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Listen]

Absalom is using **good of heart with wine** as a common expression of his culture to describe Amnon beginning to become drunk from the wine he would serve. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is tipsy from the wine] or [has begun to become drunk from the wine]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and I call out to you to strike Amnon,]

Absalom is using the question form to emphasize that he himself has given this command. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [It is I myself who have commanded you.]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you were” in [5:2](../05/02.md). Alternate translation [I have commanded you personally]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **sons of** to indicate that a person has a certain characteristic. In this case, Absalom means that he wants his servants to have the characteristic of **valor**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Be courageous and be brave men]

The expressions **Be courageous** and **be sons of valor** mean similar things. Absalom is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [Be very courageous]

text: So Absalom’s young men did to Amnon just as Absalom had ordered. Then all the other sons of the king got up, and each one fled on his mule.
While they were on the way, a report reached David: “Absalom has struck down all the sons of the king; not one of them is left!”

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking of **the report** as if it were a living thing that could have come to David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and someone brought a report to David, saying]

These two phrases **Absalom has struck all of the sons of the king** and **not one of them is left** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [Absalom has killed every single one of the king’s sons]
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:9](../12/09.md). Alternate translation: [has murdered]

The expression **is left** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [remains alive]

text: Then the king stood up, tore his clothes, and lay down on the ground. And all his servants stood by with their clothes torn.

translation_challanges.note: Tearing his clothes and lying on the ground were symbolic actions by which David showed extreme grief and distress. David’s servants similarly tore their clothes to show their grief. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he showed his deep anguish by tearing his clothes and lying on the ground, and all his servants stood there, having also torn their clothes in grief]

The expression **torn of clothes** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [having torn their clothes]

text: But Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimeah, spoke up: “My lord must not think they have killed all the sons of the king, for only Amnon is dead. In fact, Absalom has planned this since the day Amnon violated his sister Tamar.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [But Jonadab, the son of Shimeah the brother of David, responded]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since Amnon alone has died, may my lord not say, ‘All of the young men, the sons of the king, have been killed.’]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [May my lord not say that all of the young men, the sons of the king, have been killed]

Even though Jonadab is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [Please do not say, my lord]

The expression **have been killed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Absalom has killed all of the young men, the sons of the king] or [All of the young men, the sons of the king, are dead]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [You see]

By saying **it was placed on the mouth of Absalom**, Jonadab is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Absalom had been talking about this. (The context suggests that he had been talking about it only to himself or perhaps a few close confidants over the previous two years, not talking about it publicly.) If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Absalom has been telling himself that he would do this]

The pronoun **his** refers to Amnon in the first instance and to Absalom in the second instance. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state these names explicitly. Alternate translation: [from the day when Amnon humbled Absalom’s sister Tamar]

text: So now, my lord the king, do not take to heart the report that all the sons of the king are dead. Only Amnon is dead.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since only Amnon has died, may my lord the king not put the matter to his heart, saying, ‘All of the sons of the king have died.’]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: [may my lord the king not be distressed about the matter]

Even though Jonadab is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [may you, my lord the king, not put]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [saying that all of the sons of the king have died]

text: Meanwhile, Absalom had fled. When the young man standing watch looked up, he saw many people coming down the road west of him, along the side of the hill. And the watchman went and reported to the king, “I see men coming from the direction of Horonaim, along the side of the hill.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture. Alternate translation: [By this time, Absalom had already escaped] or [Meanwhile, Absalom had run away]

The author is using **lifted his eyes** as a common expression of his culture to mean that this young man looked off into the distance. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 6:13](../../1sa/06/13.md). Alternate translation: [looked off into the distance]

Here and in the next two verses, the term **behold** calls attention to the information that follows. Your language may have its own way of calling attention to information that you can use in your translation.

The author is indicating a direction in the way that was customary in his culture, in which people spoke as if someone were facing in the direction of the sunrise. So **behind him** would mean in the direction of the sunset, or to the west. Your culture may have its own way of indicating directions that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [from the west]

text: So Jonadab said to the king, “Look, the sons of the king have arrived! It is just as your servant said.”

translation_challanges.note: Jonadab is speaking in the third person respectfully about David as **the king** and about himself humbly as **your servant**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the second person and the first person. Alternate translation: [your sons … I, your servant]

text: And as he finished speaking, the sons of the king came in, wailing loudly. Then the king and all his servants also wept very bitterly.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:32](../03/32.md). Alternate translation: [and they wept very loudly]

In this verse, the word **voice** is singular in form, but the author is using it to refer to the voices of all of David’s sons. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “voice.” Alternate translation: [their voices]

It might seem that the expression **wept a very great weeping** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [wept very greatly]

text: Now Absalom fled and went to Talmai son of Ammihud, the king of Geshur. But David mourned for his son every day.

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **for his son** refers to Amnon, who had been killed. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [for his son Amnon]

The author is using **all of the days** as a common expression of his culture to mean “every day” or “continually.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [day after day]

text: After Absalom had fled and gone to Geshur, he stayed there three years.
And King David longed to go to Absalom, for he had been consoled over Amnon’s death.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Then, since he was comforted concerning Amnon, that he had died, it ceased, David the king to go out against Absalom]

This could mean: (1) that David had planned to **go out against** Absalom (that is, to attack him so that he could capture and punish him), but he **ceased** to plan that. Alternate translation: [Then David the king would no longer go out against Absalom]; (2) that David longed (another possible meaning of the term translated as **ceased**) to **go out** to see Absalom. Alternate translation: [Then David the king longed to see Absalom]

The expression **he was comforted** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [he felt consolation]

text: Now Joab son of Zeruiah perceived that the king’s heart longed for Absalom.

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

Here, the **heart** represents a person’s feelings. This could mean: (1) that David felt hostile toward Absalom. That is the meaning in [Daniel 11:28](../../dan/11/28.md), the only other instance of this expression in the Bible. The rest of this chapter shows that David had to be persuaded through an elaborate ruse to allow Absalom to return to Jerusalem, and even then he would not allow him to come into his presence. Alternate translation: [that King David felt hostile toward Absalom]; (2) that David was longing to see Absalom. Many versions follow this interpretation, and you may wish to follow it if a translation of the Bible exists in your region and follows it. Alternate translation: [that King David longed to see Absalom]

text: So Joab sent to Tekoa to bring a wise woman from there. He told her, “Please pretend to be a mourner; put on clothes for mourning and do not anoint yourself with oil. Act like a woman who has mourned for the dead a long time.

translation_challanges.note: Putting on **clothes of mourning** and not anointing oneself **with oil** were symbolic actions that in ancient Israel showed grief and sorrow over someone who had died. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and act as if you are grieving by wearing dark clothes and not applying any oil to yourself]

Joab is not referring to a specific **woman**. He means any woman who had been **mourning many days**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [like a woman]

text: Then go to the king and speak these words to him.” And Joab put the words in her mouth.

translation_challanges.note: In a context such as this, your language might say “go” instead of **come**. Alternate translation: [And you shall go]

Joab is using the term **word** to represent what he is going to say by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and tell him the following]

Here, the author is speaking as if **words** were actually objects that Joab could have placed in the woman’s **mouth**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Then Joab specified what she ought to say]

text: When the woman from Tekoa went to the king, she fell facedown in homage and said, “Help me, O king!”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using a summary statement to introduce a new part of this story, which takes place in [verses 4–20](../14/04.md). Your language may have its own way of offering an introductory summary at the beginning of a new part of a story. Alternate translation: [So the Tekoite woman went to speak to the king]

Be sure that it is clear in your translation that the woman did not fall down accidentally. She knelt down in front of David, pressing her face **to the ground** as a gesture to honor him. She then **prostrated herself** or stretched out flat on the ground to show David great honor. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and she knelt on the ground in front of David, stretching herself out flat, to honor him greatly]

The woman is referring to King David by a respectful title, and she is using the customary expression of this culture to ask him to use his royal power to help her. Use a comparable title and expression from your language. Alternate translation: [Help me, Your Majesty]

text: “What troubles you?” the king asked her. “Indeed,” she said, “I am a widow, for my husband is dead.

translation_challanges.note: The king is using **What {is} to you** as a common expression of his culture to ask the woman why she needs help. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [What is the matter]

To try to convince David that he should allow Absalom to return, the woman, as instructed by Joab, tells David a story as if it were true. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could state that explicitly. Alternate translation: [And to try to convince David to allow Absalom, she told him a story as if it were true. She said to him]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. The woman is clarifying that she is not without the support of a male relative for some other reason, for example, she has not separated from a husband who is still living. Alternate translation: [Since my husband has died, I am truly a widow]
