The woman is using **a woman, a widow** as a common expression of her culture to mean “a woman who is a widow.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a woman who is a widow] or [a widow]

text: And your maidservant had two sons who were fighting in the field with no one to separate them, and one struck the other and killed him.

translation_challanges.note: The woman is speaking of herself in the third person as **your maidservant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. You could translate similar expressions in the same way throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [And to me, your maidservant]

It might seem that the expression **And the one struck him, the one** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [And one of them struck the other]

text: Now the whole clan has risen up against your maidservant and said, ‘Hand over the one who struck down his brother, that we may put him to death for the life of the brother whom he killed. Then we will cut off the heir as well!’ So they would extinguish my one remaining ember by not preserving my husband’s name or posterity on the earth.”

translation_challanges.note: The woman is using the term **behold** to call attention to what she is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the term “behold” in [1:2](../01/02.md).

The woman is using **has arisen** as a common expression of her culture to mean “has taken action.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [has taken action]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and they have told me to give them the one having struck his brother so that they can kill him for the life of his brother whom he slew, and they want to destroy the heir also]
Here, **life** represents “death.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to avenge the death of his brother]

The other members of the clan would not have spoken these words directly to the woman. Since they say **let us**, in her depiction of them, they are pausing to speak confidentially to one another. They are speaking in this way because they are betraying their real motive, which is to get the late husband’s property by killing his sole remaining **heir**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could indicate this explicitly in your translation, ending the second-level direct quotation after **he slew** and beginning a new sentence. Alternate translation: [But their real motive is to destroy the heir also]

Here, the woman is speaking as if her son were actually a **coal** that could be extinguished. She uses this image to describe her son as her family’s last remaining source of life, hope, and continuation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And they would destroy my only remaining son]

The terms **name** and **remnant** mean similar things. The woman is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [any survivors]

Here, **a name** represents “someone to carry on the family line.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [anyone to carry on his name]

The woman is using one part of the earth, **the face of the ground**, to represent the entire earth. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [alive on earth]
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:11](../11/11.md). Alternate translation: [on the surface of the ground]

text: “Go home,” the king said to the woman, “and I will give orders on your behalf.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about the king’s command with the information about the woman going home. Alternate translation: [Since I myself will command concerning you, you may go to your house]

The implication is that the king will take some action that will ensure that the woman and her son are protected. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and I myself will take care of this matter for you]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will command** already includes this meaning. He is doing that because he is making a promise to the woman. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is making a promise. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [and I promise that I will command]

text: But the woman of Tekoa said to the king, “My lord the king, may any blame be on me and on my father’s house, and may the king and his throne be guiltless.”

translation_challanges.note: The woman is actually describing a possible condition. She is saying that if there is any wrong in this situation, she and her family, not David, will be guilty and bear the responsibility. Express this possible condition in a way that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If there is any iniquity, my lord the king, then let it be on me and on the house of my father]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:29](../03/29.md). Alternate translation: [my extended family]

Even though the woman is addressing the king directly, she is speaking of him in the third person as **the king and his throne** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person, here and in similar instances throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [and may you, O king, and your throne]
Here, **throne** represents “kingdom.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and his kingdom]

text: “If anyone speaks to you,” said the king, “bring him to me, and he will not trouble you again!”

translation_challanges.note: The king is actually describing a possible condition. He is telling the woman that if anyone speaks to her about this matter, then she should bring that person to him. Express this possible condition in a way that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [If anyone speaks to you about this again, then bring him to me]

It might seem that the expression **he will not continue to touch you further** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and he will not continue to touch you] or [and he will not touch you further]

The king is using **he will not continue to touch you further** as a common expression of his culture to mean “he will not do any further harm to you.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he will not do any further harm to you]

text: “Please,” she replied, “may the king invoke the LORD your God to prevent the avenger of blood from increasing the devastation, so that my son may not be destroyed!” “As surely as the LORD lives,” he vowed, “not a hair of your son’s head will fall to the ground.”

translation_challanges.note: The woman is using **remember Yahweh your God** as a common expression of her culture to mean “swear an oath by Yahweh your God.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [May you, the king, please swear an oath by Yahweh your God]

The implication is that the woman wants the king to protect her son from the avenger of blood who is trying to kill him, since that would increase the number of people who had died. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [so that the avenger of blood will not cause any further destruction of life]

Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Then no one will destroy my son] or [Then my son will not be destroyed]

Following the custom of his culture, David is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. He is then stating the first part of a condition (“if”) but not the second part (“then”). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explicitly state the second part of this condition. Alternate translation: [I swear by Yahweh that not a single hair from your son will fall to the ground. If he suffers any harm, then may Yahweh punish me severely]

David is using one small part of the woman’s son, implicitly a single strand from his **hair**, to emphasize that he will not allow any harm to come to him at all. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the same expression in [1 Samuel 14:45](../../1sa/14/45.md). Alternate translation: [I swear that no one shall harm your son in the slightest way]

text: Then the woman said, “Please, may your servant speak a word to my lord the king?” “Speak,” he replied.

translation_challanges.note: The woman is using the term **word** to represent what she wants to say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [say something further]
This is an imperative, but it communicates permission rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates permission. Alternate translation: [You may speak]

text: The woman asked, “Why have you devised a thing like this against the people of God? When the king says this, does he not convict himself, since he has not brought back his own banished son?

translation_challanges.note: The woman is using the question form to rebuke the king mildly and indirectly. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Then you should not have devised like this against the people of God.]

Here, **the people of God** represents the Israelite people, who worshiped the one true **God**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite people]

Here, **word** represents the judgment that David pronounced by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [For as a result of giving this judgment]

The woman is not referring to a specific **guilty** person. She means guilty people in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [is like a guilty person]

The expression **his banished one** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the one he has banished]

text: For we will surely die and be like water poured out on the ground, which cannot be recovered. Yet God does not take away a life, but He devises ways that the banished one may not be cast out from Him.

translation_challanges.note: The woman is repeating forms of the verb **die** in order to intensify her expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [For we will certainly die]

The woman is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and we will die like water spilled on the ground that is not gathered]

The expressions **water spilled** and **is not gathered** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and we will die like water that someone has spilled on the ground that no one can gather up]

The point of this comparison is that just as **water spilled on the ground** cannot be **gathered** up again, so a person who dies cannot be brought back to life. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [and after that we cannot be brought back to life]

The woman is using a construction in which a verb and its object come from the same root. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of saying this. Alternate translation: [but he makes merciful arrangements]

The expressions **the banished** and **will not be banished** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so that people whom he has banished will not remain in banishment]

Here, the woman is speaking as if God had actually **banished** some people. She is referring to the way God works to restore people who have alienated themselves from him through sin and rebellion. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [to bring people back who have gone away from him]

text: Now therefore, I have come to present this matter to my lord the king because the people have made me afraid. Your servant thought, ‘I will speak to the king. Perhaps he will grant the request of his maidservant.

translation_challanges.note: The woman is using the term **word** to the case she presented by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to present my case]

The implication is that **the people** are specifically the members of the woman’s own clan. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the members of my clan]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [And I told myself that I should come and speak to you, since you might do what I requested]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:2](../10/02.md). Alternate translation: [And your maidservant said to herself] or [And your maidservant thought]

The woman is using the term **word** to represent what she planned to say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what his female servant asks] or [what I ask]

Here and in the next verse, the woman describes herself as a **female servant**, using a different term than the one she had been using, which the ULT translates as “maidservant.” This term refers to a higher-ranking member of the household whose master might feel some sense of obligation toward her. If your language and culture have different terms for female servants of different rank, use the term for a female servant of higher rank here and in the next verse.

text: For the king will hear and deliver his maidservant from the hand of the man who would cut off both me and my son from God’s inheritance.’

translation_challanges.note: If you decided in the previous verse to translate what the woman claims she said to herself so that there would not be a quotation within a quotation, you can continue to do that here.
See how you translated the similar expression in [12:18](../12/18.md). Alternate translation: [will agree]

Here, **palm**, equivalent to “hand” in other contexts, represents the power and capability of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the power of the man]

The woman is speaking of the people of Israel as if they were something that Yahweh had inherited as a lasting possession. She is referring to the Israelites as the people who belong to Yahweh perpetually. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 10:1](../../1sa/10/01.md). Alternate translation: [from living among the people of Israel]

text: And now your servant says, ‘May the word of my lord the king bring me rest, for my lord the king is able to discern good and evil, just like the angel of God. May the LORD your God be with you.’”

translation_challanges.note: Some versions end the second-level quotation after **rest**. Alternate translation: [Then your maidservant said, ‘Now the word of my lord the king will be for rest.’ For like an angel of God, so {is} my lord the king, to understand good and evil]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since my lord the king is like an angel of God, to understand good and evil, now the word of my lord the king will be for rest]

The woman is using the term **word** to represent what the king would say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what my lord the king tells me will be for rest]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **rest**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [will restore me to a restful situation]

Since the woman has already referred to David as **my lord the king** once in this sentence, it may be more natural in your language to use a pronoun in this second instance. Alternate translation: [so is he]

The woman is asking God to bless King David. In your translation, use a form that people would recognize as a blessing in your language. You could express this as a prayer if that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh your God will continue to guide and support you]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [And may Yahweh your God help you]

text: Then the king said to the woman, “I am going to ask you something; do not conceal it from me!” “Let my lord the king speak,” she replied.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [And the king replied]

The woman is responding to David with a courteous expression that implies that she will answer truthfully. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Ask whatever you want, and I will tell you the truth]

text: So the king asked, “Is the hand of Joab behind all this?” The woman answered, “As surely as you live, my lord the king, no one can turn to the right or to the left from anything that my lord the king says. Yes, your servant Joab is the one who gave me orders; he told your maidservant exactly what to say.

translation_challanges.note: The king is using **the hand of Joab** to represent Joab himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Is Joab with you in all this]
See how you translated the similar expression in [14:18](../14/18.md). Alternate translation: [And the woman responded]

Following the custom of her culture, the woman is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. She is then stating the first part of a condition (“if”) but not the second part (“then”). Use a natural way in your language to express an oath. In a context such as this, it may be natural to express just the first part of the condition as a negative statement. Alternate translation: [I swear by the life of your soul, my lord the king, that there is no turning to the right or turning to the left from all that my lord the king has spoken]

The woman is using **your soul** to represent David himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Your life]

The woman is using **turning** in two basic directions, **the right** and **the left**, to represent all directions. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [any turning away at all from anything]

Here, the woman is speaking of agreeing completely with the king’s words as if that were staying on a straight path and not **turning to the right or turning to the left**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [contradicting anything]
Here the word **For** provides not a reason but a further explanation. Alternate translation: [In fact,]

The woman is stating the pronoun **he** separately in both of these instances, even though the verbs translated as **he commanded** and **he put** already include this meaning. She is doing that to confirm Joab’s personal role in these actions. If a speaker of your language would use explicit pronouns for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that the woman is confirming Joab’s personal role. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronouns explicitly. Alternate translation: [he was the one who commanded me, and he was the one who put]

Here, the woman is speaking as if words were actually objects that could be **put** in the **mouth** of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [told your maidservant everything she should say] or [told me everything I should say]

text: Joab your servant has done this to bring about this change of affairs, but my lord has wisdom like the wisdom of the angel of God, to know everything that happens in the land.”

translation_challanges.note: The woman is speaking as if the **matter** of Absalom’s banishment were a living thing that had a **face** that Joab could **turn**, in other words, as if Joab could get it to head in a different direction. This could mean: (1) that Joab wanted to change the situation so that Absalom could come home. Alternate translation: [In order to help Absalom come home from banishment, your servant Joab sent me to speak with you]; (2) that Joab told the woman to pretend to be a widow in order to make her appeal to David for Absalom appear to be an appeal for a son of her own. Alternate translation: [So that you would not realize I was talking about Absalom, your servant Joab told me to pretend I was talking about my own situation]

The woman is making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. She could be saying: (1) that David knows what is happening in **the land**, that is, in the kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: [since you clearly know what is happening in the land]; (2) that David knows everything that is happening on earth. Alternate translation: [as if you knew everything that was happening on earth]

text: Then the king said to Joab, “I hereby grant this request. Go, bring back the young man Absalom.”

translation_challanges.note: Joab was clearly not present when the woman was speaking with David, since David had to ask her whether Joab had sent her to him. David must first have summoned Joab and then spoken to him as this verse describes. It may be appropriate in your language to reintroduce Joab as a participant in the story here. Alternate translation: [And the king summoned Joab and said to him]

text: Joab fell facedown in homage and blessed the king. “Today,” said Joab, “your servant knows that he has found favor in your eyes, my lord the king, because the king has granted his request.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [14:4](../14/04.md). Alternate translation: [And Joab bowed down all the way to the ground as a sign of deep respect]

The author does not mean that Joab gave David his blessing, since an inferior does not bless a superior. He means that Joab wished that Yahweh would bless David for agreeing that Absalom could return. In your translation, you may wish to represent what Joab may have said as a direct quotation. Alternate translation: [and he said, “May Yahweh bless you, O king!”]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [you regard me with favor]

Here, **the word** represents what Joab said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what his servant has requested] or [what I, your servant, have requested]

text: So Joab got up, went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [And Joab took action]

text: But the king added, “He may return to his house, but he must not see my face.” So Absalom returned to his own house, but he did not see the face of the king.

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

Here, **face** represents the presence of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [but he shall not come into my presence … but he did not come into the presence of the king]

text: Now there was not a man in all Israel as handsome and highly praised as Absalom. From the sole of his foot to the top of his head, he did not have a single flaw.

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. This verse describes Absalom’s outstanding physical appearance, which helps explain his popularity among the people and sets up his ability to gain followers later in the narrative. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about Absalom being a handsome man with the information about people praising him. Alternate translation: [Now there was not another man in all of Israel whom people praised as greatly as they praised Absalom for being a handsome man]

The author is referring to all of Absalom’s body by naming two extremes, **the sole of his foot** and **his pate**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [He did not have a single blemish anywhere on his body]

The author is making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [People felt that he was attractive in every part of his body]

text: And when he cut the hair of his head—he shaved it every year because his hair got so heavy—he would weigh it out to be two hundred shekels, according to the royal standard.

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the initial statement about Absalom shaving his hair with the information about him weighing his hair. Alternate translation: [At the end of years to years he would shave, because it was heavy on him, so he would shave it. And when he shaved his head and weighed the hair of his head, it weighed 200 shekels by the stone of the king]

The author is using **at the end of years to years** as a common expression of his culture to mean “at the end of each year.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [at the end of each year]

The pronoun **it** refers in the first instance to Absalom’s hair and in the second instance to his head. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [because his hair heavy on him, so he would shave his head]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [he found that it weighed 200 shekels by the stone of the king]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter for an explanation of what it might mean and for suggestions as to how you might represent it in your translation.

text: Three sons were born to Absalom, and a daughter named Tamar, who was a beautiful woman.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **were born** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And Absalom’s wife bore him three sons and one daughter]

text: Now Absalom lived in Jerusalem two years without seeing the face of the king.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using **two years, days** as a common expression of his culture to mean “two full years.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [two full years]
See how you translated the similar expression in [14:24](../14/24.md). Alternate translation: [but he did not come into the presence of the king]

text: Then he sent for Joab to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come to him. So Absalom sent a second time, but Joab still would not come.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to Joab, while the pronoun **him** refers to Absalom. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [but Joab was not willing to come to Absalom]

It might seem that the expression **Absalom sent again a second time** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [So Absalom sent for him again] or [So Absalom sent for him a second time]

text: Then Absalom said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine, and he has barley there. Go and set it on fire!” And Absalom’s servants set the field on fire.

translation_challanges.note: Absalom is using the term **See** to focus his servants’ attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

Absalom is using **to my hand** as a common expression of his culture to mean “next to mine.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is next to mine]

It might seem that the expression **burn it with fire** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it, here, in the next sentence, and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Go and burn it] or [Go and set it on fire]

Here, the author is saying **the property** to represent the barley that was growing on the property. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the barley]

text: Then Joab came to Absalom’s house and demanded, “Why did your servants set my field on fire?”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [And Joab took action]

Joab is using this expression to represent the barley on his **property**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the barley on my property]

text: “Look,” said Absalom, “I sent for you and said, ‘Come here. I want to send you to the king to ask: Why have I come back from Geshur? It would be better for me if I were still there.’ So now, let me see the king’s face, and if there is iniquity in me, let him kill me.”

translation_challanges.note: There are three levels of quotation here. The author is quoting what Absalom said (level 1). Absalom is quoting what he sent his messengers to tell Joab on his behalf (level 2). And as he quotes their message, Absalom quotes what the messengers told Joab to say to King David on his behalf (level 3). Use the appropriate punctuation in your language to mark these levels of quotation. Alternatively, you could translate this so that there is not a second-level or third-level quotation (see the Quotes within Quotes note).

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Behold, I sent to you and told you to come here so that I could send you to the king and ask him on my behalf why I had come from Geshur, since it seemed as if it would be better for me if I were still there]

Absalom is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I should not have come from Geshur!]

**And now** was an expression that speakers in this culture commonly used to introduce their main topic. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. See how you translated the same expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

Here, **the face of the king** represents “the presence of the king.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [arrange for me to come into the presence of the king]

Absalom is speaking as if iniquity were an object that was actually **in him**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but if I am guilty of a serious crime]

text: So Joab went and told the king, and David summoned Absalom, who came to him and bowed facedown before him. Then the king kissed Absalom.

translation_challanges.note: The pronoun **he** refers to King David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And King David called to Absalom]
See how you translated the similar expression in [14:4](../14/04.md). Alternate translation: [and he bowed down with his face to the ground before the king]

Kissing Absalom was a symbolic action by which David expressed reconciliation and acceptance. After years of estrangement, this gesture demonstrated that David was officially forgiving his son and restoring him to his position in the royal family. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And the king kissed Absalom, signifying that he was restoring him to his position in the royal family]

text: Some time later, Absalom provided for himself a chariot with horses and fifty men to run ahead of him.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using this expression to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

Having **50 men** run ahead of his **chariot** to clear the way and announce his coming was a symbolic action by which Absalom asserted his importance. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [and he had 50 men run ahead of his chariot to show how important he was]
Here, **to his face** represents “ahead of him.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [ahead of him]

text: He would get up early and stand beside the road leading to the city gate. Whenever anyone had a grievance to bring before the king for a decision, Absalom would call out and ask, “What city are you from?” And if he replied, “Your servant is from one of the tribes of Israel,”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using **at the hand of the way of the gate** as a common expression of his culture to mean “by the side of the road leading to the city gate.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [by the side of the road leading to the city gate]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women, here and in [verses 5](../15/05.md) and [6](../15/06.md). Alternate translation: [person]

Absalom was using a common expression of his culture to ask what city a person was from. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 30:13](../../1sa/30/13.md). Alternate translation: [What city are you from]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation, since these are not the exact words that a person would have spoken. Alternate translation: [And he would tell Absalom what tribe of Israel he came from]

The man is speaking of himself in the third person as **Your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this and similar expressions in a humble form in the first person, here and throughout the chapter. Alternate translation: [I am from one of the tribes of Israel]

text: Absalom would say, “Look, your claims are good and right, but the king has no deputy to hear you.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

Here Absalom is using plural forms of **good** and **right** where he could have used singular forms. This suggests that he is using plural forms to emphasize the validity of the person’s case. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the singular and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [your case is very good and very right]

The terms **good** and **right** mean similar things. Absalom is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [your claims are completely justified]

text: And he would add, “If only someone would appoint me judge in the land, then everyone with a grievance or dispute could come to me, and I would give him justice.”

translation_challanges.note: Absalom is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Someone should appoint me a judge in the land, that every person to whom was a dispute and a judgment would come to me, and I would do him justice!]

Here, **the land** represents “the people of the land.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [for the people of the land]

The phrase **a dispute and a judgment** expresses a single idea. The word **judgment** tells what kind of **dispute** this is. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [a dispute calling for a judgment] or [a judicial dispute]

text: Also, when anyone approached to bow down to him, Absalom would reach out his hand, take hold of him, and kiss him.

translation_challanges.note: A person would start to **prostrate himself** as a symbolic action that showed submission and honor to Absalom as a royal figure. By stopping the person from bowing down and instead embracing him and kissing him, Absalom was treating him as a friend and equal. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of these actions in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [when a man approached him to bow down before him in respect, Absalom would stop him and instead embrace him and kiss him as a friend and equal]

text: Absalom did this to all the Israelites who came to the king for justice. In this way he stole the hearts of the men of Israel.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **Israel** represents “the Israelites.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [for all the Israelites]

Here, the **heart** represents the feelings of the Israelite people. The author is speaking as if Absalom actually **stole** these feelings. He mean that Absalom used these manipulative means to get the Israelites to feel positively toward him. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Absalom manipulatively won the affections]

text: After four years had passed, Absalom said to the king, “Please let me go to Hebron to fulfill a vow I have made to the LORD.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter. Many versions read “four years,” following the reading of some ancient manuscripts. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

It might seem that the expression **my vow that I vowed to Yahweh** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [the vow that I made to Yahweh]

text: For your servant made a vow while dwelling in Geshur of Aram, saying: ‘If indeed the LORD brings me back to Jerusalem, I will worship the LORD in Hebron.’”

translation_challanges.note: Absalom is repeating forms of the verb **brings** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [If Yahweh indeed brings me back]

text: “Go in peace,” said the king. So Absalom got up and went to Hebron.

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [Go with my blessing] or [Go undisturbed]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [So he took action]

text: Then Absalom sent spies throughout the tribes of Israel with this message: “When you hear the sound of the horn, you are to say, ‘Absalom reigns in Hebron!’”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [then you shall shout out that Absalom reigns in Hebron]

text: Two hundred men from Jerusalem accompanied Absalom. They had been invited as guests and they went along innocently, for they knew nothing about the matter.

translation_challanges.note: The author is speaking of how these men lived as if they were **walking** along a path. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and proceeding innocently] or [and acting without knowing Absalom’s plans]

text: While Absalom was offering the sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel the Gilonite, David’s counselor, to come from his hometown of Giloh. So the conspiracy gained strength, and Absalom’s following kept increasing.

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that the expression **while he sacrificed the sacrifices** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [while he offered the sacrifices]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:1](../03/01.md). Alternate translation: [and more and more people joined Absalom]

text: Then a messenger came to David and reported, “The hearts of the men of Israel are with Absalom.”

translation_challanges.note: Here, **a man of Israel** represents the people of Israel in general, not a specific person. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [The heart of the people of Israel is behind Absalom]

In this verse, the word **heart** is singular in form, but it refers to all the people of Israel as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “heart.” Alternate translation: [The hearts of the people of Israel are behind Absalom]

Here, the **heart** represents people’s commitments and intentions. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [The people of Israel are now supporting Absalom]

text: And David said to all the servants with him in Jerusalem, “Arise and let us flee, or we will not escape from Absalom! We must leave quickly, or he will soon overtake us, heap disaster on us, and put the city to the sword.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since there will not be for us an escape from the face of Absalom otherwise, arise, and let us flee]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [Let us take action to flee]

David is using Absalom’s **face** to represent the murderous intent with which he regards him and his supporters. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from Absalom, who would kill us]

David is using the word translated as **lest** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives his servants an instruction to follow so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the instruction. Alternate translation: [Hurry to go! Otherwise, he will hurry and overtake us]

David is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Absalom would kill everyone in the city of Jerusalem if David and his supporters tried to resist him there. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the same expression in [1 Samuel 15:8](../../1sa/15/08.md). Alternate translation: [and kill everyone in this city]

text: The king’s servants replied, “Whatever our lord the king decides, we are your servants.”

translation_challanges.note: Since there are multiple speakers among **the servants of the king**, you could use the plural form of “my” if that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [our lord]

David’s servants are responding to him with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:7](../01/07.md). Alternate translation: [we are at your disposal]

text: Then the king set out, and his entire household followed him. But he left behind ten concubines to take care of the palace.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [12:10](../12/10.md). Alternate translation: [and all of his household]

Here, **at his feet** means that the people of David’s household were following him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [followed him]

It might seem that the expression **women, concubines** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [ten of his concubines]

text: So the king set out with all the people following him. He stopped at the last house,

translation_challanges.note: This could be the name of a place, Beth Merhak. Some interpreters suggest that it may have been the location of a pavilion on the edge of the Kidron Valley where travelers could rest before going down into and across the valley. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region and represents this as a place name, you may wish to do the same in your translation.

text: and all his servants marched past him—all the Cherethites and Pelethites, and six hundred Gittites who had followed him from Gath.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [15:2](../15/02.md). Alternate translation: [beside him]
See how you translated these names in [8:18](../08/18.md).

The author is using this phrase to describe the relationship to David of the **600 men** who gathered around him while he was fleeing from Saul. He calls them **Gittites**, meaning people from the city of Gath, because these men went with David to the city of Gath, as [1 Samuel 27:2](../../1sa/27/02.md) describes, and then returned with him to Hebron, as the author states in [2:3](../02/03.md). Alternate translation: [under his leadership]
Here, **face** represents “front.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of the king]

text: Then the king said to Ittai the Gittite, “Why should you also go with us? Go back and stay with the new king, since you are both a foreigner and an exile from your homeland.

translation_challanges.note: The author does not formally introduce **Ittai the Gittite** as a participant in the story, even though he later has an important role in it. The next verse provides some further information about him, but if it would be helpful to your readers, you could introduce him in more detail here. The UST models one way to do that.

David is using the question form to tell Ittai the Gittite not to go with him. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [You should not be going with us!]
In a context such as this, your language might say “coming” instead of **going**. Alternate translation: [are you also coming]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since you are a foreigner and you are also an exile to your place, return and dwell with the king]

text: In fact, you arrived only yesterday; should I make you wander around with us today while I do not know where I am going? Go back and take your brothers with you. May the LORD show you loving devotion and faithfulness.”

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form to express that he should not make Ittai the Gittite wander with him. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Since yesterday was your coming, today I should not make you wander with us to go, when I am going upon where I am going.]

David is using **Yesterday** as a common expression of his culture to mean “only recently” or “a little while ago.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Only recently]

The phrase **wander with us to go** expresses a single idea. The word **wander** tells in what way Itta would have to **go** with David if he accompanied him. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [shall I make you go wandering with us]

David is using **when I am going upon where I am going** as a common expression of his culture to mean “when I do not know where I am going.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when I am going I know not where] or [when I will have to go wherever I can]
David is speaking as if Ittai’s soldiers were actually his **brothers**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [your soldiers]

David is asking God to bless Ittai. In your translation, use a form that people would recognize as a blessing in your language. You might express this as a prayer, if that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh will make kindness and faithfulness be with you]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **kindness** and **faithfulness**, you could express the same ideas in other ways. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh will make people kind and loyal to you]

From the vow that Ittai makes in [verse 21](../15/21.md), it is clear that he has been kind and loyal to David, and David is wishing the same for him. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [I pray that Yahweh will make people kind and loyal to you, just as you have been to me]

text: But Ittai answered the king, “As surely as the LORD lives, and as my lord the king lives, wherever my lord the king may be, whether it means life or death, there will your servant be!”

translation_challanges.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [But Ittai responded to the king]

Following the custom of this culture, Ittai is swearing an oath and guaranteeing it by something that he holds sacred. Use a natural way in your language to express such an oath. Alternate translation: [I swear by Yahweh and by the life of my lord the king]

It might seem that the expression **where my lord the king will be there** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [where my lord the king will be]

Ittai is using **whether to death, whether to life** as a common expression of his culture to mean “whether I live or die.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [even if it costs me my life]

text: “March on then,” said David to Ittai. So Ittai the Gittite marched past with all his men and all the little ones who were with him.

translation_challanges.note: David is not telling Ittai to **go** somewhere. He is saying **go** to mean that Ittai should take action. See how you translated the similar expression in [7:23](../07/23.md). Alternate translation: [Go ahead and pass by]

The author is using the adjective **little** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. The ULT indicates this by adding the word **ones**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the children]

text: Everyone in the countryside was weeping loudly as all the people passed by. And as the king crossed the Kidron Valley, all the people also passed toward the way of the wilderness.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **the land** represents the people of the land. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And all the people of the land were weeping]

The author says **all** as an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [And people throughout the land were weeping]
Here, **face** represents “direction.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the direction of]

text: Zadok was also there, and all the Levites with him were carrying the ark of the covenant of God. And they set down the ark of God, and Abiathar offered sacrifices until all the people had passed out of the city.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **behold** to focus his listeners’ attention on what he is abo ut to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md).

The implication is that Abiathar went up onto the Mount of Olives, which was across the valley. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but Abiathar went up onto the Mount of Olives across the valley]

text: Then the king said to Zadok, “Return the ark of God to the city. If I find favor in the eyes of the LORD, He will bring me back and let me see both it and His dwelling place again.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the expression ** in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the perspective of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [If Yahweh favors me]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **habitation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the place that he inhabits]

Here, David is speaking of the sanctuary he prepared for the ark of the covenant ([6:17](../06/17.md)) as if it were actually Yahweh’s **habitation** or the place where he lived. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [his sanctuary]

text: But if He should say, ‘I do not delight in you,’ then here I am; let Him do to me whatever seems good to Him.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [But if he says that he does not delight in me]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:15](../15/15.md) and [1:7](../01/07.md). Alternate translation: [I am at his disposal]

David is using the expression **as {is} good in his eyes** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as he sees fit]

text: The king also said to Zadok the priest, “Are you not a seer? Return to the city in peace—you with your son Ahimaaz, and Abiathar with his son Jonathan.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. This could mean: (1) that David is using sight to represent attention, as in the expression “behold.” Alternate translation: [Pay attention to what I am about to say!]; (2) that David is questioning whether Zadok is a “seer” or prophet. By asking “Are you a seer?” he would mean “You are not a seer.” Alternate translation: [You have no more idea than I do of what is going to happen]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [without openly taking my side]
The pronouns **your** and **you** are plural here. David now addressing both Zadok and Abiathar. So use plural forms in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [should go with you]

text: See, I will wait at the fords of the wilderness until word comes from you to inform me.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:2](../07/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

David is identifying the Jordan River by its location in the **wilderness** east of Jerusalem. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [at the fords of the Jordan River]

David is speaking of a **word** as if it were a living thing that could come to him on its own from someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you send me word]

David is using the term **word** to represent what Zadok would say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you send me a message]

text: So Zadok and Abiathar returned the ark of God to Jerusalem and stayed there.

But David continued up the Mount of Olives, weeping as he went up. His head was covered, and he was walking barefoot. And all the people with him covered their heads and went up, weeping as they went.

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **going up and weeping** expresses a single idea. The word **weeping** tells in what way David was **going up**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way, here and at the end of the verse. Alternate translation: [going up weepingly] or [weeping as he went]

Covering his head and walking barefoot were symbolic actions by which David expressed mourning, humiliation, and distress. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he had covered his head and removed his sandals as signs of his deep sorrow]

The expression **his head was covered** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and he had covered his head]

The author is using **covered, a man his head** as a common expression of his culture to mean “each person covered his own head.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [covered their own heads]

text: Now someone told David: “Ahithophel is among the conspirators with Absalom.” So David pleaded, “O LORD, please turn the counsel of Ahithophel into foolishness!”
When David came to the summit, where he used to worship God, Hushai the Archite was there to meet him with his robe torn and dust on his head.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the word translated **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

The author is using the term **behold** to focus his listeners’ attention on an unexpected development in the story. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use for this purpose in your translation. Alternate translation: [and whom do you think he should meet but Hushai the Archite]

Tearing his robe and putting dirt on his head were symbolic actions by which Hushai was expressing deep mourning, grief, and distress. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [He had torn his robe and put dirt on his head to show his great distress]

The expression **His robe was torn** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [He had torn his robe]

text: David said to him, “If you go on with me, you will be a burden to me.

translation_challanges.note: David is speaking as if Hushai were actually a **burden** that would weigh him down. He means that Hushai would slow him down or make his situation more difficult. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you will only make things more difficult for me] or [you will not be able to help me, and you might slow me down]

text: But you can thwart the counsel of Ahithophel for me if you return to the city and say to Absalom: ‘I will be your servant, my king; in the past I was your father’s servant, but now I will be your servant.’

translation_challanges.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and address Absalom as king and tell him that you are his servant. Say that just as previously you were the servant of his father, so now you will be his servant]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

David is speaking as if Ahithophel’s advice were actually a physical object that Hushai could **break up**. He means that Hushai could prevent Absalom from accepting or following Ahithophel’s advice. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then you will be able to help me by preventing Absalom from following Ahithophel’s advice] or [then you will be able to counter Ahithophel’s advice for my benefit]

text: Will not Zadok and Abiathar the priests be there with you? Report to them everything you hear from the king’s palace.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [Zadok and Abiathar the priests will be with you there.]

David is using the term **word** to represent what Absalom or others might say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [any information that you get]
David is using the term **house** to mean an entire household living together. In this context, it would apply to Absalom’s family and officials. Alternate translation: [in the royal court]

text: Indeed, their two sons, Ahimaaz son of Zadok and Jonathan son of Abiathar, are there with them. Send them to me with everything you hear.”

translation_challanges.note: David is describing the father-son relationship between these men in the terms of his own culture. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Alternate translation: [Zadok’s son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan] or [Ahimaaz the son of Zadok and Jonathan the son of Abiathar]

The word **you** is plural in both instances. David seems to mean that Hushai, Zadok, and Abiathar should have Ahimaaz and Jonathan inform him of anything they hear. So use the plural form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction.
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:14](../11/14.md). Alternate translation: [And you shall have them come and tell me any news that you hear]

text: So David’s friend Hushai arrived in Jerusalem just as Absalom was entering the city.

translation_challanges.note: The word that the ULT translates as **And** indicates that Hushai **came** to Jerusalem around the same time as when Absalom **came** there himself. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe the time relationship more explicitly. Alternate translation: [returned to Jerusalem just as Absalom was arriving there himself]

text: When David had gone a little beyond the summit, Ziba the servant of Mephibosheth was there to meet him. He had a pair of saddled donkeys loaded with two hundred loaves of bread, a hundred clusters of raisins, a hundred summer fruits, and a skin of wine.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [15:32](../15/32.md).
See how you translated this expression in [9:9](../09/09.md), where it has a similar meaning. Alternate translation: [the servant of Mephibosheth]

The expression **saddled** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [donkeys that someone had saddled]
Here, **summer fruit** represents “figs.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and 100 bunches of figs]

text: “Why do you have these?” asked the king. Ziba replied, “The donkeys are for the king’s household to ride, the bread and summer fruit are for the young men to eat, and the wine is to refresh those who become exhausted in the wilderness.”

translation_challanges.note: David is using **What {are} these to you?** as a common expression of his culture to mean “Why have you brought these things?” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [What do you have here] or [Why have you brought these things]

Even though Ziba is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [for your house]
Ziba is using the term **house** to mean David’s household, that is, his family and servants. Alternate translation: [for the household of the king] or [for your household]

Ziba is using the adjective **faint** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [is for people who become faint in the wilderness]

text: “Where is your master’s grandson?” asked the king. And Ziba answered, “Indeed, he is staying in Jerusalem, for he has said, ‘Today, the house of Israel will restore to me the kingdom of my grandfather.’”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since he said, ‘Today, the house of Israel will return the kingdom of my father to me,’ he is staying in Jerusalem]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [the people of Israel]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:7](../09/07.md). Alternate translation: [my grandfather]

text: So the king said to Ziba, “All that belongs to Mephibosheth is now yours!” “I humbly bow before you,” said Ziba. “May I find favor in your eyes, my lord the king!”

translation_challanges.note: Ziba did **prostrate** himself as he said this. This was a symbolic action that expressed submission, respect, and gratitude to the king. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [I prostrate myself to you in submission and gratitude]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [May you regard me with favor]

text: As King David approached Bahurim, a man from the family of the house of Saul was just coming out. His name was Shimei son of Gera, and as he approached, he kept yelling out curses.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing Shimei as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [a certain man named Shimei son of Gera, who belonged to the same clan as Saul’s family, was coming out from there]

The phrase **coming out and cursing** expresses a single idea. The word **cursing** tells in what way Shimei was **coming out**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [and he was cursing as he came out]

text: He threw stones at David and at all the servants of the king, though the troops and all the mighty men were on David’s right and left.

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that the expression **stoned David with stones** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [And he hurled stones at David]

Throwing stones at David was a symbolic action by which Shimei showed contempt and rebellion against David’s authority as king. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [he contemptuously threw stones at David]

The author is using this clause to describe something that was ongoing. This provides the background for the event that he describes in the first part of the verse. Connect this clause to that event in a way that makes it clear in your language that this clause is describing something that was ongoing at the same time. Alternate translation: [even though all of the people and all of the mighty had formed a protective shield on his right and on his left]

The author is using the adjective **mighty** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the mighty warriors]

The author is referring to the area all around David by naming two directions, **on his right** and **on his left**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [were surrounding him]

text: And as he yelled curses, Shimei said, “Get out, get out, you worthless man of bloodshed!

translation_challanges.note: Shimei is repeating the verb **get out** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [Get all the way out of here]

Shimei is saying **man of** here in the same way that biblical authors and characters often use the similar expression “son of” to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, Shimei is saying that David has the characteristics of being deadly violent and wicked. The first phrase describes what David has done, and the second phrase describes what kind of person Shimei believes David to be. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. The UST models one way to do that.

The word **blood** is plural here because it refers to blood shed by violence. Your language may use the plural form of its word for blood to mean the same thing. If not, you could express the meaning in another way, here and in the next verse. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:28](../03/28.md). Alternate translation: [man of bloodshed]

text: The LORD has paid you back for all the blood of the house of Saul, in whose place you have reigned, and the LORD has delivered the kingdom into the hand of your son Absalom. See, you have come to ruin because you are a man of bloodshed!”

translation_challanges.note: Shimei is using an expression similar to the one David used in [3:29](../03/29.md) when he spoke of the blood of Abner being on the head of Joab. By saying that Yahweh has brought the blood of the house of Saul **upon** David, Shimei means that Yahweh is holding David responsible for shedding this blood and punishing him for doing that. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Yahweh is holding you responsible for all of the blood of the house of Saul that you shed]
