Shimei is using **blood** to represent death, since people bleed when they are killed violently. He is referring to the many people whom David’s soldiers killed when, in order to make David the king, they fought against soldiers loyal to Saul’s descendants. Alternate translation: [Yahweh is holding you responsible for the deaths of all of the people loyal to Saul whom your soldiers killed]

Shimei is using the term **evil** to represent what he believes are the consequences of evil actions on David’s part. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And behold you suffering the consequences of your evil actions]

Shimei is using **behold you** as a common expression of his culture to mean that one can **behold** or look at David and see that what he is saying is true. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Now look at you, suffering the consequences of your evil actions] or [It is clear that you are suffering the consequences of your evil actions]

text: Then Abishai son of Zeruiah said to the king, “Why should this dead dog curse my lord the king? Let me go over and cut off his head!”

translation_challanges.note: Abishai is using the question form for emphasis to express his outrage that Shimei would curse King David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [This dead dog should not be cursing my lord the king!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [9:5](../09/05.md). Alternate translation: [contemptible person]

Even though Abishai is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, my lord the king]

text: But the king replied, “What have I to do with you, O sons of Zeruiah? If he curses me because the LORD told him, ‘Curse David,’ who can ask, ‘Why did you do this?’”

translation_challanges.note: David is using **What to me and to you** as a common expression of his culture to say that he has nothing in common with these **sons of Zeruiah** in terms of what they want to do. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will have nothing to do with your suggestion, sons of Zeruiah!]

The word **you** is plural here because David is addressing both Abishai and Joab. Joab seems to have been nearby and supporting his brother Abishai’s suggestion. So use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

David is using the question form for emphasis to express that no one should tell Shimei that he should not curse David. He is suggesting that someone might use the question form to tell Shimei that. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for those purposes, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [If he is cursing me because Yahweh has said to him, ‘Curse David,’ then no one should tell him, ‘You should not be doing thus’!]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [because Yahweh has told him to curse me, then no one should ask him why he is doing this] or [because Yahweh has told him to curse me, then no one should tell him that he should not be doing this]

David probably does not mean to suggest that Yahweh may have said this directly to Shimei. Instead, he probably means that Yahweh may have led Shimei to do this. So even if your language could put a quotation within a quotation, you may wish not to represent this as a direct quotation. Alternate translation: [Yahweh has led him to curse me]

text: Then David said to Abishai and to all his servants, “Behold, my own son, my own flesh and blood, seeks my life. How much more, then, this Benjamite! Leave him alone and let him curse me, for the LORD has told him so.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [7:12](../07/12.md). Alternate translation: [whose actual father I am]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:8](../04/08.md). Alternate translation: [is seeking to kill me]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:11](../04/11.md). Alternate translation: [And with how much greater reason]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [that now a Benjaminite should wish that I were dead]

text: Perhaps the LORD will see my affliction and repay me with good for the cursing I receive today.”
So David and his men proceeded along the road as Shimei went along the ridge of the hill opposite him. As Shimei went, he yelled curses, threw stones, and flung dust at David.

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **walking and he cursed** expresses a single idea. The word **cursed** tells in what way Shimei was **walking**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [walking cursingly] or [cursing as he walked]
See how you translated the similar expression in [16:6](../16/06.md). Alternate translation: [and he threw stones at him]

It might seem that the expression **dusted with dust** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and he showered dirt on him]

Throwing dust on David was a symbolic action by which Shimei showed extreme disrespect and contempt for him. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he threw dirt at him to show his contempt]

text: Finally, the king and all the people with him arrived, exhausted. And there he refreshed himself.

translation_challanges.note: The implication is that David and his people arrived at the fords of the Jordan River. That was where David specified he would be going in [15:28](../15/28.md). You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [arrived at the fords of the Jordan]

text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using **the people, a man of Israel** as a common expression of his culture to refer to Israelites from various tribes. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the Israelites from various tribes who had joined him]

text: And David’s friend Hushai the Archite went to Absalom and said to him, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”

translation_challanges.note: Hushai is repeating this phrase in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If speakers of your language repeat phrases for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [May the king live forever!]

Hushai is using a courteous and deferential expression that people in this culture would use to greet and acknowledge someone as their ruler. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [Long live the king! Long live the king!] or [God save the king! God save the king!]

text: “Is this the loyalty you show your friend?” Absalom replied. “Why did you not go with your friend?”

translation_challanges.note: Absalom is using the question form to express disappointment with Hushai and to rebuke him for not being loyal to David. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [You are not showing loyalty to your friend! I would have expected you to go with him.]

text: “Not at all,” Hushai answered. “For the one chosen by the LORD, by this people, and by all the men of Israel—his I will be, and with him I will remain.

translation_challanges.note: Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [all the people of Israel]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter.

text: Furthermore, whom should I serve if not his son? As I served in your father’s presence, so also I will serve in yours.”

translation_challanges.note: If your language would not represent a number in a form such as **second**, you could represent this number in a form that your language would use, or you could use a comparable expression. Alternate translation: [And point number two] or [Furthermore]

Hushai is using the question form to emphasize that it is right and proper for him to serve Absalom, David’s son. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [it is appropriate for you, his son, to be the one before whose face I serve!]

After saying that Yahweh, the people present, and many other Israelites have chosen Absalom as king, Hushai is stating the pronoun **I**, even though its meaning is already included in the verb translated as **shall I serve**, to indicate that for his part, he will do the same thing. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that Hushai is saying that his own actions will be comparable to those of others. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [before whom shall I, for my part, serve]

Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of someone. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Is it not in the presence of his son? Just as I served in the presence of your father, thus I will be in your presence]

text: Then Absalom said to Ahithophel, “Give me counsel. What should we do?”

translation_challanges.note: The implied “you” in the imperative **Give** is plural, as the plural pronoun **yourselves** indicates. While the author says that Absalom spoke these words to Ahithophel, Absalom was evidently addressing him as chief among a group of advisors. So use a plural form of the imperative in your translation if your language marks that distinction. You may also wish to indicate more fully whom Absalom was addressing. Alternate translation: [And Absalom said to Ahithophel and his other advisors, “Give counsel for yourselves]

Absalom is using the pronoun **yourselves** because his advisors are part of the group for whose benefit this **counsel** will be given. Since the speaker, Absalom, is also part of this group, it may be natural in your language to use a first-person plural pronoun. Alternate translation: [Give counsel for us]

text: Ahithophel replied, “Sleep with your father’s concubines, whom he has left to take care of the palace. When all Israel hears that you have become a stench to your father, then the hands of all who are with you will be strengthened.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **Go in to**. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language or you could state this plainly, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Sleep with]
See how you translated the similar expression in [10:6](../10/06.md). Alternate translation: [you have incensed your father] or [you have made yourself abhorrent to your father]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [and all who are with you will become more determined]

text: So they pitched a tent for Absalom on the roof, and he slept with his father’s concubines in the sight of all Israel.

translation_challanges.note: Here, the word ** eyes** represents sight. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the sight of all of Israel]

The author says **all of Israel** as an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a different way to express the emphasis. Alternate translation: [for any Israelite to see]

text: Now in those days the advice of Ahithophel was like the consultation of the word of God. Such was the regard that both David and Absalom had for Ahithophel’s advice.

translation_challanges.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what has just happened in the story. He is accounting for why Absalom did such an outrageous thing without questioning it. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

It might seem that the expression **counsel of Ahithophel that he counseled** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [Now the counsel that Ahithophel gave]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what God would say by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what God had to say]

text: Furthermore, Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose twelve thousand men and set out tonight in pursuit of David.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [let me take action]

text: I will attack him while he is weak and weary; I will throw him into a panic, and all the people with him will flee; I will strike down only the king

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [4:1](../04/01.md). Alternate translation: [and worn out]

Ahithophel assumes that Absalom will understand that he means he will **make** David **tremble** with fear. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 13:7](../../1sa/13/07.md). Alternate translation: [and I will make him tremble with fear] or [and I will terrify him]

See how you translated the similar expression in [1:1](../01/01.md). Also see the discussion of the term “strike” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [And I will kill the king alone]

text: and bring all the people back to you as a bride returning to her husband. You seek the life of only one man; then all the people will be at peace.”

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express the same idea in another way. This could mean: (1) that all of the other people with David will be unharmed. The term “peace” would have the sense of “welfare” or “well-being.” Alternate translation: [All of the other people will be unharmed]; (2) that none of the people with David will continue fighting against Absalom once David is dead. The term “peace” would have the sense of “absence of war.” Alternate translation: [None of the other people will continue fighting against you]

text: This proposal seemed good to Absalom and all the elders of Israel.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the term **word** to represent what Ahithophel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And what Ahithophel had said]

The author is using the common expression of his culture **in the eyes of** to mean “in the judgment of” or “in the opinion of.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [seemed to Absalom and all of the elders of Israel to be the right thing to do]

text: Then Absalom said, “Summon Hushai the Archite as well, and let us hear what he too has to say.”

translation_challanges.note: Absalom is probably speaking to a servant or official while using the pronoun **us** to refer to himself and the elders of Israel. Since the addressee is probably not included, use the exclusive form of “us” if your language marks that distinction.
Here, **in his mouth** represents “what he has to say.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [what he has to say]

Absalom adds this phrase to clarify his meaning. Without it, the word **his** might apply to Ahithophel, and Absalom might mean that he wants to hear what Ahithophel says about what Hushai recommends. He is clarifying that his meaning is simply that he wants to hear what Hushai has to say. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [for his part]

text: So Hushai came to Absalom, who told him, “Ahithophel has spoken this proposal. Should we carry it out? If not, what do you say?”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could express the first part of this as an indirect quotation, since Absalom did not actually say **According to this word**. Rather, he gave Hushai a summary of what Ahithophel had said. Alternate translation: [and told him what Ahithophel had said. Then he asked, “Shall we do]

Absalom is using the term **word** to represent what Ahithophel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what he has recommended]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [tell us what you, for your part, would recommend]

text: Hushai replied, “This time the advice of Ahithophel is not sound.”

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. See how you translated the similar expression in [16:23](../16/23.md). Alternate translation: [The counsel that Ahithophel has given]

text: He continued, “You know your father and his men. They are mighty men, and as fierce as a wild bear robbed of her cubs. Moreover, your father is a man of war who will not spend the night with the troops.

translation_challanges.note: Hushai is stating the pronoun **you** separately, even though the verb translated as **you know** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to emphasize that Absalom has knowledge that should make him realize that Ahithophel has not given good advice. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing the meaning here. Alternate translation: [You know quite well that your father and his men are warriors]

Hushai is speaking as if David and his men actually had souls that were **bitter**. He means that they were easily provoked to violence. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of Judges, see how you translated the similar expression in [Judges 18:25](../../jdg/18/25.md). Alternate translation: [and prone to violence]

The expression **bereaved** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [like a she-bear whose cubs someone has taken from her]

Hushai is using this comparison to make the point that just as a **bear bereaved in the field** is enraged and aggressive, so David and his men will be as well. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [as vicious as a bear in the wild whose cubs have been taken] or [as fierce as a bear in the wild that has lost her young]

Hushai is using this possessive form to describe a **man** who is characterized by having much experience in **war**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form in that way, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [is an experienced warrior]

text: Surely by now he is hiding in a cave or some other location. If some of your troops fall first, whoever hears of it will say, ‘There has been a slaughter among the troops who follow Absalom.’

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

The author is using **one of the places** as a common expression of his culture to mean “some other such place.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [or in some other such place]

The author is using the term **fall** by association to mean that they died, since people fall down when they die. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:16](../02/16.md). Alternate translation: [when some among them die] or [when some among them are killed]

The pronoun **them** refers to the soldiers whom Ahithophel wants to lead out against David. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [when some among the soldiers whom Ahithophel wants to lead out tonight fall]

It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you state this differently. Alternate translation: [people will hear and say]

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and say that a slaughter has happened among the people who are behind Absalom]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:25](../02/25.md). Alternate translation: [the soldiers who are fighting for Absalom]

text: Then even the most valiant soldier with the heart of a lion will melt with fear, because all Israel knows that your father is a mighty man who has valiant men with him.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:7](../02/07.md). Alternate translation: [a valiant warrior … are valiant warriors]

Here, the **heart** represents a person’s courage. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [whose courage is like the courage of a lion]

The point of this comparison is that just as **a lion** has great courage, so does King David. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [whose courage is great, like the courage of a lion]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [since all of Israel knows that your father is a warrior and they who are with him are sons of valor, melting, he will melt]

Hushai is repeating forms of the verb **melt** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [he will certainly melt]

Hushai is speaking as if even the bravest warrior in Absalom’s army would actually **melt** when he heard that David’s soldiers were killing the soldiers in his army. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of Joshua, see how you translated the similar expressions in [Joshua 2:11](../../jos/02/11.md), [Joshua 5:1](../../jos/05/01.md), and [Joshua 7:5](../../jos/07/05.md). Alternate translation: [he will certainly become terrified]

text: Instead, I advise that all Israel from Dan to Beersheba—a multitude like the sand on the seashore—be gathered to you, and that you yourself lead them into battle.

translation_challanges.note: The author is repeating forms of the verb **gathered** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [all of Israel shall certainly be gathered]

The expression **being gathered … shall be gathered** uses passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you shall certainly gather all of Israel]

**Israel** represents “the soldiers of Israel.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language, here and in [verse 13](../17/13.md). Alternate translation: [you shall certainly gather all of the soldiers of Israel] or [you shall certainly gather the entire Israelite army]

Hushai is referring to all of Israel by naming cities at its northern and southern extremes, **Dan** and **Beersheba**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. See how you translated the similar expression in [3:10](../03/10.md). Alternate translation: [from throughout the country]

The point of this comparison is that just as **the sand that is by the sea** is uncountable, so would be the soldiers whom Absalom would gather. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [like the seemingly countless grains of sand that are by the sea for multitude]

By suggesting that Absalom will have too many troops to count, Hushai is making an overstatement for emphasis in order to convince Absalom to follow his advice. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how you might represent this overstatement and the ones in the next two verses in your translation.

Hushai is using one part of Absalom, his **face**, to represent Absalom himself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you personally shall go into the battle as the Israelite commander]

text: Then we will attack David wherever we find him, and we will descend on him like dew on the ground. And of all the men with him, not even one will remain.

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [where he may be found]

The expression **will be found** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [where we may find him]

The point of this comparison is that just as the **dew** that **falls upon the ground** completely covers the ground, so Absalom’s army would completely overwhelm David and his soldiers. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [just as the dew falls everywhere upon the ground]
We recommend that you represent this overstatement in your translation, like the one in the previous verse.

The expression **will be left** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [will remain]

text: If he retreats to a city, all Israel will bring ropes to that city, and we will drag it down to the valley until not even a pebble can be found there.”

translation_challanges.note: Here, David **himself** represents him and all of his forces. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [he gathers his forces]

Hushai is assuming that David would retreat into a fortified city that had been built on a hill above a valley or ravine through which water sometimes flowed. Since [16:2](../16/02.md) indicates that it was summer at this time, Hushai may not be expecting that water would be flowing. So you may wish to describe this feature without implying that there would be water in it. Alternate translation: [down into the ravine below]

Hushai is using the term **found** in a way characteristic of his language and culture to mean that such a **pebble** will not be able to **be found**, that is, it will not be there. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 9:8](../../1sa/09/08.md). Alternate translation: [not even a pebble will be there]
We recommend that you represent this overstatement in your translation, like the ones in the previous two verses.

text: Then Absalom and all the men of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai the Archite is better than that of Ahithophel.” For the LORD had purposed to thwart the good counsel of Ahithophel in order to bring disaster on Absalom.

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [This happened because]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:34](../15/34.md). Alternate translation: [to counter]

The author does not mean that it was morally **good** for Ahithophel to have recommended launching a sudden attack in order to kill David. He means that Ahithophel’s counsel would have been “good” for Absalom in the sense that it would have been more effective in defeating David. You could translate the term that way if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the counsel of Ahithophel that would have been more effective]

Since the author has already mentioned Yahweh earlier in the sentence, it may be more natural in your language to refer to him with a pronoun here. Alternate translation: [so that he could bring harm to Absalom]

text: So Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, “This is what Ahithophel has advised Absalom and the elders of Israel, and this is what I have advised.

translation_challanges.note: Since Hushai did not actually say the words **like this and like this**, if it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [Then Hushai told Zadok and Abiathar, the priests, what Ahithophel had counseled Absalom and the elders of Israel and what he himself had counseled instead]

The author is using **Like this and like this** as a common expression of his culture to mean that Hushai summarized what he and Ahithophel had said. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [In such and such a way … but in such and such a way]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [I, for my part, have counseled]

text: Now send quickly and tell David, ‘Do not spend the night at the fords of the wilderness, but be sure to cross over. Otherwise the king and all the people with him will be swallowed up.’”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:6](../02/06.md).

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [and tell him not to lodge tonight at the fords of the wilderness but instead, crossing over, to cross over, lest the king be swallowed and all of the people who are with him]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:28](../15/28.md). Alternate translation: [at the fords of the Jordan River]

Hushai is repeating forms of the verb **cross over** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [but instead certainly cross over]

Hushai is using the word translated as **lest** to introduce an outcome that he does not want to happen. Because of this, he first gives David an instruction for him and his men to follow so that this will not happen. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that avoiding this outcome is the purpose of the instruction. Alternate translation: [Otherwise, the king will be swallowed]

Here, Hushai is speaking as if King David would actually be **swallowed**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [lest the king be destroyed]

The expression **be swallowed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [lest Absalom and his army swallow up the king] or [lest Absalom and his army destroy the king]

Even though the priests’ messengers would be addressing David directly, Hushai tells them to speak of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, the king]

text: Now Jonathan and Ahimaaz were staying at En-rogel, where a servant girl would come and pass along information to them. They in turn would go and inform King David, for they dared not be seen entering the city.

translation_challanges.note: Here, the author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. This information explains how Jonathan and Ahimaaz were secretly communicating with David after he had fled from Jerusalem. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since they could not risk being seen in the city, a servant girl would bring them messages, which they would then deliver to King David]
In a context such as this, your language might say “come” instead of **go**. Alternate translation: [and a maidservant would come]
See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [and for their part, they would go]

The expression **be seen** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [they could not allow people to see them]

text: But a young man did see them and told Absalom. So the two left quickly and came to the house of a man in Bahurim. He had a well in his courtyard, and they climbed down into it.

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **haste**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [hastily]

text: Then the man’s wife took a covering, spread it over the mouth of the well, and scattered grain over it so nobody would know a thing.

translation_challanges.note: The context indicates that this **woman** was married to the man whom the author describes in the previous verse. Your language may have its own term or expression for this relationship. Alternate translation: [And his wife]

The author is using **the face of the well** as a common expression of his culture to mean “the top of the well” or “the opening of the well.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the mouth of the well]

The expression **was not known** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [so no one knew the matter]

text: When Absalom’s servants came to the woman at the house, they asked, “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” “They have crossed over the brook,” she replied. The men searched but did not find them, so they returned to Jerusalem.

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that the expression **brook of waters** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [that brook]

text: After the men had gone, Ahimaaz and Jonathan climbed up out of the well and went to inform King David, saying, “Get up and cross over the river at once, for Ahithophel has given this advice against you.”

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **And it happened** to introduce a new development in the story. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new development.

The first pronoun **they** refers to Absalom’s soldiers, while the second pronoun **they** refers to Jonathan and Ahimaaz. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [after the soldiers left that Jonathan and Ahimaaz came up]

Since Jonathan and Ahimaaz did not actually say **according to this**, but provided an actual summary, if it would be more natural in your language, you could express the first part of this as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: [And they told David what Ahithophel had counseled against him and then said, “Arise and cross over the waters in haste.”]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since according to this Ahithophel has counseled against you, arise and cross over the waters in haste]

The word **you** and the implied “you” in the imperatives **Arise** and **cross over** are plural because Jonathan and Ahimaaz mean David and all of the people who are with him. So use plural forms in your translation if your language marks that distinction.
The implication is that **the waters** refers to the Jordan River. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the Jordan River]

text: So David and all the people with him got up and crossed the Jordan. By daybreak, there was no one left who had not crossed the Jordan.

translation_challanges.note: This is a double negative, consisting of two instances of the negative word **not**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a positive expression to translate this. Alternate translation: [every one of them had crossed the Jordan]

The expression **was missing** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [they were not missing anyone]

text: When Ahithophel saw that his advice had not been followed, he saddled his donkey and set out for his house in his hometown. He put his affairs in order and hanged himself. So he died and was buried in his father’s tomb.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **was not done** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Absalom had not followed his counsel] or [Absalom had not done what he advised]

The author is using **commanded about his house** as a common expression of his culture to mean “put his affairs in order” or “arranged his household affairs.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he put his house in order]

The expression **was buried** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And his family buried him]

text: Then David went to Mahanaim, and Absalom crossed the Jordan with all the men of Israel.

translation_challanges.note: The author is saying **all of the men of Israel** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [and all of the Israelite soldiers who were supporting him]

text: Absalom had appointed Amasa over the army in place of Joab. Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra, the Ishmaelite who had married Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister of Zeruiah the mother of Joab.

translation_challanges.note: Here the author is introducing Amasa as new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation.

It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [a man named Ithra the Israelite]

The account of Amasa’s lineage in [1 Chronicles 2:17](../../1ch/02/17.md) identifies his father as “Jether the Ishmaelite.” The name Jether is simply a variant of the name Ithra, but “Ishmaelite” may have been the original reading here, since identifying Ithra as an **Israelite** would not provide information that would help readers distinguish him from other men by the same name. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.
Abigail was the sister of Zeruiah. Zeruiah was the mother of Joab. Be sure that these relationships are clear in your translation.

The author is referring to sexual relations in a polite way by using the phrase **had gone in to**. The implication, which the author is politely not stating directly, is that Ithra had not necessarily been married to Abigail. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [who had slept with Abigail, the daughter of Nahash]

text: So the Israelites and Absalom camped in the land of Gilead.
When David came to Mahanaim, he was met by Shobi son of Nahash from Rabbah of the Ammonites, Machir son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim.
They brought beds, basins, and earthen vessels, as well as wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,

translation_challanges.note: The main verb of this sentence, “brought,” occurs in the next verse. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine [17:28](../17/28.md) and [17:29](../17/29.md) into a verse bridge so that you can put the verb “brought” before the list of things that these men provided. You could also state the verb, which is implied in the context, in this verse and repeat it in the next verse. The UST models one way to do that.

Here, **vessels of the potter** represents “earthenware vessels” or “clay pots.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [earthenware vessels]

The term that the ULT translates as **roasted grain** is the same one that it translates as **roasted beans**, but the context suggests that the author is not listing the same item twice. Instead, this term describes the way in which the grain and beans were prepared.

The term **beans** describes edible seeds that typically grow in pods. A **lentil** is a kind of small, round, edible seed. If your readers would not be familiar with these foods, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and peas and small beans]

text: honey, curds, sheep, and cheese from the herd for David and his people to eat. For they said, “The people have become hungry, exhausted, and thirsty in the wilderness.”

translation_challanges.note: The word **curds** describes a soft, thickened milk product similar to yogurt. If your readers would not be familiar with what curds are, you could use the name of a similar thing that your readers would recognize, or you could use a more general term. Alternate translation: [and yogurt] or [and soured milk]
If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about thirst with the information about hunger. Alternate translation: [hungry and thirsty and weary]

text: Then David reviewed his troops and appointed over them commanders of thousands and of hundreds.

He sent out the troops, a third under Joab, a third under Joab’s brother Abishai son of Zeruiah, and a third under Ittai the Gittite. And the king said to the troops, “I will surely march out with you as well.”

translation_challanges.note: A **third** means one part out of three equal parts. Represent this in the way your language and culture characteristically would.

Here, **hand** represents the control of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly, in this case and for the same expression as applied to Abishai and Ittai. Alternate translation: [under the command of Joab]
The author is identifying **Abishai**, not **Zeruiah**, as the **brother of Joab**. Be sure that this is clear in your translation.

David is repeating forms of the verb **go out** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly go out, I too]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I will go out** already includes this meaning. He is doing that to indicate that his actions will be comparable to those of the Israelite soldiers and commanders. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is indicating that his actions will be comparable. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [And for my own part, going out, I will go out] or [And for my own part, I will certainly go out]

text: But the people pleaded, “You must not go out! For if we have to flee, they will not care about us. Even if half of us die, they will not care. But you are worth ten thousand of us. It is better now if you support us from the city.”

translation_challanges.note: The soldiers are repeating forms of the verb **flee** in order to intensify their expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [if in fact we flee]
See how you translated the similar expression in [13:20](../13/20.md). Alternate translation: [they will not be concerned about us]
A **half** means one part out of two equal parts. Represent this in the way your language and culture characteristically would.

The Septuagint (an ancient Greek translation) reads “you” instead of **now**. This reflects a difference of only one letter in Hebrew, and it gives the meaning, “For you are worth ten thousand of us.” That may have been the original reading, since it does not require the reader to supply the rest of the thought (as the traditional Hebrew text requires, “but there is only one like you”). If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

text: “I will do whatever seems best to you,” the king replied. So he stood beside the gate, while all the troops marched out by hundreds and by thousands.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [I will do as you see fit] or [I will do what you think is best]

Standing beside the gate was a symbolic action by which the king showed his support for the troops and his authority in sending them to battle. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And the king took his place beside the gate to review the troops as they marched out in their military units]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:2](../15/02.md). Alternate translation: [next to the gate]

text: Now the king had commanded Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “Treat the young man Absalom gently for my sake.” And all the people heard the king’s orders to each of the commanders regarding Absalom.

translation_challanges.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [Deal gently for my sake]

David could have referred to Absalom as “my son” rather than as **the young man**. However, by rebelling against his father, Absalom was acting in a way unworthy of a son, so David did not describe him in terms of their family relationship. So while the expression “young man” can have the sense of “son” in some contexts, it would not be appropriate to translate it that way here.

text: So David’s army marched into the field to engage Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **Israel** represents “the Israelite army.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the Israelite army]

This is a name, not a description of a forest within the territory of the tribe of Ephraim. That territory was west of the Jordan River, while the narrative makes clear that this battle was fought on the east side of the river. This forest is not mentioned elsewhere in the Bible, and it is not entirely clear how it got this name. But translate this as a name, not as a description.

text: There the people of Israel were defeated by David’s servants, and the slaughter was great that day—twenty thousand men.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in front of David’s servants, that is, opposing them in battle. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And the people of Israel were struck there in front of the servants of David] or [ And the people of Israel were struck there as they opposed the servants of David]

The expression **were struck** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the servants of David struck the people of Israel there as they opposed them]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:17](../02/17.md). Alternate translation: [And the people of Israel were defeated]

While the word **struck** in the previous sentence describes defeat, the term **striking** in this sentence describes killing. You could indicate this in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [the slaughter]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [for 20,000 Israelite soldiers were killed]

text: The battle spread over the whole countryside, and that day the forest devoured more people than the sword.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **was scattered** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the battle spread out]
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:11](../11/11.md). Alternate translation: [the surface of]

The author is speaking of this **forest** and of a **sword** as if they were living things that could have **consumed** or eaten these soldiers. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: [And more of Absalom’s soldiers died from injuries they suffered trying to flee through the forest than died from injuries they suffered from the swords that David’s soldiers used against them]; (2) Alternate translation: [And more of Absalom’s soldiers died during the fighting in the forest, which slowed them down as they were trying to flee, than died from the fighting in the open field]

Together, the terms **made more** and **to consume** expresses a single idea. The term **made more** tells to what extent the forest consumed or killed soldiers, that is, to a greater extent than the weapons opposing soldiers were using. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [And the forest consumed more of the people] or [And the forest killed more of the people]

text: Now Absalom was riding on his mule when he met the servants of David, and as the mule went under the thick branches of a large oak, Absalom’s head was caught fast in the tree. The mule under him kept going, so that he was suspended in midair.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of David’s servants. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And Absalom encountered some of the servants of David]

The author is using **was met** as a common expression of his culture to mean “happened to be.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Absalom unexpectedly found himself in the presence of the servants of David] or [And Absalom happened to come into the presence of the servants of David]

Translate this sentence the same way you did there, and connect it to the story in a way that makes it clear in your language that it is describing something that was ongoing in the background. text: And all the people throughout the tribes of Israel were arguing, “The king rescued us from the hand of our enemies and delivered us from the hand of the Philistines, but now he has fled the land because of Absalom.

text: Then King David sent this message to Zadok and Abiathar, the priests: “Say to the elders of Judah, ‘Why should you be the last to restore the king to his palace, since the talk of all Israel has reached the king at his quarters?

Alternate translation: [to bring me, the king, back to my house … to me, to my house]

David is using the question form to rebuke those who have not yet acted to bring him back. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. While this instance of the term **house** may initially mean David’s palace in Jerusalem, it seems also to represent David’s kingdom and authority. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to restore the king to his throne] or [to make David king again]

David is speaking of this **word** as if it were a living thing that could have **come** to him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [For the king has heard the word of all of Israel]

David is saying **all of Israel** as a generalization for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [For the king has learned what people throughout Israel have been saying]

This could mean: (1) that David is suggesting that Zadok and Abiathar could leave out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [that they want to return him to his house] or [that they want him to rule them again]; (2) that the **word of all of Israel** has come to David in the **house** where he is staying in Mahanaim. text: I am now eighty years old. Can I discern what is good and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats or drinks? Can I still hear the voice of singing men and women? Why should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [19:32](../19/32.md). Alternate translation: [I am 80 years old]

Barzillai is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [I no longer know between good to bad. And your servant does not taste what I eat or what I drink. And I no longer hear the voice of the male singers or the female singers. So your servant should not become a further burden to my lord the king.]

In this verse, the word **voice** is singular in form, but it refers to all the singers as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “voice.” Alternate translation: [the voices]

Barzillai is speaking as if he would actually become a **burden** or weight that David needed to carry on his back. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [So why should your servant cause my lord the king to have additional responsibilities for his care?]

text: Your servant will go with the king only a short distance past the Jordan; why should the king repay me with such a reward?

translation_challanges.note: Going across the Jordan with the king was a symbolic action by which Barzillai showed respect and honor to David, even though he would only go a short distance beyond the river. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [To show respect and honor, according to a little your servant will go across the Jordan with the king]

Barzillai is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [But the king does not need to reward me this reward]

Barzillai is using a construction in which a verb and its object come from the same root. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of saying this. Alternate translation: [reward me so generously]

text: Please let your servant return, that I may die in my own city near the tomb of my father and mother. But here is your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him what is good in your sight.”

translation_challanges.note: While Barzillai may want David to look at Chimham (who has accompanied him, and who is likely his son, as [1 Kings 2:7](../../1ki/02/07.md) suggests), he seems to be saying **behold** as part of the courteous expression that people in this culture would use to tell a superior that someone was ready and willing to obey his orders. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. See how you translated the similar expression in [1:7](../01/07.md). Alternate translation: [But now here is your servant Chimham, at your disposal]

This is an imperative, but it communicates a polite request rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates a polite request. It may be helpful to add an expression such as “please” to make this clear. Alternate translation: [and please do for him]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:19](../03/19.md). Alternate translation: [as you see fit] or [what you think is best]

text: The king replied, “Chimham will cross over with me, and I will do for him what is good in your sight, and I will do for you whatever you desire of me.”

translation_challanges.note: David is stating the pronoun **I** separately, even though the verb translated as **I shall do** already includes this meaning. He is doing that because he is making a promise to Barzillai. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for the same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that David is making a promise to Barzillai. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [and I promise that I shall do for him]

The king is using the adjective **good** as a noun to mean a certain kind of thing. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [what is good]

The king is using **choose upon me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “require of me.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And all that you require of me]

text: So all the people crossed the Jordan, and then the king crossed over. The king kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and Barzillai returned home.

translation_challanges.note: The author seems to be suggesting that first the **people** (the tribal leaders) **crossed the Jordan**, and then **the king crossed**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [And all of the people crossed the Jordan to lead the way in an honor procession, and then the king crossed]

text: Then the king crossed over to Gilgal, and Chimham crossed over with him. All the troops of Judah and half the troops of Israel escorted the king.

translation_challanges.note: The implication here and in the next verse is that these were the leaders of Judah and the leaders of the other Israelite tribes rather than all the people. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the leaders of Judah … the leaders of the other Israelite tribes]
In this context, the word **half** does not indicate exactly one of two equal parts. Alternate translation: [only some of]

text: Soon all the men of Israel came to the king and asked, “Why did our brothers, the men of Judah, take you away secretly and bring the king and his household across the Jordan, together with all of David’s men?”

translation_challanges.note: The author is saying **all of the men of Israel were coming to the king** to describe something that was ongoing. This provides the background for other events he will describe that began to happen during this time. Connect this clause to the story in a way that makes it clear in your language that this clause is describing something that was ongoing in the background. Alternate translation: [as the rest of the men of Israel continued to arrive where David was, they said to him]

The implication is that these were the leaders of the other Israelite tribes rather than all the men of Israel. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the rest of the leaders of the other Israelite tribes]

The men of Israel are using the question form to express their anger that the men of Judah had brought David back without including them. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [It was not right for our brothers, the men of Judah, to steal you away and bring the king and his house across the Jordan and all of the men of David with him!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [19:12](../19/12.md). Alternate translation: [our kinsmen]

Here, the men of Israel are speaking as if the king were an object that someone could **steal … away**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [take you away without considering us]

Even though the men of Israel are addressing David directly, they are speaking of him in the third person as **the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [you, the king]
See how you translated the similar expression in [19:18](../19/18.md). Alternate translation: [and his household] or [and your household]

Since these tribal leaders are addressing David directly, and since they call him **you** earlier in the sentence, it may be natural to use second-person pronouns here. Alternate translation: [your men with you]

text: And all the men of Judah replied to the men of Israel, “We did this because the king is our relative. Why does this anger you? Have we ever eaten at the king’s expense or received anything for ourselves?”

translation_challanges.note: In this verse, the expressions **each man** and **a man** are singular in form, but they refer to all the men of Judah and Israel as groups. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “man.” Alternate translation: [And all of the men of Judah answered to the men of Israel]

In this verse, the word **me** is singular in form, but it refers to all the men of Judah as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a plural form. Alternate translation: [Because the king is near to us]

The men of Judah are leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [We brought the king across the Jordan River because he is near to us]

Here, the men of Judah are speaking as if being related to someone were actually being **near** to that person physically. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is our close relative]

The men of Judah are using the question form to emphasize that the men of Israel should not be angry and that they have not received any favors from the king. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [And it should not be that it burns to you about this matter. Eating, we have not eaten from the king, and being taken, it has not been taken for us!]

The Judean leaders are using **And why this** as a common expression of their culture to mean “There is no need for this.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. If you have already translated the book of 1 Samuel, see how you translated the similar expression in [1 Samuel 20:8](../../1sa/20/08.md). Alternate translation: [And there is no need for it to burn to you about this matter.] or [And it should not be that it burns to you about this matter.]

Here the phrase **it burns to you** is a common expression that means that the men of Israel have become angry. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you have become angry about this matter]

The men of Judah are repeating forms of the verbs **eaten** and **taken** in order to intensify their expression of the ideas that these verbs convey. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [Have we eaten at all from the king? Or has anything at all been taken for us?] or [We certainly have not eaten from the king! And certainly nothing has been taken for us!]

The men of Judah are using **eaten from the king** as a common expression of their culture to describe receiving food or other provisions from the king. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Has the king been providing any of our food?] or [The king has not been providing any of our food!]

The expression **being taken, has it been taken** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the king has not taken anything and given it to us]

text: “We have ten shares in the king,” answered the men of Israel, “so we have more claim to David than you. Why then do you despise us? Were we not the first to speak of restoring our king?” But the men of Judah spoke more fiercely than the men of Israel.

translation_challanges.note: In this verse, the words **a man of Israel** and **a man of Judah** are singular in form, but they refer to all the men of Israel and all the men of Judah as groups. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the plural form of “man.” Alternate translation: [And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and they said]

The phrase **and he said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this phrase explicitly. Alternate translation: [And the men of Israel responded to the men of Judah]

The men of Israel are using **Ten hands {are} to me in the king** as a common expression of their culture to mean “we have ten shares in the king.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [We have ten shares in the king]

The men of Israel are leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and we also have a greater share in David than you do]

The word **you** is singular here because the author is depicting individual conversations between Israelite and Judean leaders. If you depict this scene in the same way, use the singular form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction. But if you decide to say “men” rather than **man**, use the plural form of “you.”

The men of Israel are using the question form to emphasize that the men of Judah should not have despised them and that they were the first to speak of bringing back the king. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [So you should not have despised me! It was my word that was first, to bring back my king to me!] or [ So you should not have despised us! It was our word that was first, to bring back my king to us!]

The men of Israel are using the term **word** to represent what they said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Were we not the first to say that we should bring our king back to us?]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what the men of Judah and Israel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But the leaders of Judah spoke more harshly than the leaders of Israel spoke]

text: Now a worthless man named Sheba son of Bichri, a Benjamite, happened to be there, and he blew the ram’s horn and shouted: “We have no share in David, no inheritance in Jesse’s son. Every man to his tent, O Israel!”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [18:9](../18/09.md). Alternate translation: [And a man of wickedness happened to be there]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **wickedness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [a wicked man]

Here the author is introducing **Sheba, the son of Bichri, a man of Benjamin** as a new participant in the story. Your language may have its own way of introducing new participants that you can use in your translation.

If Sheba were speaking to the Judeans with whom he and his fellow Israelites have been disputing, the word **us** would not include them, so it would be appropriate to use the exclusive form of that word if your language marks that distinction. That is one interpretive possibility. However, since he directly addresses his fellow Israelites in the next sentence, he may well also be addressing them here, in which case it would be appropriate to use the inclusive form. Decide as a translation team which interpretation you wish to follow.

These two phrases **There is no portion to us in David** and **no inheritance is to us in the son of Jesse** mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [We will have no part of David son of Jesse]

Sheba is speaking as if David were actually land or property of which the Israelites could have a **portion** that they would receive as an **inheritance**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [We want nothing to do with David son of Jesse]

Sheba is using **a man to his tent** as a common expression of his culture that often described soldiers stopping a military campaign altogether and each one going back to his home and family. In this particular context, Sheba is using the expression to mean that the soldiers from the other tribes will not obey David as their military commander. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Abandon the army and go home, Israel!]

Here, **tents** represents homes or dwelling places. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Each of you return to his own home, you Israelites]

text: So all the men of Israel deserted David to follow Sheba son of Bichri. But the men of Judah stayed by their king all the way from the Jordan to Jerusalem.

translation_challanges.note: In keeping with what is usual for his language and culture, the author is marking travel for change in elevation with **went up**. If this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [went] or [left there]

Here, the author is speaking as if people who followed either David or Sheba as their leader actually walked **after** or behind them. He means that the people stopped being loyal to David as their king and started being loyal to Sheba instead. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with Sheba, the son of Bichri, as their leader rather than David]

The author is speaking as if the men of Judah had actually **clung** to David. He means that they remained loyal to him and supported his leadership. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [remained entirely loyal]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and they escorted him from the Jordan River area to Jerusalem]

text: When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to take care of the palace, and he placed them in a house under guard. He provided for them, but he no longer slept with them. They were confined until the day of their death, living as widows.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the possessive form to describe a **house** or residence that was a place for **keeping** these women away from other people. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [in seclusion]
