translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **righteousness**, you could express the same idea in another way, here and in [verse 25](../22/25.md). Alternate translation: [according to the way I had been righteous]

David is speaking of his actions as if they were his **hands**, which could be physically clean or dirty. He means that his behavior has been morally pure. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly, here and in [verse 25](../22/25.md). Alternate translation: [According to the innocence of my actions]

David is using **he has returned to me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “he has treated me in the same way.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he has treated me in the same way]

text: For I have kept the ways of the LORD and have not wickedly departed from my God.

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. If the connection between this statement and the previous one is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. The meaning is similar in [verses 23](../22/23.md), [29](../22/29.md), [30](../22/30.md), and [32](../22/32.md). Alternate translation: [After all,]

David is speaking of how a person lives as if that were a way or path that the person was walking along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I have lived as Yahweh commands] or [I have obeyed Yahweh’s commands]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context, specifically in the next verse, if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and I have not been so wicked as to turn away from my God]

text: For all His ordinances are before me; I have not disregarded His statutes.

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation of why Yahweh has rewarded David according to his righteousness. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use a word that introduces an explanation. Alternate translation: [Indeed]

David is speaking of **judgments** as if they were objects that could be physically placed in front of him. This means that he constantly remembers and thinks about God’s laws. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I am always mindful of his judgments]

David is speaking of disobeying God’s **statutes** as if they were objects that he could physically turn away from. He is describing refusing to obey God’s commands. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I have not disobeyed his statutes]

text: And I have been blameless before Him and kept myself from iniquity.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the possessive form to mean sin that he could have committed. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [from any iniquity that I might have committed]

text: So the LORD has repaid me according to my righteousness, according to my cleanness in His sight.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **before his eyes** represents how God sees and evaluates people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in his judgment] or [by his standards]

text: To the faithful You show Yourself faithful, to the blameless You show Yourself blameless;

translation_challanges.note: Review whether you decided in [22:3](../22/03.md) to use the second person or third person consistently throughout this song, or whether you chose to use both as they appear in the original text, as shown in the ULT here by the shift from “his” in the previous verse to **you**.

David is using the adjective **faithful** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [To people who are faithful]

The phrase **mighty blameless** expresses a single idea. The word **mighty** expresses to what degree these people are **blameless**. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [the mightily blameless] or [the entirely innocent]

David is using the adjective **blameless** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [people who are mightily blameless] or [people who are entirely innocent]

text: to the pure You show Yourself pure, but to the crooked You show Yourself shrewd.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **the purified** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [those who purify themselves] or [those who keep themselves pure]

Here David is speaking of people who deliberately do what is wrong as if they were physically **crooked** or bent. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with those who do evil] or [with those who are dishonest]

text: You save an afflicted people, but Your eyes are on the haughty to bring them down.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking as if oppressed people were **lowly**, that is, in a physically low place, and as if proud people were physically **high** and Yahweh brought them **down** to a lower place. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you save people who are being oppressed, but your eyes are against proud people, you humble them]

David is using **eyes against** to represent God’s attention and opposition. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but you oppose]

text: For You, O LORD, are my lamp; the LORD lights up my darkness.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking as if Yahweh were actually a **lamp** that gives him light in his **darkness**. This image is rich in meaning. Among the meanings that come out in this context is that Yahweh helps him understand what he should do when he would otherwise be confused or uncertain. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you enable me to recognize what I should do when I could not understand that myself]

text: For in You I can charge an army; with my God I can scale a wall.

translation_challanges.note: This could mean: (1) that David is saying that by God’s help, he can pursue and overtake a **troop**. He may be recalling how he and his men were able to overtake the Amalekite “troop” ([1 Samuel 30:8](../../1sa/30/08.md)) that had raided Ziklag and rescue their families and possessions. Alternate translation: [I can pursue and overtake a raiding band]; (2) that David is saying that by God’s help, he can directly attack and disperse an opposing group of soldiers. Alternate translation: [I can run through a troop] or [I can attack and disperse an opposing troop]

David is speaking of successfully leading troops to capture a fortified city as if he and they would **leap** over its walls. He may be recalling how he and his soldiers were able to capture the stronghold of Zion in Jerusalem ([5:6–9](../05/06.md)). If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I can surmount the walls of a fortified city]

text: As for God, His way is perfect; the word of the LORD is flawless. He is a shield to all who take refuge in Him.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking of how God acts and directs others as if it were a **way** or path that he was walking along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [everything he does is faultless] or [he always acts righteously]
Here, **word of Yahweh** represents what Yahweh says by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [What Yahweh says]

The expression **is refined** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [is pure]

David is speaking as if God were actually a **shield** behind which people took **refuge**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [He protects everyone who trusts him]

text: For who is God besides the LORD? And who is the Rock except our God?

translation_challanges.note: David is using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate these questions as statements or as exclamations. Alternate translation: [For Yahweh is the only God! And our God is the only rock!]

David speaks of God here as if God were a **rock**. This means that God provides safety and protection, like a large rock that people can hide behind or stand on for safety. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [provides safety]

text: God is my strong fortress, and He makes my way clear.

translation_challanges.note: David is using the possessive form to describe a **fortress** that is characterized by **strength**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [is my strong fortress]

Here David is speaking as if God were actually a **fortress of strength**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [keeps me entirely safe]

This could mean: (1) that God makes the **way** on which a person travels **perfect**, that is, free from obstacles. Alternate translation: [and he removes all the obstacles in my path] or [and he enables me to live the life he has chosen for me without hindrance]; (2) that David is speaking of how a person lives as if that were a **way** or path that the person was walking along. Alternate translation: [and he enables me to live in just the way that he wants people to live]

text: He makes my feet like those of a deer and stations me upon the heights.

translation_challanges.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [making my feet like the feet of a deer]

Here David is comparing his ability to move quickly and surely with the way a deer moves in difficult terrain. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [making my feet secure] or [keeping me from stumbling]

David may be using this possessive form, referring to these as **my** high places, because he is recalling how he had to hide among cliffs when Saul was trying to kill him. It may be more natural in your language to express this meaning with a different form. Alternate translation: [and he keeps me from falling from any high places where I have to go]

text: He trains my hands for battle; my arms can bend a bow of bronze.

translation_challanges.note: David is using his **hands** to represent all of him in the act of fighting in battle. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [training me for war]

text: You have given me Your shield of salvation, and Your gentleness exalts me.

translation_challanges.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [And the shield you provide for me saves me]

Here David is speaking of God’s power to save him as if it were a **shield** that could protect him from physical attacks. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you protect me by saving me]

By **your answer**, David means God’s response to his prayers requesting help. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and your answer to my prayers]

text: You broaden the path beneath me so that my ankles do not give way.

translation_challanges.note: Here, David’s **step** represents the place where he would step. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [You enlarge the place where I step under me]

David is speaking as if God had made the area where he needed to walk more spacious. This represents having freedom to move and act without being constrained by enemies. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. You could also use plain language. Alternate translation: [You give me room to maneuver]

text: I pursued my enemies and destroyed them; I did not turn back until they were consumed.
I devoured and crushed them so they could not rise; they have fallen under my feet.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking of destroying his enemies as if he were a wild animal that could **devour** them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I completely destroy them]

David is describing one event before describing another event that preceded it. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened, as in the UST. Alternate translation: [and they fall under my feet and do not arise]
The implication is that David’s enemies fall and remain dead. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but they fall down dead]

text: You have armed me with strength for battle; You have subdued my foes beneath me.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking of valor as if it were a piece of clothing with which God **girds** him, like a belt or piece of armor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you make me valiant]

David means that people who try to rebel against him ultimately **bow down** as a symbolic action by which they show renewed submission to his authority. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [you make the ones rising up under me submit humbly to my authority]

David is using **the ones rising up under me** as a common expression of his culture to mean “those who rebel against my rule.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the ones revolting against my rule]

text: You have made my enemies retreat before me; I destroyed those who hated me.

translation_challanges.note: David is describing a symbolic action in which victorious soldiers would make defeated enemies lie face down on the ground and then step on their necks to demonstrate their complete triumph (as in [Joshua 10:24](../../jos/10/24.md), for example). If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express the meaning plainly in your translation. Alternate translation: [you enable me to step in complete triumph on the backs of their necks]

In this verse, the word **back** is singular in form, but it refers to all the enemies as a group. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use plural forms of “back” and “neck.” Alternate translation: [the backs of their necks]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [you give to me the ones hating me]

text: They looked, but there was no one to save them—to the LORD, but He did not answer.

translation_challanges.note: David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [they call to Yahweh]

By **he does not answer them**, David means that Yahweh does not help his enemies as they have asked. (The meaning of **answer** in this context is similar to the meaning of “listen” in [12:18](../12/18.md).) You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [but he does not do what they ask]

text: I ground them as the dust of the earth; I crushed and trampled them like mud in the streets.

translation_challanges.note: The point of this comparison is that just as the **dust of the earth** consists of tiny pieces, so, in this image, David **beat** his enemies so thoroughly that they broke into small pieces. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [And I beat them into small pieces like the dust of the earth]

David speaks here of defeating his enemies as if he had actually beaten them into small pieces. This compares his total victory over his enemies to the way that dust can be completely scattered. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I completely destroyed them] or [And I scattered them completely]

Here David is speaking of his enemies as if they were **mud** that he could crush and trample. This metaphor emphasizes his complete victory over them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I completely crushed my enemies and trampled them down] or [I utterly defeated my enemies, destroying them completely]

text: You have delivered me from the strife of my people; You have preserved me as the head of nations; a people I had not known shall serve me.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking of his leadership role as if he were the **head** of a body. Just as the head directs the rest of the body, David ruled over other nations. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as the ruler of nations] or [to govern the nations]

text: Foreigners cower before me; when they hear me, they obey me.

translation_challanges.note: David is not referring to a specific **foreigner**. He means foreigners in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Sons of foreigners]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the common expression of their culture **Sons of ** to indicate that a person has a certain characteristic. In this case, these people have the characteristic of being foreigners or people from other nations. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Foreigners]

David is using one part of a person, the **ear** to represent entire people in the act of hearing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When they hear]
David means that these people hear specifically about him. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [When they hear about me]

By **they hear me**, David means that they obey him. (The meaning of **hear** in this context is similar to the meaning of “listen” in [12:18](../12/18.md).) You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [they obey me]

text: Foreigners lose heart and come trembling from their strongholds.

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking of foreign armies as if they were plants that **fade away** and lose their vitality. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [lose strength]

In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **son of** to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, the people whom David is describing have the characteristic of being soldiers of foreign countries that are resisting his rule. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [foreign soldiers]

text: The LORD lives, and blessed be my Rock! And may God, the Rock of my salvation, be exalted—

translation_challanges.note: David is using a phrase that expresses a strong feeling, joy. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this feeling. If not, you could say what David was feeling, or you could say what made him joyful. Alternate translation: [I rejoice that Yahweh is alive] or [How wonderful that Yahweh lives]

The expression **blessed be** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And I bless my rock]
See how you translated the similar expression in [22:32](../22/32.md). Alternate translation: [the one who keeps me safe]

The expression **be exalted** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and I exalt the God of the rock of my salvation]

David is using the possessive form to describe **God** as characterized by being the **rock** of his **salvation**. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the God who is the rock of my salvation]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the God who is the rock that saves me]

David is speaking of God as if he were a large rock or cliff where David could find safety from his enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the God who saves me by keeping me safe]

text: the God who avenges me and brings down nations beneath me,

translation_challanges.note: Here David is speaking of conquering peoples as if they were being brought **down** physically under his feet. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and defeating peoples before me]

text: who frees me from my enemies. You exalt me above my foes; You rescue me from violent men.

translation_challanges.note: By **bringing me out from my enemies**, David means escaping from being confined or restrained by his enemies. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and bringing me out from the confinement of my enemies]

Here David is speaking of his enemies as if they were physically **arising** upward to attack him, and he speaks of God as physically **lifting** him up above them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you make me prevail over those who attack me] or [And you protect me from those who oppose me]

David is not referring to a specific **man of violence**. He means violent people in general. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [from violent men]

Here David is using the plural **violences** where he could have used the singular form. This suggests that he is using the plural form to emphasize the severity and continuity of the violence that this **man** commits or attempts. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use the singular and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [great violence]

text: Therefore I will praise You, O LORD, among the nations; I will sing praises to Your name.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **name** represents Yahweh himself, in light of his fame and reputation. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [to you] or [to you, Yahweh]

text: Great salvation He brings to His king. He shows loving devotion to His anointed, to David and his descendants forever.”

translation_challanges.note: Jewish scribes instructed synagogue readers to say “a tower of salvation to his king” when they got to this phrase. That could have been the original reading. (There is a difference of only one letter between these readings in Hebrew.) If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the one saving his king by great deeds]

The expression **his anointed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [to the one he anointed]

Here David is speaking of his offspring as if they were actually **seed**. Just as a seed can grow into a plant that produces more seeds, David’s descendants would continue to come from his family line. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and to his descendants]

text: These are the last words of David: “The oracle of David son of Jesse, the oracle of the man raised on high, the one anointed by the God of Jacob, and the sweet psalmist of Israel:

translation_challanges.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. Hebrew poetry was based on this kind of repetition, and it would be good to show this to your readers by including both phrases in your translation rather than combining them. It may be clearer in your language to connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Review from your work on [chapter 22](../22/01.md) how you decided as a team to represent Hebrew poetry in your translation. Alternate translation: [An oracle of David the son of Jesse, yes, an oracle of the man raised to height] or [An oracle of David the son of Jesse, who was a man raised to height]

The expression **raised** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the man whom God raised to height]

The author is speaking of David’s position of authority as if it were a **height**. He means that God gave David great power and honor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the man whom God put in an important position]

The expression **the anointed of the God of Jacob** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the one whom the God of Jacob anointed]

The author is using the possessive form to describe **the God of Jacob** that is characterized by **Jacob**, meaning this is the God who chose Jacob and his descendants and who made covenant promises to them. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the God with whom the descendants of Jacob are in a covenant relationship]

The author is using the possessive form to describe **songs** that people in **Israel** heard and sang. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [and the one in whose songs the Israelites delighted]

text: The Spirit of the LORD spoke through me; His word was on my tongue.

translation_challanges.note: These two clauses say basically the same thing as the previous verse. See the discussion in the Introduction to [chapter 22](../22/01.md) of how Hebrew poetry was based on the repetition of words, phrases, and ideas. Recall how you decided as a team represent Hebrew poetry in your translation. Alternate translation: [The Spirit of Yahweh spoke by me, yes, his word was on my tongue] or [The Spirit of Yahweh gave me the words to speak for him]
David is using the term **word** to represent what he said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I spoke his word]

David is using his **tongue** to represent all of himself in the act of speaking. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and I spoke what he wanted me to say]

text: The God of Israel spoke; the Rock of Israel said to me, ‘He who rules the people with justice, who rules in the fear of God,

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [22:2](../22/02.md). Alternate translation: [the Protector of Israel]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [said that a righteous one]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [over people]

text: is like the light of the morning at sunrise of a cloudless dawn, the glistening after the rain on the sprouting grass of the earth.’

translation_challanges.note: The point of this comparison is that just as **the light of morning** is beneficial and brings blessing, so does a righteous ruler. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [and is a source of blessing, like the light of morning]
Here, **brightness** represents sunshine or sunlight. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from sunshine]

text: Is not my house right with God? For He has established with me an everlasting covenant, ordered and secured in every part. Will He not bring about my full salvation and my every desire?

translation_challanges.note: Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Alternate translation: [After all, is not]

David is using the question form to make a strong statement about how God has blessed his family. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [that is the way my house is with God!]

As in [1:12](../01/12.md) and similar contexts, **house** here means all the people descended from a particular person. It envisions them as if they were one household living together. In this specific context, David is using the term **house** to mean his dynasty, his royal line of descendants who would rule after him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [my royal dynasty]
Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Use a connecting word or phrase that would indicate this in your language. Alternate translation: [I say this because he has made]

The expressions **ordered** and **secured** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and he has ordered it in everything and secured it]
Here the word **For** introduces not a reason but an explanation. Use a connecting word or phrase that would indicate this in your language. Alternate translation: [Indeed, all my salvation]

David is using the question form to emphasize that God will certainly do what he is describing. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [he will certainly make sprout all my salvation and every desire!]

Here David is speaking of his salvation and desire as if they were plants that God would cause to grow. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he will certainly bring about all my salvation and every desire]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **salvation** and **desire**, you could express the same ideas in other ways. Alternate translation: [he will certainly save me completely and give me everything that I desire]

text: But the worthless are all like thorns raked aside, for they can never be gathered by hand.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the adjective **wicked** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [But wicked people]

The point of this comparison is that just as **thorns** are worthless and thrown away, so are the **wicked**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [will be rejected like a thorn]

The expression **thrown away** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [that people throw away because it hurts to hold it in their hands]

Here the author is using the pronoun **they** in a general sense, not to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [one does not take] or [people do not take]

text: The man who touches them must be armed with iron or with the shaft of a spear. The fire burns them to ashes in the place where they lie.”

translation_challanges.note: The expression **will be filled** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But the man who touches them will fill his hand with iron or the wood of a spear]

The author is using **filled with iron or the wood of a spear** as a common expression of his culture to mean “will need to use an iron tool or spear shaft to handle them.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But a man will only touch them with an iron tool or spear shaft that he is holding]

Here, **wood of a spear** represents the shaft or handle of a spear. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [or the shaft of a spear]

The author is repeating forms of the verb **burned** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [And they will surely be burned]

The expression **burning, they will be burned** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And people will surely burn them]

The author is using **in place** as a common expression of his culture to mean “where they are, without moving them.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [on the spot] or [without carrying them away]

text: These are the names of David’s mighty men: Josheb-basshebeth the Tahchemonite was chief of the Three. He wielded his spear against eight hundred men, whom he killed at one time.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the image of the **head** to represent leadership. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [was the leader of]

The author is using the adjective **Three** as a noun to mean a certain kind of person. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [the three greatest warrior champions]

The author is using **lifting his spear** as a common expression of his culture to mean “fighting.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [He was fighting]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [whom he all slew at one time]

text: Next in command was Eleazar son of Dodo the Ahohite. As one of the three mighty men, he went with David to taunt the Philistines who had gathered for battle at Pas-dammim. The men of Israel retreated,

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about **among the three warriors with David** with the phrase about Eleazar’s genealogy. Alternate translation: [And after him among the three warriors with David was Eleazar the son of Dodo, the son of Ahohi]

The pronoun **they** refers to the Israelite soldiers, while the pronoun **themselves** refers to the Philistines. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [When the Israelite soldiers taunted the Philistines, who had gathered themselves]

The author assumes that his readers will know that by **there**, he means Pas Dammim, a place where the Israelites and Philistines frequently fought battles. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 11:13](../../1ch/11/13.md) states the name of this place explicitly, and you could do the same in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [at Pas Dammim]

The author is using taunting **the Philistines**, the first thing that the Israelites did in this battle, to represent everything they did in the entire battle. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When they fought the Philistines]

By **went up**, the author means the Israelite soldiers retreated to higher ground away from the battle. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and the men of Israel retreated to higher ground]

text: but Eleazar stood his ground and struck the Philistines until his hand grew weary and stuck to his sword. The LORD brought about a great victory that day. Then the troops returned to him, but only to plunder the dead.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression “you, you know” in [17:20](../17/20.md). Alternate translation: [for his part, he arose]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:14](../02/14.md). Alternate translation: [he himself took action and slew]

By **struck the Philistines**, the author means that Eleazar killed Philistine soldiers. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [and killed Philistine soldiers]

The author seems to be using he word **hand** in its first instance to represent the power of a person. (In the second instance, it refers to Eleazar’s actual hand.) If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he had used all of his strength]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **salvation**, you could express the same idea in another way, here and in [verse 12](../23/12.md). Alternate translation: [And Yahweh powerfully saved the Israelites]

text: And after him was Shammah son of Agee the Hararite. When the Philistines had banded together near a field full of lentils, Israel’s troops fled from them.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the phrase **full of lentils** as a common expression of his culture to mean that there were lentils that had been planted and had grown up and ripened in this part of the field of battle. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the lentils that had been planted in a portion of the field there had grown up and ripened]

The author is using the **face** of the Philistines to represent running their presence. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from the presence of the Philistines] or [to get away from the Philistines]

text: But Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field, defended it, and struck down the Philistines. So the LORD brought about a great victory.

translation_challanges.note: The author is describing one event before describing another event that preceded it. If it would be helpful your language, you may wish to relate these events in the order in which they happened. Alternate translation: [and he struck the Philistines, and he delivered it]

By **struck**, the author means in this context that he killed Philistine soldiers in battle. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. See the discussion of the term “struck” in the Introduction to 2 Samuel. Alternate translation: [and he killed the Philistines]

text: At harvest time, three of the thirty chief men went down to David at the cave of Adullam, while a company of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the image of the **head** to mean a leader or chief. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [chief]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [And … went]

The traditional Hebrew text reads “the harvest.” The ULT follows that reading. The parallel passage in [1 Chronicles 11:15](../../1ch/11/15.md) reads “the rock.” That may have been the original reading, since it suits the grammar and context better and involves a difference of only one letter. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

text: At that time David was in the stronghold, and the garrison of the Philistines was at Bethlehem.

translation_challanges.note: It might seem that saying “then” in both parts of this verse would be extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could say “then” in only one part of the verse, wherever it would be more natural in your language to say that.

text: David longed for water and said, “Oh, that someone would get me a drink of water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem!”

translation_challanges.note: Since what David says in the rest of the verse indicates what he **desired**, you do not need to explain that here at the beginning of the verse by saying something such as, “And David desired to have something to drink.”

David is using the question form to express his strong desire for water from the well. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [I wish that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem that {is} at the gate!]

The term for **water** is always plural in Hebrew. Different languages may need to use a singular form in certain contexts, as the ULT does here and elsewhere. If your language would use a plural form in these contexts, it would be appropriate to do that in your translation.

text: So the three mighty men broke through the Philistine camp, drew water from the well near the gate of Bethlehem, and brought it back to David. But he refused to drink it; instead, he poured it out to the LORD,

translation_challanges.note: The pouring out of the water was a symbolic action by which David showed that this water, obtained at great risk by his men, was too precious to drink, and it deserved to be offered to Yahweh instead. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text of your translation or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and he offered it as a sacrifice to Yahweh] or [and he poured it out on the ground as an offering to Yahweh]

text: saying, “Far be it from me, O LORD, to do this! Is this not the blood of the men who risked their lives?” So he refused to drink it. Such were the exploits of the three mighty men.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [20:20](../20/20.md). Alternate translation: [Far be it from me]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [from drinking the blood of the men having gone with their lives]

David is using ** having gone with their lives** as a common expression of his culture to mean “who risked their lives.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the blood of the men who risked their lives to get it]

David is speaking as if the water that the men brought were actually their **blood**. He means that the water represents the danger into which these men put their lives to get it for him. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [this water that I am pouring out, since the blood of these men could just as easily have been poured out when they risked their lives to get it]

The author is offering a summary of the stories he has just related. This signals the end of this section about these **three warriors**. Use a natural way in your language to offer a summary that concludes a section. Alternate translation: [Those are some of the things that David’s three mighty warriors did for him] or [So ends the account of what these three warriors did]

text: Now Abishai, the brother of Joab and son of Zeruiah, was chief of the Three, and he wielded his spear against three hundred men, killed them, and won a name along with the Three.

translation_challanges.note: The author is identifying **Abishai** as the **brother of Joab** and the **son of Zeruiah**. (Joab was also the son of Zeruiah, but the author is making clear that Zeruiah was the mother of Abishai. She could have been the mother of Joab without being the mother of Abishai.) Abishai was Joab’s younger brother. Your language may have its own terms or expressions for these relationships. Alternate translation: [And Abishai, who was the brother of Joab and the son of Zeruiah]
The word **Zeruiah** is the name of a woman, David’s older sister. See how you translated her name in [2:13](../02/13.md).

The author seems to be describing two different groups of three warriors. The ULT distinguishes between them by treating the word **Three** as a title (uppercase) when it describes the great warriors of the first rank, Josheb Basshebeth, Eleazar, and Shammah ([23:8–12](../23/08.md)), and by treating the word **three** as a description (lowercase) when it describes the great warriors of the second rank, Abishai, Benaiah, and another unnamed warrior ([23:13–23](../23/13.md)). Your language may have a convention of its own that you could use to distinguish between these groups, or you could use descriptive phrases, as the UST does. Some versions express the interpretation that Abishai was the commander of the Three, that is, the great warriors of the first rank. Other versions follow some ancient manuscripts and say that Abishai was the commander of the Thirty, the warriors listed in [23:24–39](../23/24.md). If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

The author is using the image of the **head** to represent a leader or commander. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he was the commander]
See how you translated the similar expression in [23:8](../23/08.md). Alternate translation: [and he was fighting]
See how you translated the similar expression in [23:8](../23/08.md). Alternate translation: [whom he slew]

Here, **name** represents reputation or honor. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language, here and in [verse 22](../23/22.md). Alternate translation: [And he had as great a reputation as the Three]

text: Was he not more honored than the Three? And he became their commander, even though he was not included among the Three.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the question form for emphasis to affirm that Abishai was indeed the most honored of the three. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [He was certainly the most honored of the three.]

The expression **he was the most honored** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [People certainly honored him the most of the three]

Here, **come to** represents joining or achieving the same level of status as the Three. The verse means that although Abishai was a great warrior and was highly honored, he did not achieve membership in or equal status with the Three. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly, here and in [verse 23](../23/23.md). Alternate translation: [But he did not join the ranks of the Three] or [But he did achieve the same exploits and reputation as the Three]

text: And Benaiah son of Jehoiada was a man of valor from Kabzeel, a man of many exploits. He struck down two champions of Moab, and on a snowy day he went down into a pit and killed a lion.

translation_challanges.note: In certain contexts, biblical authors and characters use the expression **son of** to indicate that a person has the characteristic of something. In this case, the author is saying that Benaiah has the characteristic of **valor**. See how you translated the similar expression in [12:5](../12/05.md). Alternate translation: [was characterized by being a man of valor]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [a doer of many great deeds]

The author is stating the pronoun **he** separately in each of these instances, even though the verbs translated as **he struck** and **he went down** already include this meaning. He is doing that to confirm Benaiah’s exclusive personal role in accomplishing these feats. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that the author is confirming Benaiah’s exclusive personal role. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [He single-handedly struck … And he went down alone]

Interpreters do not understand exactly what the term **Ariel** means. However, many interpreters believe that it may be describing warrior champions as lion-like, that is, strong and fierce. Alternate translation: [two mighty champions of Moab] or [two fierce warrior heroes of Moab]

While the term **Ariel** is singular in the original, since the author is referring to **two** such people, it may be more natural in your language to use a plural form. Alternate translation: [Ariels]

If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information that **Benaiah** was **from Kabzeel** with the information that his father was **Jehoiada**. Alternate translation: [And Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, from Kabzeel, was a son of a man of valor, many deeds]

text: He also struck down an Egyptian, a huge man. Although the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, Benaiah went against him with a club, snatched the spear from his hand, and killed the Egyptian with his own spear.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using **a man of appearance** as a common expression of his culture to mean a giant. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a man who was a terror to behold] or [a giant]

The author seems to mean that Benaiah **went down** from the Israelite battle lines on a safe height, and he went into a valley to fight this **man of Egypt** in single combat between the battle lines. Alternate translation: [and he went into a valley to fight him in single combat]

text: These were the exploits of Benaiah son of Jehoiada, who won a name along with the three mighty men.
He was most honored among the Thirty, but he did not become one of the Three. And David appointed him over his guard.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **he was honored** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [People honored him more than the Thirty]

text: Now these were members of the Thirty: Asahel the brother of Joab, Elhanan son of Dodo of Bethlehem,

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you may want to put the information about **Asahel the brother of Joab** with the statement that he was among **the Thirty**. Alternate translation: [Among the Thirty was Asahel the brother of Joab]

text: Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
Helez the Paltite, Ira son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
Abiezer the Anathothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ittai son of Ribai from Gibeah of the Benjamites,
Benaiah the Pirathonite, Hiddai from the brooks of Gaash,
Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, Jonathan

translation_challanges.note: It is possible that here the author is using the plural term **sons** to introduce a single individual, as in [Genesis 46:23](../../gen/46/23.md), “And the sons of Dan, Hushim.” Alternate translation: [Jonathan the son of Jashen]

text: son of Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam son of Sharar the Hararite,

translation_challanges.note: Since the author lists **Shammah the Hararite** as one of the Three greatest warriors in [23:11–12](../23/11.md), his name seems out of place in this list of the Thirty. Some interpreters suggest that the explanation is that the Jonathan mentioned in the previous verse was his son. Some versions accordingly read, at the end of the previous verse and the beginning of this one, “Jonathan the son of Shammah the Hararite.” The reading in [1 Chronicles 11:34](../../1ch/11/34.md) suggests this as a possible reading. If a translation of the Bible exists in your region, you may wish to use the reading that it uses. If a translation of the Bible does not exist in your region, you may wish to use the reading of the ULT.

text: Eliphelet son of Ahasbai the Maacathite, Eliam son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
Hezro the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
Igal son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor-bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah,
Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
and Uriah the Hittite. There were thirty-seven in all.

translation_challanges.note: The total of **37** warriors seems to be the sum of the thirty-one listed in [23:24–39](../23/24.md), described as the Thirty, and those said to be greater than these Thirty, that is, the Three described in [23:11–12](../23/11.md) and the three described in ([23:13–23](../23/13.md) (although one of them is not named). To help your readers see how this total reflects the names the author provides, you may wish to translate “Thirty” in [23:24](../23/24.md) as a title, as the ULT does, rather than as a number (“30”).

text: Again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and He stirred up David against them, saying, “Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.”

translation_challanges.note: When the author says that **the nose of Yahweh added to burn**, he is using two common expressions of his culture See how you translated the expressions “nose” and “burn” in [6:7](../06/07.md) and the expression “added” in [3:34](../03/34.md). Alternate translation: [And Yahweh became angry with Israel again] or [And Yahweh continued to be angry with Israel]

It seems unlikely that this is a direct quotation of something that Yahweh said, since Yahweh would not command someone to do something and then punish that person for doing it. This could mean: (1) that the author is summarizing here what he quotes David more fully as saying in the next verse. Alternate translation: [so that David said, “Go, count Israel and Judah]; (2) that the author is depicting Yahweh as having said something in order to convey the idea that Yahweh led that person to do that thing. This would be similar to [16:10](../16/10.md), where David says of Shimei, “If he curses because Yahweh has said to him, ‘Curse David,’” meaning, “If he curses because Yahweh has led him to curse me.” Alternate translation: [leading him to go and count Israel and Judah]

text: So the king said to Joab the commander of his army, who was with him, “Go now throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and register the troops, so that I may know their number.”

translation_challanges.note: This seems to be a reference to the corps of soldiers stationed at the court who always remained on active military duty, that is, to David’s permanent army. The author describes these troops in [15:18](../15/18.md) and [20:7](../20/07.md), and he says in [8:16](../08/16.md) that Joab commanded them. David wanted to know how many further men were eligible for military service, that is, how great were his reserves. Alternate translation: [his standing army]
To decide how to translate this expression here and in [verse 15](../24/15.md), see how you translated it in [3:10](../03/10.md). Alternate translation: [throughout the entire territory of Israel]

By **the people**, in this context David means the men who could serve in his army. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the fighting men]

text: But Joab replied to the king, “May the LORD your God multiply the troops a hundred times over, and may the eyes of my lord the king see it. But why does my lord the king want to do such a thing?”

translation_challanges.note: Joab is using **like them and like them ** as a common expression of his culture to mean “such as they already are.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a hundred times more people than there already are]

Joab is using David’s **eyes** to represent all of him in the act of seeing. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and may my lord the king see this with his own eyes]

Even though Joab is addressing David directly, he is speaking of him in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a respectful form in the second person. Alternate translation: [and may you, my lord the king, see this with your own eyes]

Joab is using **delight in this matter** as a common expression of his culture to mean “want to do this.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But why does my lord the king want to do this?]

Joab is using the question form to politely express his disapproval of David’s plan to count the people. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [But I do not understand why my lord the king wants to do this.] or [But my lord the king should not want to do this!]

text: Nevertheless, the king’s word prevailed against Joab and against the commanders of the army. So Joab and the commanders of the army departed from the presence of the king to register the troops of Israel.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **the word of the king** represents what King David said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But what the king said prevailed against Joab and over the commanders of the army]

The author is speaking of this **word** as if it had been a living thing that **prevailed** in a contest against Joab and the commanders. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the king’s command was stronger than Joab’s objections and those of the army commanders]

Here, **to the face of** represents being in the presence of a person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from the presence of the king]

text: They crossed the Jordan and camped near Aroer, south of the town in the middle of the valley, and proceeded toward Gad and Jazer.

translation_challanges.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and then they went to Gad and to Jazer]

text: Then they went to Gilead and the land of Tahtim-hodshi, and on to Dan-jaan and around to Sidon.

translation_challanges.note: The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and then they went around to Sidon]

text: They went toward the fortress of Tyre and all the cities of the Hivites and Canaanites. Finally, they went on to the Negev of Judah, to Beersheba.
At the end of nine months and twenty days, having gone through the whole land, they returned to Jerusalem.
And Joab reported to the king the total number of the troops. In Israel there were 800,000 men of valor who drew the sword, and in Judah there were 500,000.

translation_challanges.note: The phrase **men of valor** refers to men who had the qualities of strength and courage. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **valor**, you could express this idea with words that describe men who are brave and strong in battle. Alternate translation: [valiant men] or [strong men]

The author is using this phrase, **drawing the sword**, to mean soldiers, by association with the way that soldiers at this time drew swords in order to fight battles. Alternate translation: [who could serve as soldiers]

It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you could shorten it. Alternate translation: [and the men of Judah were 500,000]

text: After David had numbered the troops, his conscience was stricken and he said to the LORD, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done. Now, O LORD, I beg You to take away the iniquity of Your servant, for I have acted very foolishly.”

translation_challanges.note: Here, the **heart** represents a person’s thoughts, feelings, and conscience. When the author says that David’s heart **struck** him, he means that David came to feel guilty about what he had done. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But David’s conscience troubled him] or [But David felt guilty]

As the rest of this expression shows, the pronoun **this** refers to David’s action of counting the people of Israel. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [after this action of counting the people]

David is speaking of himself in the third person as **your servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [the iniquity that I, your servant, have committed]
Here the word **for** introduces not a reason but an elaboration. David is using it to characterize his previous statement about having sinned greatly. Alternate translation: [indeed]

text: When David got up in the morning, the word of the LORD had come to Gad the prophet, David’s seer:

translation_challanges.note: The words that the ULT translates as **And … and** indicates that the word of Yahweh came to Gad at the same time as when David **arose in the morning**. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could describe the time relationship more explicitly. Alternate translation: [When David arose in the morning, the word of Yahweh came to Gad]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:4](../07/04.md). Alternate translation: [and Yahweh spoke a message to Gad]

text: “Go and tell David that this is what the LORD says: ‘I am offering you three options. Choose one of them, and I will carry it out against you.’”

translation_challanges.note: There are three levels of quotation here. Yahweh is speaking (level 1) and quoting what he wants Gad to say (level 2), which is that he, Yahweh, has a message for David. Yahweh then presents this message to David as a direct quotation (level 3). Use the appropriate punctuation in your language to mark these levels of quotation. Alternatively, you could translate this so that there are not second-level and third-level quotations (see the Quotes within Quotes note).

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Go and tell David that I say that I am lifting three over him and that he is to choose one from them for himself and I will do it to him]

Yahweh is using the adjective **Three** as a noun to mean three things or options. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [Three things]

Yahweh is speaking of the three choices of punishment as if they were objects he could **lift** and hold over David. This is a metaphor that indicates that Yahweh is presenting these choices to David and has authority over how they will be carried out. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I am laying out for you] or [I am presenting for you to consider]

text: So Gad went and said to David, “Do you choose to endure three years of famine in your land, three months of fleeing the pursuit of your enemies, or three days of plague upon your land? Now then, think it over and decide how I should reply to Him who sent me.”

translation_challanges.note: The implication is that Gad declared to David the three choices that Yahweh had given him, as stated in the previous verse. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and he declared to him what Yahweh had said]

Here, **to the face of** represents David being in front of his enemies. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [n front of your enemies and he is pursuing you]
Since the word **enemies** is plural, it may be more natural in your language to refer back to it with a plural pronoun. Alternate translation: [in front of your enemies while they pursue you]

Gad is using **know and see** as a common expression of his culture to mean “consider thoughtfully.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [consider thoughtfully]

Gad is speaking of a message or reply as if it were a **word** that was an object he could carry back to Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [what answer I shall give]

text: David answered Gad, “I am deeply distressed. Please, let us fall into the hand of the LORD, for His mercies are great; but do not let me fall into the hands of men.”

translation_challanges.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since **his mercies are many** gives the reason why David says **let us fall into the hand of Yahweh**. Alternate translation: [since the mercies of Yahweh are many, let us fall into his hand]

Here, **hand** represents the capability of a person. In this case, it refers to Yahweh’s power to punish and his ability to show mercy. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [let Yahweh be the one to punish us]

In this verse David uses the first-person singular pronoun **me** when asking God not to let him fall into human hands, even though he had just used “us” when speaking about falling into God’s hands. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use plural pronouns consistently, since David is speaking on behalf of all Israel. Alternate translation: [do not let us fall]

text: So the LORD sent a plague upon Israel from that morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand of the people from Dan to Beersheba died.

translation_challanges.note: The author is using the possessive form to describe a **time** that is characterized by its having been appointed. If a speaker of your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [the appointed time]

Here the masculine term **men** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [people]

text: But when the angel stretched out his hand to destroy Jerusalem, the LORD relented from the calamity and said to the angel who was destroying the people, “Enough! Withdraw your hand now!” At that time the angel of the LORD was by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

translation_challanges.note: The author could be using the same expression that occurs earlier in the book, in [1:14](../01/14.md) and [18:12](../18/12.md), to mean that the angel was preparing to use violence (in the form of this plague) against the people of the city of Jerusalem. When Yahweh tells him to **lower** his **hand**, that could mean that he is not to afflict the people with the plague. However, since David sees the angel, it seems more likely that the angel actually had reached out and upward with his hand and that Yahweh told him to put his hand back down and not use it to cause the plague. So you may choose to translate this literally.

The term **the angel** refers to the angel whom God sent to bring a plague on Israel. You could identify this **angel** more fully in that way here. However, this angel is identified in [verse 17](../24/17.md) as “the striker among the people.” Because this information appears in the following verse, you may not find a need to explain about the angel further here.

text: When David saw the angel striking down the people, he said to the LORD, “Surely I, the shepherd, have sinned and acted wickedly. But these sheep, what have they done? Please, let Your hand fall upon me and my father’s house.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [1:2](../01/02.md). Alternate translation: [Listen]

David is stating the pronoun **I** separately in each of these instances, even though the verbs translated as **I have sinned** and **I have committed iniquity** already include this meaning. He is doing that acknowledge his personal responsibility for sinning by taking a census of the Israelite soldiers. If a speaker of your language would use an explicit pronoun for this same purpose, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of showing that the David is acknowledging his personal responsibility. It may not be necessary to represent the separately stated pronoun explicitly. Alternate translation: [I was the one who sinned, yes, I was the one who committed iniquity]

These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine them and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [I myself have greatly sinned]

David is using the question form to emphasize that the people of Israel were innocent and had done nothing wrong. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [But these sheep have done nothing wrong!]

David is speaking of his subjects as if they were **sheep**. He means that they are innocent and defenseless, like sheep who depend on their shepherd to protect them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But these innocent people]

Here, **hand** represents God’s power to punish. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [use your power to punish me and the house of my father]

text: And that day Gad came to David and said to him, “Go up and build an altar to the LORD on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [2:1](../02/01.md). Alternate translation: [Go]

text: So David went up at the word of Gad, just as the LORD had commanded.

translation_challanges.note: Here, **word** represents what Gad said to David. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [according to what Gad had said to him]

text: When Araunah looked out and saw the king and his servants coming toward him, he went out and bowed facedown before the king.

translation_challanges.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [14:4](../14/04.md).

text: “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” Araunah said. “To buy your threshing floor,” David replied, “that I may build an altar to the LORD, so that the plague upon the people may be halted.”

translation_challanges.note: Araunah is speaking of David in the third person as **my lord the king** to show respect, and he is speaking of himself in the third person as David’s **servant** to show humility. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate these expressions with a respectful form in the second person and in a humble form in the first person. Alternate translation: [Why have you, my lord the king, come to me, your servant]

David is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [I have come to buy]

The expression **the plague may be restrained** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [that Yahweh may restrain the plague]

text: Araunah said to David, “May my lord the king take whatever seems good to him and offer it up. Here are the oxen for a burnt offering and the threshing sledges and ox yokes for the wood.

translation_challanges.note: Araunah is using the common expression of his culture **the good in his eyes** to mean “whatever seems good to him” or “whatever he chooses.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [whatever he sees fit]

text: O king, Araunah gives all these to the king.” He also said to the king, “May the LORD your God accept you.”

“No,” replied the king, “I insist on paying a price, for I will not offer to the LORD my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.

translation_challanges.note: David is repeating forms of the verb **buy** in order to intensify his expression of the idea that it conveys. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [I will certainly buy it]

These **50 shekels** of silver weighed about 570 grams or 1.25 pounds. In your translation, you could use the ancient measurement and spell the word “shekel” the way it sounds in your language. You could also use the metric measurement given in the UST or use the measurement that your language and culture customarily use. Alternatively, you could use the ancient measurement and put a modern measurement in parentheses in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [570 grams of silver] or [50 pieces of silver weighing about one and a quarter pounds]

text: And there he built an altar to the LORD and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. Then the LORD answered the prayers on behalf of the land, and the plague upon Israel was halted.

translation_challanges.note: The expression **was entreated** and **was restrained** are passive verbal forms. If your language would not use those forms, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And thus David entreated Yahweh for the land, and Yahweh restrained the plague from against Israel]
